content:
Posted: April 1
												This is the best game I have ever played, and it's not because of nostalgia. In one week, it will be exactly a year since I started exploring the magical world of Morrowind. I love everything about this game: the quests, the music, the characters, the lore. The lore is some of the most fascinating I have ever seen in a video game, and trust me, it's a wild ride to discover. You should avoid spoilers at all costs, but look at this picture[img11.deviantart.net] before you begin your journey. It might not make sense at first, but the more you play, the more you will eventually understand :)That being said, this game is far from flawless by modern standards and requires a lot of patience to play. Here's my advice for all beginners: Turn down the difficulty. Combat is the worst part of this game, and for a new player, it's a living hell. Make sure you understand how to fight, then gradually increase the difficulty when the game is starting to feel easier. Talk to everyone. Morrowind will not hold your hand, and if you don't ask questions or listen to what people say, you will be completely lost. Save your game often, or it will be very irritating when you inevitably die and have to start your progress all over again. If you're coming from Skyrim or Oblivion, read this.[en.uesp.net] Download the Morrowind Code Patch.[download.fliggerty.com] It's essential while playing, but abstain from downloading any other mods until you're farther into the game. If you hear battle music and can't figure out where the enemy is, look up.If you love The Elder Scrolls or old-school RPGs, give Morrowind a try! It's the most beautiful experience I ever had in a video game, and I highly recommend it at any price.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												I have sunk countless hours into Morrowind since before I got this game on Steam and I plan to sink in even more for years to come. To me, Morrowind is a timeless game and despite criticism on the game's age and whether or not it holds up to this day, this game is truly a classic. To be fair, this was my first 'Elder Scrolls' game that I played back when I had the original X-Box over a decade ago so some may contribute my praises to nostalgia, but hear me out. Very few games captivated me the same was as Morrowind did. The level of freedom this game gave was unparalleled back in the day. It has a large map open to exploration, tons of side quests, amazing soundtrack, and deep lore. Despite these praises, it would be difficult to recommend this game to newcomers considering numerous role-playing games that have sprung over time that would overshadow this game in terms of content and overall experiences with examples such as 'The Witcher' or 'Mass Effect' but I argue that this game still holds up. Some knock this game for its visuals which I think people need to let that one slide considering this game was released in 2002 and for a game of it's sheer scope and content, was pretty revolutionary for its time. Another huge critique would be the combat which could agitate new players since the combat relies on a form of dice-roll mechanic similar to the likes of MMOs where there is a chance the attack could miss despite the enemy CLEARLY taking the hit. It is indeed frustrating and I understand criticisms to this combat, but I just compare this game to the likes of 'Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic' or 'Dragon Age' with the exception that you're freely controlling each individual hit instead of your attacks being automatic.Another critique of the game is that it can be vague with directions since the whole "follow the waypoint" concept didn't become a thing until the next installment "Oblivion" so some could be frustrated when finding their way. Personally, I have never struggled with the directions of side quests and I have gotten lost from time to time, however, I always managed to find my way. I suppose everybody has different experiences. The last critique by some people, to my surprise, would be the journal. Apparently, some people don't like the first-person style writing of the journal whenever it updates you on the quests which I find shocking because I love the journal in Morrowind. It has this style that feels as though your character is documenting his/her thoughts and, in my opinion, adds a nice touch to the game.Summary:I would recommend this game only if you keep an open mind. If you're a fan of the later 'Elder Scrolls' titles such as 'Skyrim' and 'Oblivion,' please give this game a shot, but try to work with its flaws. It's not a perfect game and I don't want to pass off as a fanboy, but I personally consider this game to be a masterpiece and one of my peronal favorite games ever made due to what it offers and the unique world you delve into. The environments and the experiences are like no other game I have ever played before. It's hard to recommend this game nowadays, but I hope some will appreciate it for what it has accomplished.

												It's not an easy game. If you're used to Oblivion and Skyrim, it seems rather clunky and obsolete at first. It took me several tries before I could really get into it.But man, when I got into it, I got into it hard.Underneath the supposedly clunky mechanics lies an RPG experience so deep and rewarding that it has yet to be matched to this day. It's a game that allows for a level of player freedom that the later Elder Scrolls games could not match. Not to mention the land of Morrowind is still, to this day, a beautiful and unique world with a culture worth discovering. There are many stories to be told on this land, and once you climb over the the initial barrier to entry you will find yourself making many of your own.Morrowind is, without a doubt, a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Morrowind is an amazing game. It's got a great soundtrack, the game's world is absolutely unique and sucks you in right from the start. I'll never forget the experience of just starting this game, running away from cool beasts and being scared of the mysterious diseases. Sure, the game's got some faults, for example, the world also feels plastic because it's just NPCs going around, giving you Tolstoyian amounts of words when you click a keyword in the dialogue window. But all those faults don't diminish the game at all. However, when people talk about how good Morrowind is, they mean only the game, not the expansion packs. I mean, I don't know that for sure, but it really feels like that. Why? Because the expansions sucked. Their mediocrity is absolutely painful compared to the great work that the base game is. Oh, you don't like escort quests? There's like six of them in Bloodmoon and quite a bunch in Tribunal, not to mention that the expansions' storylines are pretty bad, all over the place and don't involve you in it any bit. You should probably steer clear from them or take a break after beating the base game and starting the expansions.

number of helpful: 29 of 34 people (85%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												A brilliant game design, and one of the best volunteers in every overall list of the most influencing video games in history. There are hordes of Morrowind fans in the world, and I am one of them. But I am not going to tell you that Morrowind is the best of RPGs, or even vouch for it as the best in Bethesda's TES series.It is not fitting for every person, but quite pervasive for those who caught the flow.There are no other game where I restarted from the very beginning so many times not because I have died from some critters, or did something wrong. I restarted this game so many times for the boundless field of possibilities of what to do with your character in that game.All of the Morrowind game mechanics, would that be fighting, character evolution, story and quests patterns, they all may look quite dated, clumsy and unpolished. But all of those start to make sense after you discover the biggest hook of the game. Not only it is one of the most glorious open-world adventures, it is also a great sandbox game. One of the greatest sandboxes in the whole RPG genre, that's a good definition.Morrowind gives you all the tools to make your adventure the most unique in the world. The first and the most useful tool for it is the magic. That part is much more sophisticated than in previous and later Elder Scrolls games, for you have the immense variety of effects that you can combine in spells, embed in your inventory, drastically changing not only yourself, but the whole world around you. You could kill a demigod, capture his soul and use it to create the most powerful weapon. That could be the large portion of the plot in another game’s main quest, but in Morrowind you can do it all on your own initiative without the game saying that you should do it. Or hey, forget the uber-weapon, use the soul of the demigod you killed for permanently warming your trousers, you can do that too.Morrowind was released in 2002, and vanilla version surely looks quite aged for modern standards. For graphics, for clunky mechanics, for difficulty, but with all that, it is still one of the most cunning worlds ever created. It is still looks great, it is still gives you the same enormous field to play with magic, dozens of heroic quest deeds and much more things you expecting from an open-world game. So I hope you'll share the delight from this game with me and millions of other fans of that living monument of the game design.Morrowind marks a turning point in Bethesda’s career, before they figured out that going for the wider audience and console markets, aiming for the lowest common denominator and spending more budget on marketing than development will make more profit than making actually good games. Unfortunately, we will never see another game like Morrowind ever again, let alone a successor. Oblivion and Skyrim are worse in almost every way, and take away more than they add. One step forward, three steps back if you will. Fortunately, digital goods do not have an expiration date, and old games can still be played and enjoyed years after release.The game combines modern graphics with classic functionality. As such, many things will be determined by dice rolls. Many inexperienced players have expressed their frustration when not hitting enemies in combat. Let me just say this, it is perfectly possible to create a character who, even at level one, never misses an evenly matched opponent. Though this is not something a newbie would come up with.Morrowind’s main selling point is the open world, which is available to you once you complete the short tutorial. Unlike later games in the series, where you are the center of the universe and the world revolves around you, in Morrowind you start as a nobody, dropped in a world that would exist with or without you.Unlike the later games in the series, that underwater cave at the edge of the world will not have exactly the same treasure and enemies as the dungeon just across the tutorial town. The chest at the bottom of the biggest and most dangerous dungeon will not contain a rusty iron dagger just because you were at too low of a level. Poor bandits will not wear armor worth as much as an entire city just because you are high-level. The world is there, and waiting for you to explore it. Here, a young thief won't just have to steal silver spoons and forks because that's all he will find. All the best gear in the game is available right from the start, although well-guarded.  Also, people are not mysteriously immortal just because you might need to talk to them later. Morrowind lets you do just what you want to do, without trying to protect the player from his/her stupidity through artificial barriers and limitations.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												This game is very different from the later elder scrolls games, so when you start playing don't expect Skyrim with 2002 graphics.  First of all it is much more of a hardcore RPG than skyrim and Oblivion, you will need lots of trial and error with what to do when it comes to what the right things to say to people are, where to go and how you should build your character.  There are so many quests to do in cities like Vivec that they will keep you busy for plenty of hours, and all the things to do outside like exploring caves or maybe venturing up north to explore the dangerous island of Soltheim.  Like I said earlier about it being way more hardcore, you will have to walk everywhere on foot with the acception of paying gold to people to get to major cities.  Also there are no quest markers so you will have to look at your journal for directions and go around asking people for more detailed directions.  The dialouge in this game even though not all your conversations are fully voiced, they are so detailed and emersive you will read it for 10 minutes straight because it's so intresting.Though you will need to spend lots of time to do quests and to get around in general, I find it to be much more realistic this way and it makes you feel like you're an actual adventurer in the province of Morrowind.9.7/10

content:
Posted: March 11
												Oh Morrowind, how I wished to complete your story before I reviewed you.  But you're such a massive game, and I simply can't leave you without a review.Morrowind is a huge game.  I can't describe how big it is.  And it has aged.  A lot.  Yet, I found the way the game aged poorly to actually be great.  D20 based combat that plays like an action RPG makes you realize how it feels deeper than other games having something that involves 'who loses health first,' 'hold on, let me eat some cheese wheels quick.'  The world is vast and unique, containing elements of a sci-fi planet rather than that of fantasy.  The feeling of being in the minority race, surrounded by a mainland race as you play an outlander is something that expands this lore filled game.  It has its flaws sure(cliff racers!), but in the end I love this game!It's not T rated Skyrim, it's better.  And as someone born in '98, I can easily say that once I realized what I got into, I loved it.

number of helpful: 18 of 18 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Oh man, this game is something. I can remember the first time I heard about it. Toonami, on the Cartoon Network, ran a review for Morrowind when it came out. I just remember the open world, do anything you want, mechanic appealing so much to me. I was twelve then, and had not really ever played an RPG, other than Pokemon. I had no idea what to expect. When my cousin rented the game for his original Xbox, we played it all night long. I knew this was a game that would stick with me. And it has. I have come back to this game over and over again about once ever two to three years. When Skyrim came out and I finished it, most of my friends started it over so they could play a different character. But I went back to Morrowind.Where to start Hm, well first of all, let me preface my praise for this game with a warning. A lot of modern gamers seem to have difficulty getting into these older classics. The RPG system is fairly old school. Your skill determines your chance to hit and not your damage dealt like in Oblivion and Skyrim. Some modern gamers don't like this restriction, but being a fan of the traditional RPG systems of games like FO1 and FO2, Baldur's Gate, Planescape, etc. I enjoy this system. Sure, it's hard as Hell when you first start out. You feel so incredibly weak. You're in this strange, alien world where nothing is really familiar. Instead of horses or carriages, people ride around in the hollowed out carapace of giant bugs. The abundance of plant life is generally nothing you'll recognize except for a few flowers in the more westernized cities. You really get the sense that you're alone in this wild place. You're so weak that you struggle to battle against rats and mudcrabs. Just make sure you check the "Always Use Best Attack" option in the settings menu. It helps a good deal.You also have to really play into the RPG system. This isn't Skyrim where you, a mage, can use any weapon and still be a bad♥♥♥♥♥ If you're a mage, then you won't be able to kill♥♥♥♥♥♥with a sword. Likewise, if you're a warrior, you're more likely to turn your genitals into a basket of fruit than you are to fry your enemies with magic. Try to choose a race that complements a certain class. Plan out what type of character you're going to play and then try to make your gameplay efficient in that regard.One last thing is that this game was created before voice acting was considered necessary in video games. I still argue that voice acting isn't necessary and that I'd rather see more content than less content with voice acting included. Regardless, some people find it difficult to deal without it. Really, it's not that hard to read and it just gets you into the story even more. I find myself paying more attention to the details when I'm reading as opposed to listening.Another warning is that the graphics are outdated. When Morrowind was released, it was the pinnacle of video game graphics. Screenshots of the game were advertised on the back of high end graphics cards you'd find in electronic shops. However, thanks to the game's wonderful compatibility with mods, this can totally overhauled with some excellent mods. It's possible to transform the game into something truly more beautiful than it was ever imagined to be.Controls are going to be a problem for you if you only like using a controller. I guess it would be possible to map the controls to an Xbox controller, but it wouldn't really be efficient. I imagine you'd have a lot of difficulty aiming at anything in the midst of battle. It's just as well, though, as this game is better played with a macro keyboard and mouse.Okay, now that the warning are out of the way, time for the good stuff.The writing for this game's story is phenomenal. The backstory and lore for this game is top notch. The atmosphere of the entire game is spot on. You get SO immersed into this world, so quickly. Some crazy things happen to your character in the main story that really just draws you in to the history of this world. The culture of the people in Morrowind is one of the most dynamic and interesting that I've ever seen in video game. The Dunmer culture was solidified in this game and it has obviously left an indelible mark on the series, even on into the future games like Skyrim.Speaking of which, the second expansion pack for this game (being including in this GotY bundle) is the first appearance of Solstheim. That's right, the frozen island featured in the Dragonborn DLC for Skyrim is a revisit to the beautiful little island featured in The Elder Scrolls III: Bloodmoon. Bloodmoon allows you to become a werewolf, truly one of the greatest mechanics of the series and something that was sorely missed in Oblivion.The other expansion, Tribunal doesn't add any new landmasses, but the capital city of Morrowind, Mournhold. While the city proper isn't huge, the underground sewers, and old ruins are quite expansive. The quests and story for Tribunal is just as compelling as the main quest for Morrowind and gives you the opportunity to meet yet another living god (the first being introduced to you in Morrowind's main quest).The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is just one of those games that everybody should have in their library. It's just a beautiful game in it's entirety. It does have it's flaws and bugs, but when you take an abstract look at the entire game, it is not hard at all to see why so many people consider it to be a true masterpiece. The story, setting, detail, art, and dialogue is just all so wonderful that outweighs any of it's more "dated" aspects. This game has been with me for around twelve years now and I will probably never stop playing it. There will always be times when I revisit Morrowind, as the little island of Vvardenfell was practically my backyard for my early to mid teenage years. Buy it. It is so worth it. And even if you can't get past the graphics or the lack of voice acting, then buy it anyway and get Oblivion. If you own both of these games, you can run the Morroblivion mod and play all of Morrowind's story in the Oblivion engine. The same will be true for Skywind when that mod is finished. Neither of them have voice acting yet, but the fans are trying to record it. One day, all of Morrowind will be available, fully voiced and retouched in the Oblivion and Skyrim engines.But you should experience the game in it's original engine at least once. The feel of it just adds to the magic that is Morrowind.10/10

number of helpful: 27 of 34 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Firstly, don't let the Steam statistics fool you: I have played hundreds of hours before having the game on Steam. The time for me to write a review of my favourite game ever has come, and I couldn't be happier. It was the year 1996, and the fairly young videogames studio of Bethesda was releasing The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall, the successor of the modest, quite unnoticed first chapter, TES Arena. Presenting you to a world with deep RPG mechanics, a map of the size of Great Britain and the freedom to do whatever you wanted in a sandbox, 3D world, it has become a true legend among the other RPGs of the time. Changing the paradigm, it introduced dozens of brand new mechanics and improved anothers from Arena, making it the turning point for RPGs. Straight after the release of Daggerfall, Bethesda worked on an expansion called Battlespire, that was later turned into a standalone game, and Redguard, a more action-like, dumbed down game that explored the universe and developed the lore. Meanwhile, deep into the studios of Bethesda, more shocking, jawbreaking ideas for a new game started to appear. Making a full, huge 3D detailed world filled with creatures, NPCs, enemies and with a full day/night circle seemed like an utopia, and it actually was. Being developed allways at the edge of the time's hardware, a new TES started to get shape, something bold, something unique, something terrifying and creative. Thus, TES III: Morrowind was born.    Well, enough with the story. This review will be divided into 4 aspects, graphics, story/plot, gameplay and sound, and a consideration of som other aspects. Released in 2002, as mentioned, Morrowind had two additional expansions, Bloodmoon and Tribunal. Since this in the review of the GOTY Edition, it will also take into consideration all the expansions and official add-ons.Graphics: this game runs in the Gamebryo Engine, the same engine that was used to make the next TES, Oblivion, and Fallout 3 and New Vegas, so it's an engine that spaned a very long lifetime. In 2002, the minimum requirements for this game were huge, and a state-of-the-art computer was necessary in order to run it in it's ful splendor. While some would think this was a bad optimization, in this case it's just the ludicrous ammount of details and material that was put into this game. The view distance was very short, even with the settings on the maximum, just to make the game able to run in that time's hardware. Nowadays, we can unlock those restrictions and see Morrowind in it's full splendor: for that time, it was just fantastic. From the water to the sky, going through the unique flora and the weird and suffering environment of volcanic formations, strange swamps and some environments that can't even be described due to their singularity make this one of the most inimaginable experiences in gaming. 96 out of 100. Gameplay: most people had their first contact with the TES series with the latest entry, TES V: Skyrim. Skyrim was good, but it was a game made to appeal to the casual masses, which it did. Some may also had their first contact with TES IV: Oblivion, which is, by far, the most equilibrated: the almost perfect balance between deep RPG, TES-like funcionalities, and accessibility for a smoother, more friendly experience. Yet, there is a more restrict group of gamers that had their first contact with Morrowind, or even with the oldest entries. These fans usually see the quality of the latest entries, but miss the deepness Morrowind had. the funcionalities Morowind had made it possible to do whatever you want: you want to be a vampire? You can! You want to be a werewolf? You can! you want to be a mercenary-like warrior working for a guild who gives you nasty jobs? You can! Of course all of that can be done in the other TES as well. the difference resides that in here you must have the appropriate skils to be able to do that and to even be able to accept various quests. This is just an example of the hardness Morrowind presents; From having to constantly sleep to recover health, to be unable to cast a spell properly, to the multiple hits you have to give and take in order to take down an adversary are, the confusion and sense of dispair is always present, making certain actions very rewardful. The only major problem are the menus, the combat system and the dialogue system: while they do their job, they are clumsy and could had been improved a lot. From the useless third person view to the very confusive journal and quest tracking, the interface and the combat is probably Morrowind's biggest flaw. And bugs, lots of bugs. Not as much as Oblivion and Skyrim, but yet, they started all here. 82 out of 100Story/plot: you, as usual, start as a prisioner. This time, you were released under the order of the Emperor himself, and were dropped in the forsaken island of Vvardenfell, which is a island that comprehends about half of Morrowind's total area, and the home of the Red Mountain, a volano that hosts a mad god-like man inside called Dagoth-Ur. After your release, you do some research jobs for Caius Cosades, a Blade that answers directly to the Emperor. After that apparently uninteresting research you were doing, Caius tells you a very disturbing truth that leads you to a seires of dangerous situations, in order to prove yourself as the Nerevarine, a hero who would save Morrowind from the wrath of the Red Mountain and Dagoth Ur himself. While this is just the main quest, there are still other multiple quest-lines and lots of sidequests that are very interesting and immersive. You can pretty much obtain a huge ammount of lore from the conversations, where you can select multiple topics. The quest-lines on the expansions are also unique and interesting: in bloodmoon, you go to the damned island of Solshteim (the same as in Skyrim's DLC Dragonborn) and involve yourself in a werewolf-related situation. Tribunal starts as a attemp from the Dark Brotherhood to murder you, and leads you to the mainland capital of Morrowind, Mournhold. Here, you will mess with the gods. Without any negative aspect, the plot, and all the TES lore is one of the best ever made for an RPG of this kind. It only sins for the bad organization of the journal, as mentioned above, and could use some more cutscenes or bold scenes. Yet, it's wonderful in it's own way. 95 out of 100.Sound: this is probably one of the most epic sountracks ever written for a game. May the Dunmer Gods bless the soul of Jeremy Soule for his geniusness. Also, it's filled with details: if you are not a Dunmer, Morrowind's native race of elves, you will be called some nasty and pejorative names by the people, allways depending on your race: a Orc will be called an Outlander with a very strong negative conotation, while a imperial will be seen as a "civilized" person. There are just some bugs, like the footsteps that are annoying and faulty, and the repetitive sound of "interacting with objects". 97 out of 100.Other aspects: with a humongous longetivity, to the ammount of mods the community has made, this game can give you months of fun. The Construction Kit allows you to create your own mods in a fairly easy way (though you may need some geometry knowledge), and it has a very active community even in today's time. As usual, the final score is given by the average between the 4 forementioned aspects, plus a factor of correction based on thre other aspects. So, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, my favourite game ever, and the game that brought to me the world of RPGs end up with the great score of 96 out of 100. Greatest RPG of all time, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												The best in the Elder Scrolls Series. I've been playing this game for many years, and I got the steam version at a later date. My hours would probably be triple what it shows on steam. No quest markers and limited fast travel may sound like a negative to some, but honestly it makes the game so much deeper. You have to talk to everybody, explore dialogue options, and make sure you pay attention to what NPC's say. When they tell you to go east and take a left at the sign post, they mean it. No arrow on the map is going to show you where to go. You have to use your brain. You cant just fast travel anywhere either. You must pay for trasportation, and only at other settlements. You can pay for a ship to take you to Sadrith Mora, for example, but dont expect to be able to warp to every little place you discover. Honestly, it feels more like an adventure this way. You must use your brain and explore your surroundings, like you would in the real world.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Essentially the game that shaped the elder scrolls series to what they are. A pinnacle of ''freedom of choice''. The game has no set path or quest marks, it trusts you to be smart enough to figure it out yourself. An open world RPG in the way it was meant to be, simple but hard and effectively smart. The humor is always apparent and you even love the racist dark elves. To me it is the game to come back to when i dont know what to play and i always lose myself in it all over again. Ive finished it so many times and even though the combat feels dated, the modding community keeps it alive. No wonder they are still modding to a scale where they want to recreate it in the Skyrim engine, a multiplayer is still in the making and all of that for a game that is well over 10 years old. To me it is the perfected RPG before they became too easy. Thank god for not fast traveling, no regenerating health and for the love of god there is spellmaking to even deepen the endless possibilities. To me it is my nr.1 game of all time. Nuff Said, just buy, download, mod and enjoy for even a modded version doesnt look so dated. 10/10 A Masterpiece amongst masterpieces

												Morrowind is a great game. It has great graphics for 2002, great exploration, and great replay ability. Many hate the combat, but I like it more then skyrim's combat where you hit every time.A little advice: when being chased by a cliff racer do zig zags while sprinting diagnolly and he won't hit you as much.Update: I will also note that I don't just like this game because of nostalgia. In fact I never even played until December 25th 2016. You don't need nostalgia to love a classic like this. Anything you don't like about this game can be corrected with mods or console commands. Finally, if you are unsure if you want to buy this game or not, check out oblivion and skyrim, if you dont want those, or if you're sure on this buy Morrowind. I do advise at least looking at Skyrim and Oblivion, they are also great games. It's on sale now as of March 31st! Get it!!!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												I will be honest and say that when i first booted this game up half a year ago or so, i didnt like it. But then  i decided that 30min-1 hr without really trying to learn how the stats system works wasnt enough. So i gave it another go with a clear mind and as of now i am totally hooked.the first thing people will ask how does it compare to skyrim and i say its better.  I have 450 + hrs on skyrim on ps3. And despite me playing this for less i still think this game is better and no this isnt a comparion between this and skyrim.The good:Story: I will begin with the story and is one of the best stories in an open-world game. One of the best main stories i have seen in a open world  game second only to witcher 3 , but this game has a far better lore. The story touches upon drugs, gods, religion, racism , good and evil is always not as clear as it seems. As someone pointed out who is good guys here are you the good guy or are you helping some evil killing off the good , well that up  to you to decide , but in this game it isnt clear who the villain really is. Quests:  In this game compared to many games i have played i really feel like doing all the side quests, i feel i help the world in someway, makes it a better place. There are alot of different side quests, from assasination, fetching, clearing a tomb, steal something , persuade etc. The main quest is great and the side quests doesnt feel forced and you will probably on numerous times find out that you rather do the side quests then the main quests. Or like what happens to me alot i do a main quest then suddently i get to a new area were i get tons of new side quests, or some of the side quests i have that can be completed in the area or close to it. Some of the best quests i have seen in a long time. As i said previously only Witcher 3 comes close or surpass it.Atmosphere: The atmosphere is fantastic. Every city feels unique, almost every place feels unique. The landscape/ world is huge and you really feel like you are there , also because of the music. When it comes to the places you visit you got the huge place called Vivec , small towns like Balamora and Peligrad, different forts, a huge mushroom that alot of shops and homes is in. You can walk from a huge town then you suddently finda a field with steam or  you have come to a volcano. And the weather system needs to be mentioned too. It can go from bright daylight - to ash storms - to rainy nights. Music: The soundtrack is fantastic and really helps creating this fantastic world.Gameplay: Well lets starts with when you hit someone it use a dice based system and a variety of factors and it works. It will probably get smashed by today standards if developers did this in todays games, but if you get around the idea you will find a gameplay that is pretty great and still works al right today. The skill system is great, with major, minor and misc skills. Major and Minor skills levels up your overall level so you can have more strenght, luck , agilit etc Misc skills is just some skills that still will help you dont focus on them too much. Your skills depnds on the class.I will also like to add that the use journal and talk to the people to find the directions to a town or do a quest without any hand holding is great.You can enchant whatever you want with say  levitate, that makes you levitate as long as you want. You can make for some stupid reason that when you hit and enemy he will turn inviniclbe. You can enchant so you have more strength etc.The fast traveling in this game is pretty great, instead of what alot of todays game do that you simply click on a location you have visit previously and teleporting there for a magical reason you will in this game have to either use a mage guild, slit strider, use scrolls, boat or a  mark and spot with a spell then teleport you to that spot again later.So yeah its old school but adds to the exploration.Cons: As of my update as i have played tribunal and after reaching around 65+ hrs, i have encountered a lot more time falling trough the floor, inside buildings and so on, at the worst time i am stuck and have to teleport out. And yes you get some atletic or acrobatic xp but is still really tire some.I have also encountred a few crashes. Score is redone.So for me i rate this a 9.8/10Skyrim if you wonder 9.4/10One of the best open world game i have played.  Only witcher 3 , and fallout 2 comes close or even supass it.N.B: When i wrote my fallout 2 review or the one for deus ex i had hard time imagining that i would fine a new game that  i would enjoy this much on pc and this one did ( not going to be surprised if days of the tentacle, total war rome will be up there too,maybe the old gta`s too). Despite whatever flaws people find in this game i will still say is a masterpiece of a game.Review might be updated or rewritten when i am done with tribunal and bloodmoon. I have rewritten cons and the last paragraph of the gameplay.

I highly recommend this piece but am unable to give an unbiased number rating, so I won't. Just know if you're willing to be patient with a game, and love the fantasy genre, prepare for many hours of immersive adventure.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2012
												I was introduced to this game at an early age, I might have been 11 or 12 years old.  I remember how my mind kind of melted of the very idea of a open world, where you could walk around and do whatever you pleased. Most gamers can relate to those specific games that did not only changed our perspective toward games but maybe even played a part in forming your very personality. I have been a big fan of The Elder Scrolls since then, and Morrowind stays the favorite because of the nostalgia. The game itself is probably not Better than Oblivion or Skyrim, but for me that does not matter.The Elder Scrolls have really climbed since Arena, which was not a particularly good game compared to other old-school RPGs from the same age. Daggerfall was certainly an interesting game, with that HUGE world, but sadly randomly generated. Morrowind took a huge step from Daggerfall, going from 2D to 3D and I believe this is where the series really started its "golden age". When Oblivion was about to get released I purchased my first computer and built it just for that game thanks to the impact Morrowind had on me.As to be expected, Morrowind is a western fantasy RPG, and today The Elder Scrolls are the biggest western fantasy RPG series. The very idea of the genre is that you choose your own path, build your own character and create your own adventure. Often build around the Health, Mana and Stamina system, where you have these 3... "elements" to preform your attacks and movements. Depending on the class you choose and build, you focus on a specific one of these "elements" for your favor. A mage for example should prioritize to build up mana for his/hers spellcasting while the warrior focuses health for close combat. Morrowind is a very open RPG, very much old-school, where you literally can focus on anything and still make it through the game, something that has been restricted in modern RPGs, where its expected of you to choose less "crazy" builds.Morrowind is set on the island Vvardenfell in the province of Morrowind in the world known as Tamriel. A very harsh land with the Red Mountain, a volcano, in the middle shaping a very alien and hostile world. Each time I return to this game I feel unfamiliar every time, it is clear that the developers had this in mind for the world to appear strange and unique. It appears Bethesda are very fond of putting your character in imprisonment at the start of all of their games. I like the idea of rising up from the lowest of the low to become the hero, saviour and an ultimate killing machine. In Morrowind you are to become the Nerevar, the upriser of the Dunmer people and defender of Morrowind.I can not begin to express my love for this game, and I realize that newer players will find the game very clunky and hard in the beginning. The lack of support for higher resolutions and the overall outdated graphics will surely prevent this game to shine at this age. Even so, I feel that this game have so much backstory, and the gameplay will become very rewarding over time. Besides, there are thousands of mods for it these days, such as complete overhauls to make the game very up to standards. If you enjoy RPGs, especially western fantasy and The Elder Scrolls, then you should not hesitate to play Morrowind. You just have to get over it being old.

												This game is fantastic. It's got that old RPG mechanic were you have to build your character up from scratch. This game is a little difficult to get into at first (especially if you played Skyrim or Oblivion like I did.) but if you push yourself to play more and more of this game, you will find it is probrably the best Elder Scrolls Game.

content:
Posted: March 31
												Ahhh, The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind! I want to start by saying that yes I am a fan boy, but I wont let that get in the way of giving the best, most accurate review of this game as I can. Years ago, this game as many remember, was released on the orginal xbox ( was also on PC but I mean come on) which is where the elder scrolls series reallllly took off imo, and back then I could not get enough of this game. So to keep it simple, ill make a semi-detailed list of the pros and cons of Morrowind:Pros:-The best story of all the elderscrolls ( an opinion but if you give it a chance, youll see why ) so far, very in depth and extremely detailed.- THE MUSIC, MY GOD THE MUSIC. They actually used a sample of Morrowinds theme song in Skyrim, anyone who played morrowind before hand will have recognized it, thats how good the music is, tBethesda pretty much recycled it lol. You can get lost in the pleasent music and ambient backround sounds, and the combat music gets you on your oes in a split second. Playing Morrowind really makes me feel like im in a foreign land, an alien world. No other elder scroll game can capture that essence like Morrowind DID. This  set the bar reaaaaallly high, and honeslty I have yet to play another game where I was so enveloped in its atmosphere, it's captivating, magical and wonderful. - Character Customization/Class creation:  Same Races as the other Elder scroll games, not too in depth as far as how many types of face/hair etc you can choose. however the game has an awesome way of helping players to choose what role may fit them best which is unique ONLY TO MORROWIND. You can customize your class completely from the ground up, choose from a list of pre-set classes, or answer a series of questions and depending on how you answer these questions, the game will suggest a class for you. ( which you do not have to take if you dont want )- The NPC's : Morrowinds NPCs are very interactive, there are 3 different forms of persuasion you can use to try and get information from NPCs, not only that but there are many other ways to get information needed. Simply being a good person in game will help you, unless you decide to go on an extreme killing spree without going to jail, people will be afraid of you, word of who you are will travel across the land, and in some events NPCs will completely refuse to speak to you yet alone help you. - Vvardenfell is the continent Morrowind is held on ( if you get the GOTY, which I would highly suggest if you enjoyed the regular version, can port your character right over ) and during your travels ( you will have access to something that can transport you from town to town for a small cost, its called a SIlt Strider, looks like a giant flea and can be found in most cities) you will find tons of ruins, mines, bandit camps, and much more to explore. Vvardenfell has so many secrets hidden and locked away, and among those secrets is the tresure, the loot, the good stuff. There are tons of quests, and guilds, and side missions to do;  unlike the newer ES games, Morrowind is set in a harsh land where things are much more powerful than you are, and forces you to flee until you get stronger or can formulate a soild plan of attack and escape. There is no random loot, things are where they are which I personally like, it always gave me a particular goal to work towards like killing that guy for his armor, or robbing a certain store and teleporting out before the guards come. - THE MAGIC SYSTEM! Again, unlike any of the other Elderscroll games, Morrowind allows you create and customize your own spells.  ( one CON is that while casting spells, you have a chance to fail completely and use up mana which will make the start of the game very tough) Now there is a limitation to this; you must have the required skill level of magic in order to successfully cast a spell. You can make any spell you'd like, but in reality some you just wouldnt be able to cast if you make them too crazy. Was def one of my favorite things about the game, being able to make my own spells. There are spells in Morrowind that were removed ( jumping spells, levitating spells, MARK AND RECALL...) in Oblivion and never made a return, sadly. Now, the CONS:- RPG like combat. This means early on, when you start your game it will be very tough to kill things. You will swing your weapon and miss over and over until a few blows actually land. The thing with Morrowind is that even RUNNING drops your fatigue, and with lower fatigue your chance to cast spells/ strike your target decreases . So, the less stamina you have, the lower the chance youll have to hit something/ cast a spell. This can make the game frustraiting for some players, pushing them away from the start. As your skills go up , naturally so will how much you are able to hit something or cast a spell, once you get a skill to 100, you will always hit no matter what, but fatigue will still effect how much damage you do per swing etc. If you're really liking the game, just push through this- find the correct trainers for your skill set ( mages guild, fighters guild, theives guild, Morag tong [ assassin guild ]  etc ) and this wont be a problem for very long.  - Vvardenfell- IS IT TOO BIG..? It might be, for those who dont have an adventerous spirit, you might find the world too expansive.  Often times you will have to run on foot ( or use spells...!?!? ) to new destinations, and it is possible you can actually get very lost .  There are a lot of other ways to travel around Vvardenfell, and youll figure that out in time, but still looking for a partclar person or a particular place in such a large world can be extremely difficult and at times, demoralizing. - EVERYONE AND ANYONE CAN BE KILLEDIt would do you well to remember this, because in the newer elder scroll games they disable the ability to kill characters who are important to the main story. Well, in morrowind you may kill whoever youd like, whenever if youre powerful enough. You will not knock them out, they will be killed. The NPC will die and you will be able to loot them. HOWEVER..if and when you kill a NPC that is important to the main story, a large box will appear in your bottom left hand corner warning you of what you've just done, and how in doing so the main story line has been severed and you can never finish it. At which point you may reload your game, or you can carry on and keep playing because the rest of the world is still in action with plenty to do, but I wouldnt suggest it. -THIS GAME IS TOUGH. Morrowind can be very unforgiving. Save often or else youll find yourself losing hours of progress, which is extremely disheartening. -ALL IN ALL- The Elderscrolls 3 : Morrowind is wonderful game that has a tough learning curve, its not nearly as easy to play as  ES4: Oblivion or ES5: Skyrim and so if you dont want a challenge, a real one, don't pick it up. However if youre a big fan of the Elderscroll series, and you like games where you can see real progress overtime,  pick this gem up, you wont regret it. This is one of those things in life where you wish you could forget about it ever existing, just so you could go back and discover it all over again for the first time.

												Just finished this time on my first playthrough, haven't even started either of the two DLC. This game is fantastic, and I would recommend for any RPG fan.Pros:Good character creation systemFantastic main story, better than Skyrim'sOver a dozen factions, each with conflicting interests and interesting conflictsRacist DunmerNaked NordsEncourages running around and exploring, even forces you to explore world before starting the main storyComplicated political world, with three Great Houses vying for control of VvandenfellCons:Bad 2003 graphicsMany, many glitches. Console commands are useful for fixing said glitchesClunky combat. Worse than SkyrimOverall, one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. It doesn't hold your hand and help you with things like quest markers and fast travel, you have to actually think for yourself. The end battle was thrilling, much more interesting than the stupid battle against Alduin in Sovngarde.

												The last in the Elder Scrolls series which requires thought to play.You must actually read to understand what is going on and how to get to places.Signs are your go-to for directions, NPCs will tell you general locations of thing relative to land marks, and there are no magical floating arrows anywhere.Main storyline is okay, though the side quests and fluff content is excellent.Game is designed with random hits/misses as its core, so the start can be tedious of flailing without results but does get better as you level your skills with the weapons.There was a competition to make a build that wasn't viable to beat the game with.It provided not a single build that couldn't work.Seriously if you can find a selection choice that makes you unable to beat the game, then post it somewhere and be praised for your insight.Graphical quality is definitely a factor for one's enjoyment if they're into that sort of thing.Its models are super low polygon counts, and the animations are very jerky.The weather effects actually aren't bad.Snow resembles snow and feels like snow when moving through it.The Sun has an accurate light blinding effect, and looks really bright compared to everything else.Rain is the worst of the effects but it gets the job done.  I feel it is a bit too line-stretchy rather than point-drops in appearance.You are able to become super powered at the end-game to the point of being a God without the requirements of using third party tools/cheats/mods.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I could truly go into detail about this game, but for now, I'll mostly just say it's a flawed gem or even a masterpiece depending on your opinion. The game has some very archaic features such as dice rolls determining your ability to hit enemies which means you can miss even if you have a high skill with the weapon, but it's not as bad as some people make it out to be and you just have to learn to cope with it. However, this is a considerably unforgiving game overall. You have to be careful not to go off the beaten path too much as enemies don't scale in level the way they do in this game's successors. There are also diseases which can give nasty effects to your character such as debuffs potentially lasting until the disease is cured though it can easily be done with potions that you should always have on you.You also need to be sure you make good choices when it comes to creating your character so you can maximize your chances of survival and killing potential. It's probably best to select a predesigned class or even look online to get an idea of building your character effectively. This does NOT mean you have to follow them exactly and use cookie-cutter builds to succeed. They're just general rules of thumb which you can better understand with. This way you won't go around missing every swing and dying instantly to enemies. Quests take more attention than they do in successors because there's no compass pointing you to your objectives meaning you must read your journal to see the directions there which aren't always 100% accurate. While this can be confusing and you may just not enjoy it, it serves to better immerse you into the experience and encourage you to explore the surrounding areas of the quests.The last possibly negative things I'd like to mention are the various exploits and bugs. You should definitely install the fan made patches, that you can find online for free which should fix the majority of the bugs that would otherwise make it a terribly glitchy experience. As far as exploits, these can be avoided if you choose to and play the game normally, but from what I've heard, alchemy can really unbalance the game with things like flying above enemies and shooting them and buffing up to near invisibility. However, you might find this to be a fun aspect of the game. There are many other things to learn that I didn't cover like this such as disposition and fatigue so I'd encourage anyone to look up some information to guide you a bit where a manual might have if you had a physical copy. This won't take anything from the experience (depending on where you look), unless you're the type who likes to go into a game and figure everything out the hard way, and it will probably prevent a lot of frustration for a beginner. To talk about the good, I'm sure you could easily look online to find a cult following gushing about this game, but from my own experience, the reason I enjoy this the most in the series is it's complexity, depth, and thematically alien feeling. You can look up what makes this game comparatively deeper and complex than the others with things like each individual weapon type being a skill and how the many factions interact with you and each other, but I just want to mention the world. Morrowind is a very strange place compared to the other games and real life in general. The environment includes ashlands which are essentially barren shadows of past volcanic eruptions that have caused dry, dusty terrain with calderas mostly providing the only form of pass through the many impassable (without flying) mountains. There's also the 'West Gash Region' which is hard to describe, but definitely unusual. There are other places more familiar like the 'Bitter Coast' being swampland, more that I can't name that are grasslands, beach, shallow waterered areas with stones and land sticking up from it with giant thorn trees where flying wizards reside, a lake area with different plantation grounds where slaves work. Most of the biomes contain giant mushrooms which act as trees. There's even an island in the Northwest, provided in one of the expansions that come with this version where there are traditional forests, ice areas and snowy places. So Morrowind cetainly has the most various environments of the last three Elder Scrolls.The native npcs themselves where insect armor, ride giant insects to other areas, use large reptiles to serve as mules, have a strange religion featuring many of their own gods not seen in the other games, have cities on water and shun any 'outlanders'. There are also ash dwellers who live in tribes that celebrate the banned god Nerevar who acts as a central plot - point to the story. The story is compelling enough, but it's the presentation that makes it great. You don't know a lot of what's going on when you first get to Morrowind and you only find out through books, npcs who are reluctant to inform you, and other npcs who help further the plot along. It's a very mysterious game. Simply put, this game demands a lot from you, but it's extremely satisfying when you succeed and win the main quest, not to mention all the side quests and definitely rewards you for being invested in the story and lore which are truly deserving of the word 'fantasy'.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Have you played skyrim before this? Did you enjoy the hell out of it? This game may be too old school for you, purchase at your own risk. Did you play this before you played oblivion or Skyrim? What are you reading reviews for!? You should either have the game already or be buying it right now!To summarize what I love about this game- The setting- Navigation- Interesting quests and events- Ability to become insanely OP- Enemies that don't scale to your levelThe island of Vvardenfell remains my favourite landscape. Sure the graphics are dated. But, I still recall my astonishment as I exited the boat for the first time. The alien creatures, silt striders, Kwama, nix hounds and those damned cliff racers. The giant mushrooms, sandstorms and blizzards set the environment apart from other sandbox settings. Subtle animations such as your character shielding their face from the sand being tossed about in the storm bring the world to life.Questing in this game is quite different from modern rpg and sandbox games. No quest markers exist, at all. Your source of directions are the locals and those you provide you with the quests. Luckily your journal will log all conversations related to quests and topics. Need to remember how to get to Balmora? Open your journal and search under B, any important conversations about the place will be recalled for you to reread.I don't want to spoil the magic of this event just in case someone reads this, decides to purchase the game and is yet to experience it. But it is just north of Seyda Neen, along the path through the swamp. As another example, further of the track near Seyda Neen, the body of an Imperial tax collector can be found. Still with all his money. What do you do? that is your choice. Tell the guards? Keep the money for yourself? Track down the murderer? No quest markers means that the quest ends when you want it to (to a degree). Of course the true ending of this quest is to track down the murderer, but there is nothing to stop you from just looting the corpse and forgetting about the whole incident.I'll sum this point up quickly. Scrolls of Icarian Flight Fortify your acrobatics by 1,000 points, making your jump send you flying into the clouds. Without a levitate or slowfall spell the landing will kill you. These are a joke item. But you get the picture.Finally, the leveling in this game. This is not like modern elder scrolls games. In both Oblivion and Skyrim enemies would scale to your level. However, in Morrowind this does not occur. Early days exploring are best spent cautiously, some enemies will one hit you, should you get too comfortable exploring a Dwemer ruin.I should also mention combat. This could be a turn off for some. The best way to explain it is that everything is determined by die rolls. Trying to hack at a creature with your sword? What is your skill with a blade? Do you have enough stamina for the swing? What is the targets dexterity? This is all taken into account as you try to hit a target. So some of your attacks will appear to pass through the enemy, missing for no reason. So do I recommend this game? Yes, Absolutely. This game is a must buy (in my opinion) for any fan of rpgs. I'd like to think that anyone who's a fan of the elder scrolls series has played this game. I fear many may call it dated, and give the game a miss. There is much to appreciate in this game. If the animation and graphics are an issue for you there is an overhaul mod pack which adds much to the game, even at the cost to some of the original feel. But you can tweak it to be more faithful to the vanilla game.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This is it: the greatest Elder Scrolls game ever.Ok, it doesn't look to great by today's standards (but there are TONS of mods to improve the graphics), and the combat system is pretty clumsy (although I love it) but the gameplay, the exploring, the freedom, and all the things you can do make this a game you'll gladly sink hundreds or thousands of hours into.  There's a lot more depth to this game than any of the Elder Scrolls games that have come since.I've probably spent a thousand hours playing Morrowind, and I still feel like I haven't seen it all (I haven't even spent much time on the two expansions).  In 2002 when Morrowind first came out on PC and Xbox, it was my life.  I loved the game so much I bought it for both systems.  My friends saw me playing it and several of them became addicts as well.  I was never turned off by the slow start or the difficulty in using your low level skills.  In fact, that was part of the fun for me - watching my character grow from someone who could hardly do ANYTHING in this world to a god-like juggernaut that could do ANYTHING in this world.  It's so satisfying, and much more satisfying than the character growth in any other game I've ever played, Elder Scrolls or not.The spell creation system, which is sadly missing from newer Elder Scroll games, is so fun to play around with.  If you have the skill and money you can mix ANY of the spells together for some fun effects.  And there are a LOT more spells in this game.  Some are a little pointless (I've never figured out the point of the "Sound" spell) but some are tons of fun.  Levitate is a blast.  See something up high you can't get to?  Just Levitate up to it!  And the Jump/Slow Fall combo of spells is great.  You can do an uber-powerful jump, quickly flying through the sky for miles (or more/less, depending on how powerful your spells are) and then slowly, gently fall back to earth.  There are more weapons/stats including medium armor, spears and crossbows (great fun).  There are more factions.  The standard Fighter/Mage/Thieves guilds are there, but there are also TWO Dark Brotherhood type guilds, the Imperial Legion, the Blades, two religious guilds, vampire guilds, and three "House" guilds (although if memory serves me, you can only join one house).  And there is a LOOOOONG main quest.  So when I saw there's hundreds of hours of gameplay here, I don't mean hundreds of hours of aimlessly wandering the world.  It's real, substantial gameplay.But the world of Morrowind is a world you'll WANT to spend hundreds of hours wandering.  It's exotic and different, espcially when compared to other Elder Scrolls games.  Giant mushroom trees may dot the landscape, some cities are built using the shells of huge craps, you're transported around the world in big bugs, wizards live in enormous plants, violent ashstorms darken the sky, animals or people disfigured by sickness attack you.  And around every corner you'll find something, such as large, bizarre looking Daedric temples; sunken ships or underwater caverns in the sea; or a lone farm in the wilderness.If you've enjoyed Skyrim or Oblivion, you HAVE to play this game.  If you hear people complain about the graphics or clunky combat, ignore them and just play this game.  If you haven't played Skyrim or Oblivion, you HAVE to play this game.  It may take a little while to get past the old look and feel of this game, but you WILL get past it and you'll find that the more time you invest in Morrowind, the more satisfying and rewarding it becomes.  You'll feel a sense of accomplishment when every single one of your sword blows hit your opponent and when you sucessfully cast your spells every time.  Don't give up out of frustration because the questing system doesn't show you EXACTLY where to go, or because you can't fast travel EVERYWHERE.  That's a purposeful design choice to encourage exploration, and it promotes the feeling of a huge, open world.  In short, you HAVE to play this game.  It's the most rewarding game I've ever played, and it probably will be for you too if you allow yourself to become immersed in it.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												As a later TES fan, you may find it hard to believe that someone who actually started with Skyrim has found Morrowind to be their favorite installment in the series. But the thing is, Morrowind has a particular charm to it, despite it being over eleven years old. There are several things I'd like to discuss about Morrowind and why you should ultimately buy it, whether you're new to the TES series, or are a die-hard fan screaming for nostalgia.I'd like to create some points with Morrowind discussing its values:1. Presentation2. Gameplay3. OverallReady? Let's begin.Point One: Presentation.At first glance, Morrowind shows its age with the early Embryo engine with skeletal animation, and an average of 800 x 600 display. Also noticable is how NPC's stay within a general area without eating, drinking, or sleeping (sounds like a serious insomnia epidemic, no?). But besides that, there's nothing really flawed about the graphics, and it's actually reminiscent of Oblivion's. This gives Morrowind a sense of familiarity to begin with. You start off the game with a cinematic intro, as you awaken on an Imperial prison ship that has docked on an Imperial colony, Seyda Neen. From there, you enter your name, choose your race, and once you enter the Commision Office, you are asked to choose your birthsign, favored attributes, and class. From there on, you are asked to deliver a message to a man named Caius, and thus your quest begins. Or at least, the main quest begins. Like other TES games, what you do there on out is up to you. Fight monsters and bandits, loot tombs and ruins, join guilds and political factions, basically what you'd expect from an open-world RPG. That said, the island of Vvardenfell is wonderful, given you can see it, with the render distance and all. Cities aren't closed in separate maps like they were in Oblivion and Skyrim, and the geography is very immersive as you walk around, looking for your objective or simply looking for a dungeon to pillage. As you walk around Vvardenfell, you will encounter strange creatures, such as the Nix-Hound, the Alit, the Netches, and the infamous Cliff Racer. Imagination was really put into these monsters, and some of them won't be so easy to kill. As for the islands residents, Vvardenfell is home to the Dunmer, the ash-skined elves you've seen in the later or earlier installments. Their culture is reminiscent to that of Asian and some tribal cultures, as they may live in the shells of ancient arthropods, adobe buildings, giant mushrooms, and nomadic tents. You will also find your typical Imperial stone structures, things you may yawn about. The in-game literature in Morrowind is very well-written, providing fictional stories to amuse you with, informative tips about the local governments, cities, and religion, and even books that hint on certain gameplay aspects such as vampirism. It truly is something to see the thought lingers in your head.  Point Two: GameplayAs for perhaps the most important aspect of any game, the gameplay element in Morrowind is quite different from the later installments ( and definitly Arena, but we aren't comparing.) The game offers a wide variety of skills to use, with various weapon types, from typical swords and warhammers, to spears and throwing stars, to crossbows and staves. There are also a wide variety of spells to use, from your average destruction and restoration spells, to teleportation, and even flying spells. Filed Soul Gems can be used on epuipment to enchant them, and an alchemy set can be used with flora, fauna, and even raw minerals to brew potions and poisons. Dialouge with NPCs is somewhat different, though, as they will communicate with text-based responses to the selected topic, and there are many things to talk about with NPCs. The thing about dialouge is despite these many topics, what they say is usually the same as everybody else. Copy-pasted, in fact, thus rendering many NPC void of real personality, unlike Oblivion and Skyrim. As for conflict with enemies, you may either hate it or simply don't care, as it works more like D&D role-playing games. Based on your skil with a certain weapon type, or the Agility attribute itself, you may miss an enemy point-blank while they take crackshots at you (though still able to miss.). Magic works similarly, as using less skilled magic type while tired out will usually result in failure to cast the spell. Aside from those questionable gameplay elements, however, there's still plenty to be had with Morrowind. You can't simply fast travel from the map so you could skip treking all the way to a destination, but rather you use public transportation, teleportation spells, and spells to increase your speed to move around Vvardenfell. Personally, this gave Morrowind a really huge look at the world map, even though it's only 10 square miles + 2-3 from the Bloodmoon expansion and about an additional one from Tribunal, compared to Cyrodill and Skyrim (16 square miles each) or even The Iilic Bay from Daggerfall, with a whopping 480,000 sqare miles (randomly generated though). Plus, you really got to know the geogrophy of Vvardenfell, as the game references landmarks and cities to help you navigate the world, all written in your little journal. Speaking of which, the journal system is probably the closest thing you'll have for a friend in this game ( besides Ahnassi, of course ). Quests and Topics are recorded on your journal with every indication. Viewing your journal is always very helpful if you've been sidetracked from looting dungeons or completing other side quests. That's not to say it isn't flawed, of course. Some quests give really bad direction and can be sometimes misleading. If you don't believe me, join House Redoran. This was really compensated in later installments with a quest marker, as a mere convinence. But don't let the gameplay issues deter you from purchasing this amazing title. Overall, the game function very well and even a late audience can find enjoyment out of it.Point Three: OverallMany thing can be said about Morrowind to criticize it. The fact that NPCs had nearly no personality at all, a cumbersome combat and magic system, and even some broken quests do hurt Morrowind a little bit. But despite these cons, Morrowind is uplifted with many pros. Its lore will fascinate you, the landscape will amaze you, and your impact on the game world will really matter here. You truly can be what you want, whether that be a noble knight, a malevolent mage, an infamous assassin, or a troublesome thief, Morrowind can provide.This game has been Dubb-approved

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
One of the best PC RPG's ever!Introduction - I would have to start this by saying that first off this game is absolutely massive. There is simply put no other way to describe it in one word. The original Morrowind was my favorite Action Role Playing Game of all time so this upgrade ranks even higher on my list. The Morrowind legacy Grows.Gameplay - This is where The original Morrwind really shines, and Game of the Year edition improves on an already great formula. When you first begin the game you get to start by choosing one of ten races which include everything from the traditional humans, orcs and elves, to the more fantasy like races of the cat like Kajiit people, and the lizard like Argonians. From there you proceed to totally customize everything about your character, including looks, class birth sign, and much more. Each different class and attribute, has a large effect on the game, so playing as an elf mage is completely different than playing as an elf thief, or assassin. The birth signs also come with their own special powers, and weakness's as well so each one is worth trying at least once.When you're finally into the game things start off a bit slow. You run a couple of errands, collect a few stray items as the game walks you through the first little bit, but you soon realize that there is a freedom here that no other game has managed to get just right. Want that piece of armor you see lying there on someone's shelf? Grab it. Want that cool looking sword you see a guard carrying kill him and take it, but be prepared for consequences.Bethesda went to such great detail on this aspect, that almost every item in the game can be interacted with with great freedom. You can spend hours at a time simply decorating a house you've made your home base, and all items aren't simply decoration. Books are fully readable, herbs can be mixed into potions, crates, bags, and shelves can all be used for storage. Beds can be slept in, candles and lanterns can be placed in your home to light it, or carried along to light dark areas.As far as character development, it's extraordinary, and a bit overwhelming at the same time. Every single action you take has the possibility of increasing one or more skills. Even something so simple as walking or swimming will lead to a faster stronger character in the end. There are nearly limitless combinations in ways to grow your character, so long as you remember every thing you do affects you in some way.Fighting at first is a bit difficult until you increase in some skills a bit, but with practice you will soon be swinging axes, and casting spells with the best.There is also an option for a third person view if the first person is not your thing, but keep in mind that fighting is a bit more difficult like this because aiming becomes harder.Story- The story in Morrowind was great, in the game of the Year it simply gets better with two completely new areas to explore, the addition of the Werewolf, and lots more surprises that I won't speak of here. Needless to say it the Story in Game of the Year is greatly improved.Graphics/Sound - My only real complaint about the first Morrowind was the choppiness in the frame rate, and the awkward way in which it made characters move. Thankfully this has been greatly improved. Characters, and NPCs have a much more fluid look, and less robot-like appearance now. Another improvement is that there is much less fog now. Before it was used to cover pop-in, but now for the most part it is used to convey mood rather than cover up for the programmers.The sound and music are both fantastic. Each race has unique grunts groans, and dialect, they also speak with accents that seem proper for their race. The music has always been a favorite of mine in morrowind, and Game of the Year is no exception. It has that special way of making you feel as though you are really part of something special.Play Time/Replayability -This is really a harder one to judge. The play time simply put is as long as you want it to be. As far as a straight walkthrough you could spend anywhere from fifty hours to one hundred plus hours, depending on how many side quest you choose to do, and the rate at which you choose to develop your character.Replayability is without a doubt one of Game of the Years best features. As stated earlier each of the Races are completely unique, with there own strengths and weaknesses, add to that all the different classes, the birth signs, literally thousands of different combinations of ways to get through the game, and you have a mighty big game. That's not even mentioning the completely new quest that were added in the expansion.Final Recommendation -In conclusion I full-heartedly recommend anyone that has a PC, and even the slightest love of Role Playing Games pick Up this game. It will keep you immersed in it's world for no doubt hours at the time, and at only thirty bucks, you get a lot of added content over the original. I say that Morrowinds world is completely magic, and that's what games are supposed to be.

Posted: June 11, 2015
												I've never reviewed anything before, but I just wanted to write this to make sure that anybody thinking about purchasing this, does just that. I've played for a little over thirty hours so far and I've only done one quest in the main story in addition to barely exploring half of Vvardenfell. I love Oblivion and Skyrim and I thought I might as well try Morrowind. I'm very glad I did. Sure when you first get in the game you have to get past the original culture shock of early 2000's graphics and diceroll combat, but as you progress through the game the graphics actually grow on you to the point of them becoming charming. And as you level up skills in the combat tree, the dicerolls become less annoying and begin to hit nearly every time. Essentially, buy this game. Especially if it's on sale for $10 or less. Then, just give it a couple hours for you to settle in and I guarantee you won't regret it. Have fun and I hope you can enjoy this game as much as I have so far!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pinnacle of the Elder Scrolls series, "Morrowind" is far superior to "Oblivion" & even "Skyrim" due to the magic system, environment, & music.  It is one of the greatest games of all time... now, after perhaps the buggiest release of all time.  Much of the fun was in breaking the game, despite the issues.  The atmosphere was msimply too brilliant for one to be bothered.  Jeremy Soule's soundtrack is perhaps one of the greatest game musical compositions, if not one of all media's greatest scores, enrapturing one in the turmoil & beauty of the lands.  Listening to the music inspires one to adventure, making even the most mudane of tasks seem exciting.  Magic, similar to how the materia system of "Final Fantasy VII" is far better than 8, 9, or 10, thus the combination of all systems by "Final Fantasy XI"; a pattern we are hoping to find in "Elder Scrolls Online" but as of yet have not.  If you prefer "Skyrim" it is because you prefer movies to games, and the illusion of power, as opposed to actual hard earned skill.  "Skyrim" holds the player's hand, "Oblivion" less so, but just as much guilt.  "Morrowind" is open-ended, free, & a true adventure that more oft than not is out to kill you.  What makes that great is all of the ways one could circumvent death, notably levitation & the godly acrobatics skill, letting the player eventually create their own god.  The progression from nothing prisoner to god-killer feels right, usually around 40-100 hours depending on play style.  You will get there if you try, no matter the path, & that's amazing.Few games allow for such versatile gameplay style.You must survive.  The Mods make this game epic, in the true sense of the word, with 1000s of miles and hours of player made content.  The plot of the regular world is incredible nonetheless, & the portrayal of power versus illusion is phenomenal.  The religious overtones are masks for the subversive nature of philisophical gnosticism...  This game will change you.   The lore is as real as "FFXI" yet more accessible, if more ethnocentric, most Pagans should find it refreshing to hear a proper rehashing of some of the more negative remnants of christian slander against witches & sorcerers.  Werewolves & Vampires make this game relavant to the popculture as "Morrowind's" lore is much more dependable than a lot of the garbage being floated around out there as vamp, or lycan, or fronts for far worse.  Be safe, kids.  A lot of this is real, a lot is fantasy, just remember this;  It doesn't matter if someone calls themself a Vampire, Werewolf, or any sort of dangerous humanoid if if they are a crazy psychopath whom believes enough that it simply doesn't matter what you think.  Worse still, they could be a crazy psychopathic monster... and what then?  Don't take chances.  Don't do Skooma, stay in school, & actually read all the lore in RPGs. Now go, Vagabond!  Mod those graphics & remember you are discovering a story with hidden ancient lore and arcane secrets woven within.  This is not merely a game, it is a tome of riddles with the promise of truth & magic trapped for the ignorant, enchanted for the wise.  Therein lay a treasure for the Hero to unbind & wield:  The Philosopher's Stone, coicidencia oppositorum."Morrowind" is the great American ARPG:  9.7/10- Found pipe, made Skooma, smoked... *Would Smoke again!* ...& again.   AN AGAIN!!  AGAIN MORE !@$#%!
