content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Throughout the years, I've put maybe 4500 hours into this game, more than any other game, over the course of three lost and rebought discs, as well as the Steam edition once I stopped putting optical drives into my computers. I still have the Cliffracer screech as my alarm in the morning. Doesn't fail to wake me up.To me, this is the highlight of the Elder Scrolls franchise. I realize a lot of it is nostalgia - when this came out there was nothing about it that wasn't revolutionary in scope. Oh, I remember the days when my mates would outright whine for days about not being able to run the game well, after they saw what it was supposed to look like on my first proper bleeding-edge gaming PC.Off the back of its combat system, the game got a few moderate reviews, even back in 2002. Which is understandable as this game is something as rare as a PC game that was ported to console rather than the other way around. However, as a pen & paper role playing gamer I always enjoyed the combat and never understood the problem people had with it. I was simply predisposed to suspend my disbelief before I even began.Even today, with the graphical mods to Morrowind that are available, I have still not been able to make Oblivion look better than Morrowind. Modded DirectX 9 Morrowind just flat out looks better and more atmospheric.The soundtrack is up there in my top 5, maybe second behind Age of Conan: Hyborian Adventures, just in front of the Monkey Island franchise. Jeremy Soule's best work, and such a great compliment to exploration and discovery. Apart from aforementioned Age of Conan soundtrack, I have never been more motivated to explore just because of a soundtrack. And when you hear that Cliffracer screech and the descent of timpanis, you know♥♥♥♥♥♥is going down.Thank god we had spears back then. Nothing like a 1.5 reach modifier against Cliffracers.A modder's perspective:The game is infinitely moddable - more so than the newer TES titles. It is just more accessible and powerful. There's no need to add empty voice .mp3 to a mod just so the dialogue won't skip along on its merry way. There is no convoluted AI pathing and waypoint micromanagement just to script an NPC to move somewhere. And the scripting language in Morrowind is just downright simpler and more intuitive than most notably Skyrim.For these reasons, Morrowind still to this day has 5-10 new mods being posted every day, and a live community. Additionally, because of how easy it is to turn idea to practice, the amount and quality of quest mods is tenfold that of especially Skyrim. If you want ACTUAL CONTENT from mods, and not just blinging out your character or anime mods, Morrowind is hands down the game you should get.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												TES III: Morrowind is not a RPG, it is an experience and a milestone.The moment when you step outside the ship and the soundtracks kicks in, doesn't only mark the beginning of your adventure, but the beginning of a genre that defined the future of RPGs.Every NPC encountered, every quest or enemy, they all hold a special place in our memories and this is what makes Morrowind such a great game.For many gamers this is the first played TES episode, and probably this is the reason that made us purchase the Steam version once again: the first TES is like your first love, it is unforgettable and incomparable.I remember receiving it as a Christmas present in the early 2002, along with my Xbox; I remember the Christmas holidays spent trying to figure out how to properly play it as I felt amazed by the open world in front of my eyes. And now that Chirstmas is nearing (27 Novemeber 2015 as I am writing this review), I can feel the very same excitement, the sensation of awe when I arrived once again in Balmora, the thrill of having taken down an enemy after countless missed hits, and yes, even the terrible sensation of annoyance everytime a Cliff Racer approaches me.Honestly, despide all the wonderful mods user created, I refuse to enhance this experience, as I wouldn't feel it original and genuine. My advice is to play Morrowind as it is, and afterwards, perhaps, try out all the user created content.Do not wait any longer, grab it already, you n'wah!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I first played this game in 2004. When I saw it I was blown away that I could be who I wanna be and go where I wanna go. And that was exactly what I got back then when I played it. Im sure I put over 1000 hours into it easily by now.Well i recently picked this game up again. Added the graphical overhaul 3.0 and its definatelly stunning in comparrison to the original so highly recommend getting that. 100%Well I definately love Skyrim to death and I think the combat in Oblivion is good but the rest of the game is Ehhh... okay.. i guess. At best.But the way the world of Morrowind it self is crafted is like no other open world RPG befor or since. Just the level of love they put into every area and every detail is fantastic. The world it self is what grips me in these type of games and this world is everything but "just slapped together". Its very detailed, it has enough dungeons to explore around every corner and I love that when im exploring I can open a chest and potentially I could find anything. Kinda like Diablo. Loot finding is awesome. Great variaty. Not just the same kinda things over and over like in the other Elder Scrolls games.Combat may not be for everyone though and I can understand that. Its alittle dull. But if your willing to get used to it you will definately have a good time.  For me personally even when it comes to playability today this is my favorite Elder Scrolls game. Though I also love Skyrim as well. This is the perfect "in the middle" of the series game, in that i mean, it has the action and feel of the newer ones while keeping it classic RPG like Daggerfall and Arena. Its the perfect middle man.But The reason I recomend it most of all is beacuse of the world of Morrowind it self. To me its the best crafted and most lovingly detailed Open World RPG of all time. Its kinda like they relized the possibilitys of creating and open world and they persued it passionately as hell. It is definately a trail blazer game that was built with a passion.9.7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Morrowind's greatest triumph is that it crafts a distinctly unique fantasy world, from its various cultures and politics to its dwellings, landscapes, and species.  There is a great deal to discover and an epic story to be experienced - one that still stands as one of the best, even all these years later.However, the game is not without its flaws.  In particular, combat and its related skills are a bit unrefined.  For example, you won't be able to hit anything with melee attacks until you raise your melee skill, which is only raised by successfully hitting things.  Luckily, this game was very popular and you can find many mods to get around the aspects of the game that aren't up to modern snuff.If you have the time and see what fantasy can be like when it isn't just piggy-backing off of Tolkien, play this game!

Whatever, man, do what you want!This game also has a dedicated modding community, so it won't take you long to replace the dated 2001 graphics with something more intensive.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												In my opinion: The best Elder Scrolls game available. Its almost the polar opposite of titles like Skyrim. Morrowind encourages exploration and flatout tells you to deviate from the main story to become more experienced and come back when you think you're more prepared to progress. There is no fast travel, only Striders which are basically buses. And there are no quest markers. The game instead gives you directions which you then write down in your journal. Personally I had a much better time trying to figure out how to get places based on hints and directions than just walking mindlessly towards a beacon on my map. This game is flawless, a masterpiece. Granted it does take an hour or so to get past the "terrible" graphics. And you may one to get an HD overhaul mod or two. But with the previous set aside, RPG/Adventure games can't get any better than this.Pros:-Blinding nastolgia-Amazing exploration-Beautiful world design-Stunning character design-Easy to use UI-Great storyCons:-YOU RUN SOOOO DAMN SLOW!!!-Its incredibly hard to do a brute character. (magic is your best bet)

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Morrowind's greatest triumph is that it crafts a distinctly unique fantasy world, from its various cultures and politics to its dwellings, landscapes, and species.  There is a great deal to discover and an epic story to be experienced - one that still stands as one of the best, even all these years later.However, the game is not without its flaws.  In particular, combat and its related skills are a bit unrefined.  For example, you won't be able to hit anything with melee attacks until you raise your melee skill, which is only raised by successfully hitting things.  Luckily, this game was very popular and you can find many mods to get around the aspects of the game that aren't up to modern snuff.If you have the time and see what fantasy can be like when it isn't just piggy-backing off of Tolkien, play this game!

content:
Posted: February 9
												This was the second PC game I ever bought, as well as my entry into Bethesda's Elder Scrolls series. It blew my mind, and it still does. The sheer volume of things to discover and the freedom you're given is just amazing, the customizability of your character is astounding, the music score stupendous, and the sound effects had me standing in the rain, listening for thunder. I've had this in disk and digital, so please, ignore the hours spent. I beseech all Elder scrolls fans just jumping on at Skyrim to play this game, especially if you like playing as a mage. You can customize your spells immensely and literally create spells large enough and strong enough to depopulate entire cities.(Even if you have to cheat to cast them :P)  It feels larger than Skyrim despite being damn near the same size (World wise), and was MUCH more enjoyable than Oblivion in my opinion. I was genuinely sad when going back to Solstheim in Skyrim revealed just how much had been lost in the cataclysm. Tribunal is still the best expansion ever released for an Elder Scrolls game. (Though I wasn't sad to see that Rieklings no longer reflected magic. Those city destroying spells I mentioned earlier? Rieklings can kill you in God Mode by reflecting them at you. It may just be the frost portion, I was never able to ascertain what exactly was being reflected as the casting usually obliterated me in a second.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
THE ELDER SCROLLS III: MORROWINDMorrowind is the indirect sequel to the 1996 game, Daggerfall. Morrowind is widely recognised for having one of the first hand-modelled open worlds in gaming. How does it stack up? Well, spoilers, but it's good.KHAJIIT HAS QUESTS IF YOU HAVE TIMEMorrowind follows the questing style of Arena an Daggerfall, in that there are no questing markers, and no fourth wall-breaking journal entries. You will get directions to your quests, that's it. This adds to the feel of immersion in the game. FInding areas without the help of a quest marker was a satisfying feeling. The directions given by questgivers were almost never tedious, and are descriptive enough to make you feel like you are getting real-life directions to a town or area. In typical Elder Scrolls style, there's a silly amount of quests, and every one of them feels unique enough to keep you interested for a good long time. The DLCs in particular have some engaging and immersive questlines. You never feel like the hero the world needs. In a similar fashion to Dark Souls, you feel like many have come before you, and the world isn't owing you any favours.AROUND EVERY CORNERThis land is very compact. You can go anywhere at any time, uninterupted. However, in a similar fashion to Zelda, there are certain places you can only go off of your own accord once special circumstances are met. The world feels very alive, there is very little empty space in between the towns and cities. This felt like a true RPG, in every sense of the word, and was even better when you knew it wasn't holding your hand in any way. Elder Scrolls is known for its charming characterization. Not every NPC is just a copypaste of the last. They all have unique dialogue, names, questlines and personalities. This is taken to the extreme in Morrowind. Even bandits who you will be doing nothing besides killing have names and different traits, I feel this went on to inspire games like Shadow of Mordor in the future. This world felt real, with real people, both good and bad. This isn't to say that the world is perfect. while all areas are loaded, crossing into different regions triggers a very small loading message along with a very brief pause, this was obviously to stop lag on ye olde machines back in the yesteryears, and isn't needed now, but is hard wired into the game, and can't be removed, sadly. The dungeons suffer from "Elder Scrolls-syndrome" of being a little repetetive, but the before-mentionned characterization makes them feel unique enough. There are so many random events in this game. Becoming too popular? Someone might try to bump you off. Taking a stroll in the woods? Watch out for that wizard falling from the outer atmosphere. This game had so much content for the time.HIT OR MISSMorrowind's combat system is pretty bad. Even for the time. The first three Elder Scrolls games use RNG to determine if you can hit enemies or not. This will lead to you flailing your weapon towards enemies, even right into their face, dealing no damage at lower levels. Thankfully, this can be modded out, but I reccomend playing on a higher difficulty if you do, as it becomes too easy. Skyrim's combat was just clunky. Morrowind's was bad. But you know what? It didn't hinder the massive sense of immersion. This was the Skyrim of 2002. And that's why Elder Scrolls fans revere it so much. Rightfully so, too.RATINGMorrowind is one of the best RPGs of all time, hands down. There has never been a higher sense of immersion in an open world game. It may be somewhat dragged down by the out dated mechanics, but you know the Elder Scrolls modding community always has your back. This is my favourite Elder Scrolls game, and for many good reasons. Not only that, but it's one of my personal favourite games ever. 9.6/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												This game is what Skyrim promises to be. I love all the Bethesda games, even Fallout 4, but there's no denying this is the best Elder Scrolls made IMO. Daggerfall is too archaic for me to want to pick up, and while I recommend the Morrowind Overhaul project, I'm playing through for my first time using only a mod to fix the resolution and loving it. You can craft spells with EIGHT DIFFERENT EFFECTS. Want a spell mixing multiple elements and area of effect damage? You can do it. Want to summon 8 Daedric Beings with the press of a button? You can do it. Want to create a spell that heals as much as it damages, allowind you to indefinitely practice your magic on one enemy? You. Can. Do. It. All the systems in this game are about as deep as that, and alchemy requires FOUR different machines to properly do it. The two biggest barriers to entry are the graphics and combat. Morrowind Overhaul fixes that completely so that's squared away. The combat is purely stat based; I do more damage with a mid range sword than the best most OP axe in the game, because you'll miss your swings with a weapon you have no knowledge of how to use. Also WATCH YOUR FATIGUE. % chance you hit is based on how much fatigue you have, don't be like those dumbasses who mash left mouse and wonder why they miss every swing.Pros- In depth lore and a wide variety of topics to ask NPCs about.The best magic system in any game I've played. Free form quests- I have a sword powered by the soul of a god I slew. Nobody told me to do that, Morrowind merely provides the weapon (Daedric Shortsword) the soul (not gonna spoil which god) and the means (in depth enchanting system) to do it. Wide variety of locales and quests. Good storytelling that isn't always spoonfed to you. To cure vampirism without looking it up online, you need to read a couple of books and figure it out yourself. As far as I know, it's impossible any other way besides discovering it by dumb luck or google.Truly an RPG. Very easy to stick to your characters beliefs, unlike in Skyrim where the story makes you a good guy no matter what you do because you saved the world from Alduin.Cons-Somewhat obtuse mechanics. Once they're learned they're badass, but hard to do so. I recommend looking up how to do alchemy, enchanting, etc. as the game expects you to have an instruction manual.Some bugs. Morrowind Overhaul fixes thousands though.Personal Preference- I think having to read to figure stuff out without the game just telling you is awesome. Some might not.No quest markers. You get directions, and late game are in unexplored areas and have to go off of handwritten maps. Conclusion- 10/10 best RPG I've ever played. Quite a challenge, but if you're up to it, it's the most rewarding game I've ever played.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Just as a side note, I have never played an Elder Scrolls game before Morrowind. I have never played another one since I bought it on December 24, 2014 either.  Anyways, Morrowind is an open world RPG game, and probably the Elder Scrolls game the brought the Elder Scrolls franchise into the public's eye. Many people claim that the reason people still play this game today is because of "nostalgia" and they say that it's outdated. I can seriously say that this is completely false. I can say this with all honesty because this game was made only one year after I was born, as I was born in 2001 and this game was made in 2002. I'll go through a couple of major catagories of this game and give some details on each one in this part of the review. Graphics This section does not deal with the enviroment, but with the actually way things look. While this game was made in 2002, the graphics are actually decent. While yes, they have a low polygon count and are rather structured, it still gets the job done. There is still a lot of artistic talent going on here, the art really shines in my opinion. And honestly, graphics can be completely redone by MGSO. I really am fine with a game having O-K graphics, so I'm going to give this section a7/10 Gameplay If you're not totally new to the gaming world, you've probably heard something about Morrowind's combat and how bad it is. And truely, it is not very interesting. Stealth, magic, melee, ranged. Nope. But this game isn't about combat. It's about exploration, questing, collecting, and talking. Sure, there is some combat, but it really doesn't play as huge of a part as other RPG games I've played. Anyways, the gameplay is fun. Exploration is very well rewarded, and there are lots of places to visit and people to talk to. Also, there is so much to do in this game. I'm 120 hours in and I haven't even come close to finishing the main quest, and I have about 5 characters so far (four of whom havent started the main quest at all). I am going to give this section a 9/10  Story and NPCs I'm lumping all of these together because they have a lot in common. The story to this game I think is actually very interesting. While it sort of follows the classic "an ancient evil has awoken" story, it's done in a very unique way in which you can relate to both "sides" and in this case there are actually very many sides. More on that later. Now onto NPCs. The NPCs are pretty bland, with a few exceptions. They have generic answers and things to talk about, and none of the dialoge is voiced. This can be sort of fixed with mods, but I'd still give NPCs a 6/10and the story a 10/10 because it truely is a fantastic story. Setting The setting may be this game's strongest part. You could also call this part the enviroment. The world of Morrowind is a very alien one. About the only thing that you might recognize is a rat when speaking about Fauna, or some grass and tress if you're talking about Flora. Everything is so different and stranged, and it's rather intimidating stepping out of the first building and being greeted by a giant mushroom (and Fargoth...). Also, the history behind everything is really awesome. Just about every cave you explore has a stroy that you can peice together from things that you find in it, it's quite facinating.If you haven't read much about TES lore, Morrowind is the land of the Dunmer, or dark elves and was also once home of the Chimer and the Dwemer. The setting and history is so very interesting and I really get engrossed in it. I could rave on for a really long while just talking about this, but I'll spare you.  Expansions The expansions to Morrowind are pretty awesome, too. Bloodmoon transports you to Solstheim, an island just north of Morrowind where the Legion has just set up fort and some pioneers are trying to set up a village (which you get to help build, by the way). I'm not going to spoil a lot but lets just say  FIRST PERSON LYCANTHROPY Tribunal takes you to Mournhold, the capital of Morrowind. Now I haven't started this one yet, because it's not supposed to make sense if you haven't done the main quest, but It's supposed to be really awesome. You get to meet Sotha Sil! (sorta) I'm going to give the expansions a 9/10----------Now that I've covered the major points I'll cover a couple of minor ones.MusicFantastic. There is not a lot of it, but the stuff the you do have is amazing and really captures the essence of Morrowind. Plus, the Elder Scrolls theme comes from this game. There are also lots of mods that give the game more music like the things already in the vanilla game. I'll give this section 9/10 (one point off because there isn't as much music as I might have liked. Speaking of mods...Mods!There are so many mods! The community has been pumping them out since 2002, so there are a boatload of mods out there. MGSO, Sotha Sil Expanded, Starfire's NPCs, Tamriel Rebuilt, just so many. The community for this game is truly fantastic (and not pervy like Skyrim's or Oblivion's).10/10PerformanceThis game should perform well on any computer made after 2007. I can't afford a nice PC at this time, and even on my 2011 laptop, I get 25-30 fps at all time with Medium Settings on MGSO. You shouldn't worry about your computer being able to take this game, especially if you have a nice one.9/10 Conclusion All in all, Morrowind is a fantastic game. I recomment it to anyone who likes RPG games. And don't be fooled by the age of the game. Even vanilla Morrowind is so much better than all of the stuff they are pumping out these days. Thanks for reading, and I hope that this inspired you to buy this game. I hope you enjoyed my review!I give this game a  10/10 3000th Review for this game, yay.

content:
Posted: March 25
												TL DR: Morrowind is a masterpiece in world building. Combat is bad, and there are some really broken systems to be found and enemies you'll just mod out after first sight, but it still has an absolutely incredible world to explore.The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a first-person RPG developed by Bethesda. The third main title in the critically acclaimed Elder Scrolls series, it's a departure from both previous and following games in the series, having the smallest world in the series but also the most deep and interesting one.Morrowind starts with a cutscene showing an ancient prophecy, and your character awaking on a boat. You're a prisoner arriving on Vvardenfell, an inner island to the continent of Morrowind, home to the dark elves of Tamriel. You start off by creating your character, choosing your race, appearance, birthsign and preferred attributes and skills. Afterwards, you're left with the mission to go see an Imperial agent at a somewhat nearby city, and that's it. A stranger in a strange land, you can go wherever you want to after this fairly short introduction.Vvardenfell isn't huge in size, but the developers cheated for it to appear so. Your starting speed is very, very slow, and there's no fast travel. However, there are lots of lore-respecting means of travel to be used throughout; cities usually have cheap silt strider services which will take you to nearby cities instantly, for example. The game starts out pretty slow, with you having to do mostly fetch quests for a few factions. Luckily, as bad as fetch quests do sound, Vvardenfell is one of the best videogame locations I've had the pleasure to explore. It's a really alien island, featuring swamps, ashlands, sandstorms, giant mushrooms, some used as buildings, and the huge red mountain volcano at the center, blocked on all sides by a magical barrier to keep the evil lord Dagoth Ur from escaping it.Once you get some levels on your character, exploration starts becoming much easier as you've got more money to travel, more speed, maybe a few teleportation spells.The main quest starts to open up as you deal with both the Great Houses of Vvardenfell and the nomadic Ashkhans who refuse Morrowind's Tribunal religion and believe in the return of the legendary lord Nerevar. Combat becomes slightly less of an affair in missing several times and finally hitting your enemy, though overall it's still bad, and the low point of the game, along with the Wikipedia-like conversations.Tens of hours in, near the end of the game, you'll no longer be a stranger in Vvardenfell. Quest locations will still be pointed out by somewhat confusing directions, but they feel easier by then. You already know things like what the hell a foyada is, for example. You already know you way around this island, by feet or by magic, because by then if you do use magic you should already know how to levitate and walk on water, maybe even how to jump across long distances in one jump. The main story also reflects this in part, which is great!What I'm saying is that Morrowind, by throwing you into a world and giving you the time to adapt, turns into into an inhabitant of sorts, who knows the nooks and crannies of a previously alien land. It's a masterpiece in world-building, though brought down a bit by simply bad combat. What is there more to say? Well, the music is great, and even though I'd usually associate such an alien setting to something other than Jeremy Soule epic fantasy stuff, it does fit.Being a Bethesda Gamebryo game, Morrowind is, of course, highly moddable, though it doesn't have as may mods as later games in the series. This means you can change whatever you don't like about the game, including making combat slightly more actionRPG-like, removing cliff racers (an omnipresent menace in the roads of Morrowind, and an awful one), improving graphics, et cetera. I'd recommend MGE XE, Morrowind Code Patch, watercolor textures if you're into that sort of thing (they're the same as the main game but high-res), any mod to remove cliff racers, and the dark brotherhood delayer (so you don't get attacked by people with the 2nd best light armor in the game by level 1, either dying or completely unbalancing your economy.)Overall Morrowind's amazing world makes the game very much worth your time, as you're not likely to see something like this anywhere else.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I'm going to open with pointing out my bias, because I played and loved this game endlessly on XBox back when it came out. Objectively, the graphics are very dated, and the gameplay does feel a little clunky. However if you're any fan of more classic RPG's, you need to give this game a look. Before Oblivion's more medieval landscape (Shivering Isles exheunt) and before Skyrim's Canada, Morrowind built a beautiful fantasy landscape, filled with spectacular creatures, varied characters, dwarven mechanations, and original quests.Technically speaking, the sound and graphics aren't much to speak of (though the music is adventurous, and really ups the experience). There is not much voice acting to speak of in most of this game, instead Bethesda opted for text boxes to save space. However, this opens the door for so much lore, and flavor text (which is important, damnit!) that this feels like the best crafted version of the Elder Scrolls universe. The game isn't levelled like it's predecessors, the world stays as it is, and you start out pretty weak. But it pushes you to be strong, and if you put the time in, you can overcome every challenge. There isn't a lot of emphasis on balance, because like a classic RPG, this game doesn't hold your hand. There isn't a compass to help you find quest points, instead you have a journal which subjectively directs you to your quest goal. For example, "The cave is north of Seyda Neen, a bit past the bridge on the river." It feels like a real adventure, going through it.If I were to price it: 30-Full price due to the age. But the game now can be found for incredibly cheap, I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hard RPG experience.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Morrowind has long been one of the best of the best.  What makes it so are the setting and the freedom.  I got into the franchise with Skyrim, but Morrowind is truly its pinnacle.  Sad to say we are unlikely to see anything like it as long as the corporate higher-ups at Bethesda see the Skyrim model as a safer bet.  Sure, Skyrim is prettier, and many people prefer its combat, but it just can't do as much, not even with mods.Really, I think what turns most people off the combat system isn't that it's based somewhat in RNG, it's that it's based somewhat in RNG but there's no animations showing what happened, leading to ridiculous situations where people go "I stabbed that rat in the face at point blank range and missed!" rather than "It dodged again?!  I guess rats are really fast..."  I think the latter is enough more immersive that many people would be able to ignore it...so long as they know WHY they're missing (usually low fatigue because they're running everywhere).  While there doesn't seem to be a mod to accomplish this now, when the open-source engine OpenMW hits version 1.0 and a full release, this kind of mod should be entirely possible, among a host of other options, such as natively working on Linux.  (As of this review, OpenMW is on version 0.40 -- perfectly playable, but somewhat buggy and doesn't work with all mods.)  There are, however, mods to make the combat like that in Skyrim and Oblivion -- I recommend the mod Oblivion-like Combat, which, as far as I know, is still only found on the official Bethesda forums.Finding mods for Morrowind can take a bit more searching than it does for Skyrim.  Skyrim mods are mostly consolidated on the Nexus, with a few exceptions.  Morrowind mods on the Nexus are few and far between.  Most are found on Morrowind Modding History, Great House Fliggerty, or the personal websites of the authors.  MMH in particular is an archive for all the mods formerly hosted on sites like Planet Elder Scrolls and ElricM which have gone down over the years.  You can find some truly impressive and interesting stuff there and the quantity swamps the Nexus, with almost four times as many mods uploaded.  Between GFH, MMH, the Nexus and all the other small sites out there hosting a handful of mods, I'm pretty sure there are more Morrowind mods available for download than Skyrim, and they're capable of affecting a lot more.  Much of what's hardcoded in Skyrim's engine is able to be altered in Morrowind's, and because of the way the engine processes them as well as the scripting language used, scripts are both safer to use and more versatile.  Beyond that, for things that ARE hardcoded, we have external utilities like the Morrowind Code Patch to make the changes we need, in addition to the script extender and others.The other enormous advantage Morrowind has over its sequels is its setting, which is strange, and alien, and very good at telling a story through the world itself.  Morrowind is also where most of the series' interesting lore comes from.  If you don't know how anyone can care about TES lore and haven't played Morrowind, that's probably why.  One of their major writers for the game has written stuff that makes it look like he can't possibly be sober, and yet it somehow works.  If you don't know what I'm talking about, look up Michael Kirkbride.  The man is some strange variety of storytelling genius, even if he doesn't appear to be at first glance.Other majorly good things about Morrowind include its main quest, which is probably the highest-quality out of the series  (by a very long way if you're only comparing it to Skyrim, and a bit less if you also include Oblivion).  There's just something special about getting dropped on Vvardenfell with not a coin to your name and no idea what you're doing or why you're there, and working your way up to godlike power so you can face down a terrible threat to all of Tamriel...Or is he?  Delve into the lore and the backstories, and you find it's not all so cut-and-dry.  Are those who would see the armies arrayed in secret shrines and ancient ruins destroyed truly your friends, or did Dagoth Ur have the right of it the whole time?  You may need mods to actually side with the seemingly crazed living god, but even without them, you can see that he may not actually be the villain all the citizens of Morrowind are making him out to be.  That ambiguity makes for a fascinating main story, and unlike the later games, it's paced very well for an open-world game, because your foe is a schemer.  He's incredibly dangerous, but you never know how imminent that danger is.  There's no false sense of urgency; instead, there's a sense of inevitability about impending doom if you don't act.  You can leave the main quest completely alone in favor of side quests for hundeds of hours right in the middle and go back to it afterwards and it still feels like it makes sense in-game.The guild quests have no overarching story, but their self-contained stories are generally interesting, and it's far less immersion-breaking to become the head of every major faction because A) you need the skills that faction cares about to ever be promoted anywhere near that high, and B) as the Nerevarine, you are a uniter of squabbling factions against the threat from Red Mountain, and so it makes some sense to have you leading numerous guilds that would otherwise oppose each other when you need to make arch enemies cooperate in the face of a common threat.The side quests are also quite good, all of them hand-placed and written with care.  None of those stupid strings of radiant dungeon-delving quests we got in Skyrim.  Also, remember all those little pieces of DLC made for Oblivion and sold for a few bucks each?  Remember Horse Armor?  Well, Morrowind has a few of those as well, but they're completely FREE.  Nothing as stupid as horse armor, either.  Instead, you get small but good dungeon mods, short but decent quest mods, item mods with and without quests attached, and small immersion increases, and none of them cost you a penny.  They are also all excellent, and generally recommended, except where you can find versions you prefer made by the community around ideas they got from the official version.Finally, I would be most remiss not to mention the magic system.  There are all sorts of crazy things you can do.  Enchanting is also much more versatile than in Oblivion, let alone Skyrim.  On-use magic items are something that Oblivion did away with completely, but in Morrowind, you could use a ring to summon creatures, or an amulet to shoot fireballs.  Enchanting weapons with constant effects is gone in the later games as well.  Beyond that, people of a particularly diabolical mindset have been known to enchant robes with constant effect damage health and place them on NPCs they want to see die, and on-use items allow you to get powerful effects that would be beyond overpowered if they were constant, either at the level you get them or at all.  Furthermore, no TES game since has had anywhere near the diversity of magic effects found in Morrowind.  Spells having a chance of failure if you try to cast ones that are too powerful is also something that makes sense to me as a lover of fantasy and an effective self-balancing mechanism.  Yeah, you could try to cast that enormous fireball, and if it hit, everything you're after would die...but it only has a 55% chance of succeeding, and would drain most of your magicka to boot.  Maybe try something safer?  This means there's no hard skill checks, no magic number at which you suddenly get access to spells you couldn't cast before.  If you have enough magicka and are willing to take the chance of failure given, you can try any spell you can think of.  You might have to increase your skill for it to be worth the risk in the heat of battle, but trying new things in the middle of combat has always been a dangerous move in any case.  But it could pay off...

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Spent a lot of my time in OpenMW rather than vanilla Morrowind, so my steam play time is relatively lower than my actual hours played. Open MW only updates the game engine, making it far more stable, nothing else, so i do know the game and its quirks well.Morrowind does not infact take place within Morrowind, It takes place on the island of Vvardenfell, I direct you to Tamriel Rebuilt for full Morrowind land mass.More in depth than Skyrim in terms of enchanting, magics, weaponry and interesting character backstories and a fantasticly built up world and of course, the NEED for stats and decent thought on how you distribute them.Story starts similarly to Oblivion and Skyrim... and most TES games with the old prisoner shenanigans.Combat is intensely complex, needing relative knowledge of how the Races and Classes will effect how your character plays during the first say around 5-10 levels when EVERYTHING can mess up your day.Not as pretty as Skyrim in terms of the games appearance, but at the heart the game has more soul, Though the looks can be potentially fixed with MGSO (go check it out if your unsure).Still to this day I would willingly pay $40 for this as there is potentially tons of replayability, even in terms of main storylines.ALL NPC's can be killed, yep even so called "Essentials", you kill a main quest character. Good job, find another way to do the quest and at worst, thats it, quest over, gg well played go screw over someone else now.A lot of people, will be put off by A- the graphics B- the combat system, C- how the game treats you like♥♥♥♥♥♥at low levels.The game does not care if you are roleplaying an uber hero, until you have actually achieved something in the eyes of Vvardenfells people. You are not a majestic hero with power flowing out of every orifice on your person. You're no one, N'wah, Outlander. A person who does not know Vvardenfell, unwanted by the populace of Dunmer, those who do want you there don't want you... youu are there by the commands of their superiors. You are a blade of grass upon a huge field, no one, nothing, no heroic deeds to your name, no well made gear on your person, your privilige is you are allowed to tread upon Vvardenfells pathways, your only reward is the gear you fight for and scrape from dust and corpses.Uses ye olde fantasy utility of only silver and magical weapons can harm Ghosts, Daedra, etc...Moddable, but with great delicacy.Frustrating at first, but grows on you, slowly.I hope to the nine divines Bethesda leave MW alone, as I know for a fact, they will remove the dice rolls hits and ridiculusly OP enchants, scrolls and potion possibilities. On par with the Witcher 3's detailing in the world, On par with Skyrims modding community, On par with the Nostalia of Baldurs Gate. Ridiculously cheap for what it actuallt is.The Elder Scrolls at it's finest.Morrowind.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												One of the greatest games I have ever played.    I just want to highlight the skill system here, for some of the good and inherently bad things about it.The thing about the skill system in Morrowind is that it has many skills and possibilities, but it is solely based on the gods of RNG. The thing that's so bad about this (or, based on your perspective- good), is that everything you do is based on a percentage, a number, a sliver of chance as a new character. This means that even if you are an extremely powerful level 50 character, mastering all there is to know in the school of swordplay, you'll still have a chance of completely missing the enemy and doing no damage.   Another thing I see people fail to realise in their nostalgia is the fatigue system. There is literally no reason for me not to be able to throw fireballs at people's faces because my Fatigue is low. And because of this, the chance of casting is significantly lowered...that's all I'll say about that. It's incredibly aggravating.   The Graphics...they're extremely dated and about 13 years old. They haven't exactly aged well. But although this game doesn't look terrible, it can still be jarring for a new player to come from Skyrim or Oblivion into this game.   The Gameplay isn't incredible, but still fun. Even despite it's odd skill system. It's Classic RPG fundamentals are, in a way, the lifeblood of this game, despite it's oddities. In no other game can you walk up to a slow-moving mudcrab at level 1, completely miss every swing, and get yourself killed. Despite this, you can do anything you want, kill anyone or anything you want, steal, plunder, or even become the Grandmaster of almost every guild. Despite this, the game does NOT hold your hand. You have to work for what you want. Don't have enough gold for that Dreugh Helmet? Go to that dwarven ruin over the hill, kill everything inside, and find the treasures within. This game really captures the scope and expanse you would expect of an entire continent, even in just the space of an island. You can be running through the rolling hills of the grazelands, and the next minute you're in the middle of Molag Amur, in the midst of pools of lava and ash. That being said, it still takes a while for that transition. Even for an old game, the map is huge.   The Story is one of the pinnacles of this game. In more recent years, the story has not been bland, per se- but rather, it has been turned into this constant story that the game will try to make you feel inclined to stay with until that story has ended. For example, in Skyrim the main story was very heavily forced upon you. They try to create this false sense of "urgency" that you just do not find in this game. You are thrust into this world with no money, no hope, and no future. You are not respected as an outlander. People don't like the idea of integrating the ignorant "n'wahs" into their society. As with anything in this game, you must earn their respect. There is tons of side-quests which, I will argue, are about 30-40% "Go fetch this for me" quests or, "Go kill this man for me". But even in these quests, Morrowind most definitely has an extensive story to tell, and quite an enthralling one at that.   The DLC in this game is phenominal! Much like the other Elderscrolls games, the downloadable content in this game is extremely good. (Minus the horse armor from Oblivion!) Rich, and deep with story- the activites and things to do in them are quite extensive. The first time I had gone to the Clockwork City in Tribunal, I KNEW that I would remember that experience in gaming forever. I was in awe of this world created by a man-turned-god. Which is a feeling you don't get in most games today.   All-in-all, I think that this is a great game- and definitely stands the test of time today. With a few mods (which are still being made in 2015), this game can definitely net you countless hours of mudcrab-bashing fun. Definitely worth picking up, if you haven't already.

												Truly a classic. While Skyrim drew the attention of casuals and babbie's first RPG's, Morrowind has always been a game to respect the player and his choices. That's your choice, live with the consequences or reload a save. Sold a quest item? Shouldn't have done that, all your fault. It feels more like a game as opposed to a sandbox. You can do anything, but the world isn't here for you to just ride it.

Он либо может затянуть с первой мелодии, либо с первой мелодии отвратить.А меня вот затянула рецензия на ещё вышедшую игру, вернее короткая новость в Навигаторе игрового мира вроде. 												After playing almost 200 hours of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, I decided to give Morrowind a try, as everyone says it's the best entry in the series. I bought this game back in 2012, and played it for about 1 hour; I didn't like it at all, it started out slowly, I had to read a crapton of stuff, and I got easily lost in about half an hour, so I stopped playing it.Two years later, I decided to give this game another try. It's seriously one of the best RPG's ever.The game is slow, I simply accepted that and decided to take it all slowly, read all texts, even take notes IRL so I don't get lost and I remember important stuff; the graphics are a bit outdated, yeah, but nothing Morrowind Graphics Extender can't help; the lore is awesome, everyone seems important (except those slaves you free) to the game, the gameplay is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because it's dice-based, but it gets pretty cool in mid-end game, and the best part: The Soundtrack.Totally recommend this game, may not attract everyone, but those who like this type of game will fall in love with Morrowind.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												I want to like this game, but it's so difficult. I know the serious RPGers go on and on about how Morrowind is the best thing ever created, but if you're not a hardcore RPG player or someone who gets nostalgia from it, you're probably going to be disappointed. I can appreciate some of the complexity as far as different weapon and armor types go, but there's not enough good to outweigh the bad for me. For starters, it takes forever to get anywhere. Yeah yeah, RPG realism, blah blah blah. My point is if you don't have 8 straight hours to play this game, then you can't get a whole lot done. There's no fast travel, which wouldn't be a huge deal because of the transportation services, if it weren't for the fact that you still have to run to a lot of places. Walking is the default speed, and it is ridiculously slow. Running is a little faster, but it uses up stamina, so you have to run, walk, run, all at a far slower pace than in other games. The hit chance is so low that you can swing 20 times at something and miss every single time if your skill with the weapon you're using is low. It makes sense for an opponent to occasionally dodge an attack, but come on. Training that weapon skill requires actually hitting the opponent, so it's very slow going to train your weapon skill and boost your agility to the point where you can hit something maybe 8/10 times. It's even harder to efficiently level than it is in Oblivion, partly because you have both major and MINOR skills that contribute to your next level, and you're going to end up accidentally training the ones you don't want quite often. The plethora of factions is cool, but you can never really become super close with any of them because it's all so impersonal and it's hard to become invested in them. The music isn't nearly as pretty as in Oblivion or as energetic as in Skyrim, and the landscape is all rocky and grey, with a few giant mushrooms sticking up to try and make it look a little more interesting. I'm personally not a huge fan of the whole alien looking flora and fauna, and I thought it was much better done in the Shivering Isles than here anyway. If there's one saving grace for Morrowind, it's that it has a great lore and backstory, arguably better than the other games in some respects. So if you really want to experience the story of the game more power to you, but my advice is to install some major mods to make the gameplay less frustrating and a lot more bearable.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Golly gee wiz, just going through the first few reviews of this game wasn't a walk in the park. Granted, many have made valid points and I do agree in some aspects, but some may have been a tad bit biased. That being said, that's not what this is about. Now, let us move on to the actual review, shall we?Ahem.Let Blue the Bard (that me) tell all you lovelies a teeny tiny story. A story that you may or may not rage at, but that matter is entirely on your part, not necessarily mine. Blue will admit that they got into the Elder Scrolls series by first playing Skyrim. I know, I know, how n00bish and lame of me, but please, spare Blue the Bard a moment or two! Thing is, Blue hadn't even  heard  of the TES series until Skyrim came out. And even then, they didn't even play it at that time (when it first came out in 2011). Skip to a few years and one of their good ol' friends caused Blue to perk an interest in the game. They were curious, so they decided to try it out. And, to their surprise, they loved it! Blue wanted to get into more of this series, so they did. Blue tried their hand at TES I: Arena. A bit of a hassle, that one is: what with the DOSbox thingy and remembering the commands, etc. But Blue had minimal knowledge in that area so it wasn't so bad. Skip to a few weeks or months later and TES III: Morrowind and TES IV: Oblivion went on sale. Blue acted quickly and purchased them. First, they tried Morrowind, seeing how that game was released first out of the two. Okay, so I lied. THIS is where the actual review starts. Blue was very mindful as to not have been biased in any manner, for such a thing is a spell for disaster. They reassured themself that "hey, this is an old game. It's not gonna be fancy-pantsy pretty like them later installments. And maybe the mechanics and gameplay are slightly different. You'll just have to go through with it, like other people have."Well, I played it, and I loved it. Sure it is a tad bit more complicated, and there are indeed things I could complain about (initial player speed and limited voice acting to name a few specifics) but those aren't things worth giving up this game for. In this game, Blue is nearly unbiased, for they lack the nostalgia factor and they have an understanding of this game being an older thing.Honestly, despite the early graphics, Blue felt immersed. Here they were, exploring this strange and magnificent land. And, in Blue's humble opinion, this installment has the most relaxing music track. And that is a good thing. Blue felt..happy playing this game. Despite the fact that they have obviously played more Skyrim and Oblivion than Morrowind, Morrowind is something Blue can always come back to. There is still so much more to be explored, after all. And they look forward to it. c:And that's my review for The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.

A story that you may or may not rage at, but that matter is entirely on your part, not necessarily mine. Blue will admit that they got into the Elder Scrolls series by first playing Skyrim. I know, I know, how n00bish and lame of me, but please, spare Blue the Bard a moment or two! Thing is, Blue hadn't even  heard  of the TES series until Skyrim came out. And even then, they didn't even play it at that time (when it first came out in 2011). Skip to a few years and one of their good ol' friends caused Blue to perk an interest in the game. They were curious, so they decided to try it out. And, to their surprise, they loved it! Blue wanted to get into more of this series, so they did. Blue tried their hand at TES I: Arena. A bit of a hassle, that one is: what with the DOSbox thingy and remembering the commands, etc. But Blue had minimal knowledge in that area so it wasn't so bad. Skip to a few weeks or months later and TES III: Morrowind and TES IV: Oblivion went on sale. Blue acted quickly and purchased them. First, they tried Morrowind, seeing how that game was released first out of the two. Okay, so I lied. THIS is where the actual review starts. Blue was very mindful as to not have been biased in any manner, for such a thing is a spell for disaster. They reassured themself that "hey, this is an old game. It's not gonna be fancy-pantsy pretty like them later installments. And maybe the mechanics and gameplay are slightly different. You'll just have to go through with it, like other people have."Well, I played it, and I loved it. Sure it is a tad bit more complicated, and there are indeed things I could complain about (initial player speed and limited voice acting to name a few specifics) but those aren't things worth giving up this game for. In this game, Blue is nearly unbiased, for they lack the nostalgia factor and they have an understanding of this game being an older thing.Honestly, despite the early graphics, Blue felt immersed. Here they were, exploring this strange and magnificent land. And, in Blue's humble opinion, this installment has the most relaxing music track. And that is a good thing. Blue felt..happy playing this game. Despite the fact that they have obviously played more Skyrim and Oblivion than Morrowind, Morrowind is something Blue can always come back to. There is still so much more to be explored, after all. And they look forward to it. c:And that's my review for The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.

												Good:You are truly free to go wherever you want and do whatever you want. The game world is incredibly rich and complex. The main story is amazing, but there are also a huge number of side quests, which the game actively encourages you to explore. I didn't even get past the first mission of the main quest in my first year or so of playing. Unlike the other TES games, you usually have to work hard to get the best gear, which makes it far more rewarding. Bad:The graphics aren't the best, although that can be fixed with mods. The combat system takes a bit of getting used to, although it can be very rewarding when you reach higher levels. Overall, this is probably my favourite game of all time. The graphics and combat are quite dated, but if you can get past that, you are in for a fantastic open-world experience.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I have well over 500 hours in Skyrim (counting all platforms), 350 hours in Oblivion and probably around 350 hours in Morrowind in total...so far, and it is my opinion that Morrowind gives the best RPG and TES experience of this threesome (I am leaving out Arena and Daggerfall as I haven't really gotten around to playing them properly yet). The main story of Morrowind (which is the only real questline in the game without the expansions) is simply many levels above what is presented to us in Oblivion and Skyrim as I see it. Even though the graphics are now very outdated, I still feel the game world in Morrowind feels more "real" than in the two latest games - the reason for this is probably that Morrowind is much more lore-rich and that no matter where you go and what you do you still feel connected with the main plot and the workings of Dunmer society (which you will be intimately familiar with in this game).Morrowind's greatest asset is probably the sense of wonder and strangeness the game world instills in the player and its very rewarding exploration. Some have called Morrowind "the last real TES game", and while I'm not going to make that claim it is clear that the dumbing down of the series and the extreme hand-holding of the player in say Skyrim has not exactly made the series take a direction that I'm very happy with. In Morrowind you often have to read to discover what to do and where to go at times and at other times you will have to think - there are no quest markers in this game to ruin this part of the game. Many people complain about the combat in Morrowind, and reasonably so if the game is to be compared to modern action titles - this was never the point however: this game is supposed to be an RPG with many mechanics taken from table-top RPG gaming. Seen in this light the combat system is altogether decent and in my opinion can be quite fun. In vanilla Morrowind for instance you can not manually block with your shield, something that probably sounds ridiculous to modern players - it makes perfect sense though seen from the perspective of old-school RPG-gaming where it is your character's stats and abilities that govern the outcome of an action and not the players own skills of reaction and button-timing and what not.All in all I strongly recommend this game and I urge all fans of TES to try it out no matter their feelings about the lack of an action-oriented combat system, because in my opinion this game is simply a better RPG experience than we get in Oblivion or Skyrim. A far better one. Oblivion and Skyrim are games I will probably never play again (been there done that...), but Morrowind I will return to again and again.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is quite possibly the best video game I have ever played and easily the best RPG.  The backstory is basically that you're sprung from prison by imperial decree, put on carriage, then ship, and dropped off in a swampy little village in a distant elven land without being briefed on anything.  You get clued in a little bit when you talk to the Imperial agents at the offices where you're dropped off, but you still don't know the real reason you're there until you persue the main quest.  I won't provide spoilers on that.This game is much truer to the RPG element than many modern RPGs which rely heavily on action, kill moves and stunning graphics.  This basically means it's much harder to play the game through and accidentally becoming a jack-of-all-trades and master of all guilds.  The spell and weapon and apparel variety is exceptional.  Armor comes in individual pieces that you wear over your torso, left and right hand, left and right shoulder, boots and head, but you can also wear clothes under your armor and a robe over it, if you choose.  You can also trek accross the land in not a stitch of clothing if wish.You can forget about random fast travel from any given location.  You need spells and scrolls for that, or otherwise find people who provide travelling services.  If you find yourself lost in ash country without proper provisions or equipment, the game will also most likely punish you accordingly.Morrowind was releaseed around 2002 and does show its age in the graphics department, however.  If graphics and deeper immersion are that important to you, the game has been given exceptional attention by modders over the years.  Many mods are available over at the Nexus that are compatible with the Steam version here.  For bare basics, I recommend the Morrowind Code Patch which basically combs over many of Bethesda's oversights.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Morrowind is arguably the best in the Elder Scrolls series for several reasons which I will go into detail in this review. If you're on the fence about this game, hopefully I can bring some insight to the wary. Please note that Morrowind is by no means a perfect game, but has some incredibly redeeming qualities about it that will keep you coming back for more no matter your experience with other RPGs or Elder Scrolls games.You're sent to Morrowind on a prison ship along with one other, for reasons left unkown to the player, with a missive from the emperor himself. There has been rumours abound for a long time in Morrowind that Saint Nerevar, a powerful Dark Elf from ancient days past, would be reincarnated and rid Morrowind of the outlanders and protect her from it's enemies. The emperor has suspicions that the player may be one who could fulfill this prophecy, and sends you to the island of Vvardenfell within the province of Morrowind. There had been plenty of 'false incarnates' of Nerevar in the past, who claimed to be the reincarnated hero, but all of whom were proven false by the roaming Ashlander tribes that inhabit Vvardenfell. This is basically your introduction to the game.After you exit the prison ship, you choose your race and which skills to favour, and they basically hand you a note to deliver and tell you 'good luck!' From here, the world is open to you, and you can choose any path you wish. The world is truly massive and you can pursue whatever suits your fancy. There are few limitations in Morrowind as to what you can do; you can kill every single character in the game, for example, which the later Elder Scrolls games lack. You can rob entire stores, kill the 'false gods' (tribunal), claim an entire city as your own... The possibilities are rather overwhelming at first.The magic system is probably the best of any of the games, allowing you to create your own spells in several schools of magic, including the ability to levitate high above the ground or jump several kilometres in a single bound. You can use bound weapons and armor at the same time, and even create one spell to not only bind a weapon but also a set of armor to wear. The enchanting system is impeccable, allowing for 'constant effect' enchanting, which can allow you to heal your health constantly without the use of spells, or constantly have several flame atronachs or golden saints following you at all times. The spellcrafting and enchating in Morrowind offers a lot of different combinations and possibilities to make your character the most powerful being in all Tamriel.The combat system is clunky, and rather lackluster. Depending on your skill with a weapon, you will either hit or miss, even if you're aiming directly at the target. It is also dependent on how much stamina you currently have; if your stamina is low your chance to hit is significantly lessened (This however can be corrected with a constant effect stamina regeneration enchant). This is one of the more frustrating aspects of Morrowind, but after a certain point when you become skilled with a weapon it really doesn't affect the gameplay too negatively. It'll be hard in the beginning, but you will notice when your character truly begins to become strong.The story line is very in depth, and involves your quest to find out whether or not you truly are the reincarnated Nervar, or the 'Nerevarine,' as was prophecised by the Ashlander tribes. Along the way you will meet many memorable characters and enemies, delve deep into very dangerous dungeons and caves, and form alliances and bonds with the Ashlander tribes that live throughout Vvardenfell. Through these experiences the player becomes stronger and more aware of the world around them, and also what is at stake; the destruction of all Tamriel itself.This game also boasts a huge selection of items, including 9 different types of weapons (with appropriate skills to use them), dozens of different armor types, hundreds of different potions, hundreds of books, and more! Many of these items also have unique designs which makes for varied NPC enemies and exceptional loot; all of which has been hand placed in the world by the developers. No more random loot for you, you know where something will be after you've found it for the first time.There are also two expansions, the Tribunal expansion, which involves two of the three of the 'false gods' known as the Tribunal, and also Bloodmoon, which involves the exploration and salvation of the small island of Solthsteim. Both of these expansions feature extended gameplay, new types of armor and weapons, new enemies and even bigger challenges than the vanilla originally offered.There is something to be said about the NPCs and their relation to the player as well. Though on the outside, they're rather robotic, when you engage them in conversation you have dozens of topics that you can ask almost every NPC in the game, and many a time they will be different or unique responses depending on their relation to the player or their race/status. For instance, on my last playthrough I donned some Ordinator armor, which are the guardians of Vivec city and the guardians of one of the Tribunal, Vivec himself. Since I am not of the Ordinator order, I am not permitted to wear such sacred armor, and the Ordinators will attack me on sight for disrespecting their hierarchy. It's little things like that that make the NPCs just a bit more a part of the world than bumbling ways of retrieving information.I could go on and on about the things that make Morrowind such a joy to play, but really it's something that needs to be experienced rather than read about. And that's the key thing here, it's an experience, not just a game you play through and forget. There are plenty of little quirky things in the game that make it memorable, such as an orc who believes he's a khajiit, no matter how many times you tell him he's not he will not believe you. Or a man falling from the sky to his death in front of you, for seemingly no reason until you read his journal which explains what went wrong. All in all, this is my favourite game of all time, and if you can look passed it's flaws and dated graphics, you may find yourself of a similar opinion.Oh also don't let my played time on Steam fool you, I've owned this game for over a decade on Xbox original, played through it several times with friends on their consoles, and also on older PCs, with what is most likely over one thousand hours of play time. You can definitely get your money's worth with Morrowind.

												I came from Oblivion to Morrowind and normally I keep an open mind about going to older games and so I did and this game is Incredible, I love the environment of the world and it felt like a very mystical and fun world to explore, the only complaints I have are about the combat system, for the longest time I thought the game was glitched and I could only get hits with a 2% chance while everyone else gets a direct hit, but now I realize how the combat system works, it seems rather odd but after researching it, found it to be bareable to say the least, besides that I found nothing else to dislike about the game, its understandable why theres little voice acting but it doesn't completely take you out of the experience  just makes you appreciate the work put into the dialogue, I fell in love with the crazy amount of weaponry in the game and found myself using spears almost all the time, and however some can argue about not being able to fast travel via a map is a very tedious endeavor however by forcing you to travel from place to place it does make it feel more real the world you are exploring and so I would recommend this to anyone who has played the 4th and 5th elder scrolls game and is looking for something to pass the time while waiting for that 6th elder scrolls announcement.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												The essence of Morrowind is that which cannot be described. It is transcendant, absolute, and eternal. Without a doubt Bethesda's greatest work, this game is what, even now, any serious rpg should aspire to be like.Oblivion and Skyrim, while fine in their own right, fall short of their intended purpose as successors to the Elder Scrolls series. What Morrowind had in spades, such as character building, or spell and equipment variety, Oblivion cut back on. What remained in Oblivion, Skyrim gutted entirely. Luck is dead, and no amount of dual wielding will change that.Depth of lore, fantastic world building, variety in locations, factions, and inhabitants, though sparse by todays standards, each of the locales, their inhabitants, and even the clothes those people wore, were hand crafted with specific purpose in mind. That purpose was to create the most fully realized world possible, with all the factions, motives, loot, and beasts possible, then drop you in the middle of it with the keys to the kingdom in hand.What you did from then on was up to you. Every Elder Scrolls game does this to an extent, but not in the way Morrowind did. As your character grew, so to did his ability to shape the world around him. Guilds would clash against each other depending on who you ally with, self-made gods might very well die by your hand, and if you so chose the very mechanics of the world could allow you to ascend to god-like power. The framework was all there, it was just up to you how you used it. If you don't care about the crunchy bits of roleplaying, in other words half of the fun, pass on it. There are plenty of more casual friendly games out there, like Skyrim or Bejeweled.If you want a game where character stats and gear still matter, where the world is a character itself, and there is always the promise of adventure over the next hill, there are few games more worthy of your time.P.S. - I'm fairly sure there are more mods for this game than there are stars in the sky. Seriously, you'll never run out of things to explore and try out.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												I have been playing this game on and off for the last ten years. I can honestly say it has to be my all-time favourite, and the very first game I ever bought which was a fantasy RPG.You are plunged into an alien world, playing as a foreigner to this land (and you certainly feel it too) with beautiful landscapes and so much open plot you can play a different game every time. The vanilla version of the game is wonderful, but add the thousands of mods you can install onto it and it becomes almost perfect. Granted, this game is not for the faint-hearted: It's hard. Very hard. From the moment you get off that prison ship in Seyda Neen. However, put enough time into it and all the hard work pays off, rewarding you with incredible weapons, spells and armour, or even the ability to create even better equipment.Don't let the out-dated graphics put you off either; there are tons of mods that provide graphics overhauls, not to mention the Morroblivion mod and the forthcoming Skywind mod.I can honestly say this is so much better than Skyrim in terms of the diversity of all the creatures and denizens of Morrowind, the massive story and side-quests, the lore and just that feeling you get when you find yourself lost in the Bitter Coast, taking in the scenery, exploring forgotten tombs, foraging strange fauna and hoping to Azura that you don't encounter another damn Cliff Racer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												This, without a doubt, is one of the best games ever released. It has a just deep enough character development system, good combat, exploration and replayability value. I've accrued about four hundred hours in Morrowind back in the day when I had it on CD.Pros:  A large world to explore. It's not as large as Skyrim or Oblivion, but still good. Replayability. You can make dozens of different builds, most of which will be viable with a little work. No, really. My main character fought through spears and acrobatics, akin to Final Fantasy Dragoons. No railroading AND no quest markers. Instead you get a rather detailed description of a road...OR NOT! Some quests just want you to explore, and if you don't like it, I wouldn't recommend this series. Immersion. Everyone has something to say, even if most of the time it's not helpful in any way. Cons: Somewhat clunky combat system, not much of a trouble, though. Playing as a mage is a PITA due to manaregen being nonexistent in normal gameplay, easily rectified with a mod, or just by being hardcore and not giving a damn. Some people may find the graphics outdated. The game is JUST FINE as it is, actually, but there's a fix for graphics, too - Morrowind Graphics Extender and some retextures.  ...there ain't a fourth! If you want an open world RPG, grab this without a second thought. Hundreds of hours of fun guaranteed.Details:What makes it different from the following entries of TES series like Oblivion and Skyrim is that it is absolutely playable and enjoyable to the core WITHOUT any mods, and Morrowind also supports a wider variety of playstyles.It has no handholding, you're thrown into a world ripe with magic and mayhem, but unlike some other oldschool RPGs, it also gives you some directions, which do not feel like handholding, but merely provide a path which you may take, knowing that it won't massacre you brutally for deviating from some pattern, but rather will reward you as long as you're somewhat sensible.

content:

												Good:You are truly free to go wherever you want and do whatever you want. The game world is incredibly rich and complex. The main story is amazing, but there are also a huge number of side quests, which the game actively encourages you to explore. I didn't even get past the first mission of the main quest in my first year or so of playing. Unlike the other TES games, you usually have to work hard to get the best gear, which makes it far more rewarding. Bad:The graphics aren't the best, although that can be fixed with mods. The combat system takes a bit of getting used to, although it can be very rewarding when you reach higher levels. Overall, this is probably my favourite game of all time. The graphics and combat are quite dated, but if you can get past that, you are in for a fantastic open-world experience.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												I was excited when Morrowind finally came out on Steam. I've decided (obviously) to write a review.Let's be clear: This mod is not for you if you require on graphics or audio to enjoy a game. If you don't, read this review (NOTE THAT THERE WILL BE SPOILERS):Morrowind is a creatively-crafted, replayable game with great storylines and gameplay. You start out as a mere, useless outlander and work your way up. This game by no means gives you a title. No matter what quest you do, you must be powerful enough to become the next rank in a guild. The main quest doesn't hold your hand and is relatively harder compared to modern RPS. The combat, the skill system, it's great, yet not perfect. Trust me when I tell you that this game will not be over quick. I became Nerevarine of all tribes and Hortator of all houses... and I was pronounced a heretic and hated by many. If you don't enjoy this game... you're an n'wah!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												What can be said that hasn't been already been said about this fantastic entry in the series? The game brings the province of Morrowind, more specifically the island of Vvardenfell, to life. Its an unforgetfull experiance just wandering through one of the more "interesting" regions of Tamriel. This game is one of the finest examples of an RPG in the early 2000s and it amazes me how much lore and intrigue Bethesda put into this game, it's great just going up to an NPC and just hearing their backstory.The Dungeons were also great with some unforgetfull puzzles along with the interesting architecture that surrounds almost every building in Vvardenfell. RPG elements too are all present which any RPG fan will appreciate though it could be jarring to someone who started on Skyrim which seems to throw most of the elements out the window. Sometimes I have a hard time deciding whether Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind or Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall is my favourite in the series but you can't be wrong either way, this game is a fantastic entry in the series, every Elder Scrolls & RPG fan needs to play this game. 100% recommended.
