number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												A long time ago in my early highschool days, I was lent a copy of a game called "morrowind." I hated it, I thought it was boring, so I gave the CD back. A week later, I asked to borrow it again because in an odd fit of curiosity, I wanted to see it again. My friend gave it to me, and told me not to give it back. He hated it, but I found to my surprise, that I loved it.As time goes on, it seems like less and less care is being put into the TES games. I had fun with skyrim, sure, but whered the complexity go? morrowinds combat is really nothing to look at, and it's journal is horrendous, but what about throwing weapons? what about spears? what about the differences in weapon types? Did the whole TES world simply forget about crossbows until the dawnguard rediscovered them in skyrim? What happened to complex enchantments on equipment? Dumbing down is what happened. Simplifying the games for a simpler generation. What happened to the exploration? I played oblivion for a couple hundred hours, and had seen most of it. I played skyrim for about 100 hours, and has seen ALL of it. I played morrowind for an untold number of hours, and I still find things I've never seen before.While bethesda continues to dumb down release after release of TES and FO games, I'll still be back here, playing Daggerfall, Morrowind, and Oblivion. Maybe skyrim here and there, but meh.As one final note of disgust for Bethesda in general; Morrowind may be great, but do not pay 20$ for it. How they can justify charging that much for a game this old is well beyond my reasoning. Get it on sale and enjoy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												The first Elder Scrolls game I played was Skyrim and I got Morrowind and Oblivion later on to learn more of the background story. I assume I'm not the only one so this recommendation will be geared towards other people who are playing the series backwards.Pros: + Large and dynamic world (for the time anyway)+ Quests aren't spoonfed to you and you're challenged to figure out on your own where to go and what to do+ Many different factions for you to join and your choices will affect how other factions judge you. It's not like Skyrim where you can join the Theives Guild and Dark Brotherhood and no one seems to care.+ What happens in this game is sometimes referenced to in later titles so you get a better understanding of the Elder Scrolls universe+ No fast travel means you have to prioritize where you want to go. The ability to use silt striders and teleport with the Mage's Guild is a fair compromise. Some might see this as a con, but I think it's better this way. It forces you to explore more and get to know all the places along the way instead of fast traveling and missing out on things. Cons:- Combat is super clunky. Meelee fights are basically like rock em sock em robots. Even your shield is completely passive. - If a skill level is too low, it will always "fail." Weapon swings will always miss, ingredients can be mixed and used up but the potions won't be created, spells will eat up your mana but still won't cast, etc.- Stamina, referred to in this game as "fatigue," can run out quickly and you're practically useless in a fight once you've run out. If your enemy is strong enough, they'll keep knocking you to the ground and can't do anything but revert to your last save or wait till they kill you.- Your character runs really really slow when you first start out (you can level your speed or get items to make you faster later on) and you can move a bit faster by jumping while running diagonally which is kind of stupid if you ask me.- NPC dialogues in many situations are lazily copy/pasted.Overall I'd say it's worth getting the game even if you're more accustomed to Skyrim. The game is from 2002 so most of the issues with it are kind of forgiveable. Just keep in mind that if something isn't one of your main skills, you can basically forget about using it until you find someone who can train you in it, and that you should always have fatigue potions ready when you might get into a fight. I'd also suggest getting the MGSO mod to make the game look nicer and fix some of the bugs.

												Perhaps the best RPG ever made. Graphics are a bit out dated, but there are mods for that. I recommend Morrowind Overhaul 3.0. It will set up most things automatically, and then let you set specific things that you want. It breathes life back into one of my favorite games.Don't be fooled by newer Elder Scrolls games such as Oblivion and Skyrim. This game is difficult to start up. It's unforgiving. You may die in the first cave. Don't give up though. Explore, gather loot, and learn how to best use your fatigue.There is no hand holding in this game. No quest markers, no fast travel (unless you use the town to town system and even that costs gold), and enemies don't level with you. You can wander into zones where you have no business being.I can not recommend this game enough. It's a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I have well over 500 hours in Skyrim (counting all platforms), 350 hours in Oblivion and probably around 350 hours in Morrowind in total...so far, and it is my opinion that Morrowind gives the best RPG and TES experience of this threesome (I am leaving out Arena and Daggerfall as I haven't really gotten around to playing them properly yet). The main story of Morrowind (which is the only real questline in the game without the expansions) is simply many levels above what is presented to us in Oblivion and Skyrim as I see it. Even though the graphics are now very outdated, I still feel the game world in Morrowind feels more "real" than in the two latest games - the reason for this is probably that Morrowind is much more lore-rich and that no matter where you go and what you do you still feel connected with the main plot and the workings of Dunmer society (which you will be intimately familiar with in this game).Morrowind's greatest asset is probably the sense of wonder and strangeness the game world instills in the player and its very rewarding exploration. Some have called Morrowind "the last real TES game", and while I'm not going to make that claim it is clear that the dumbing down of the series and the extreme hand-holding of the player in say Skyrim has not exactly made the series take a direction that I'm very happy with. In Morrowind you often have to read to discover what to do and where to go at times and at other times you will have to think - there are no quest markers in this game to ruin this part of the game. Many people complain about the combat in Morrowind, and reasonably so if the game is to be compared to modern action titles - this was never the point however: this game is supposed to be an RPG with many mechanics taken from table-top RPG gaming. Seen in this light the combat system is altogether decent and in my opinion can be quite fun. In vanilla Morrowind for instance you can not manually block with your shield, something that probably sounds ridiculous to modern players - it makes perfect sense though seen from the perspective of old-school RPG-gaming where it is your character's stats and abilities that govern the outcome of an action and not the players own skills of reaction and button-timing and what not.All in all I strongly recommend this game and I urge all fans of TES to try it out no matter their feelings about the lack of an action-oriented combat system, because in my opinion this game is simply a better RPG experience than we get in Oblivion or Skyrim. A far better one. Oblivion and Skyrim are games I will probably never play again (been there done that...), but Morrowind I will return to again and again.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												The Elder Srolls Series i think is one of those Love and/or Hate series because of its take on the RPG genre.The Story Lines are really deep and there is huge amounts of background lore scattered about through side quests, books in game, or even just by listening to the NPC's converse with one another. Insane, I know. Still one of the Largest free roam RPG's of its time probably even bigger than some AAA MMORPG's (before major expansions of course).Combat is where it was hit or miss with people, you can still attack at will, yet some features like your shield skills were based upon a hidden RTD (roll the dice) feature that rolled your chance to block attacks until it leveled up and made your shield skills grow. There is plenty of secret areas (not really secret anymore since im sure theyve all been documented and plundered since) and large areas and dungeons to explore.***If you want the Hardest play through possible without any help from the game or the gods, kill Vivec when you first meet him, loot the note and item from him. You will get a message pretty much the same one you get from killing any important NPC suggesting that you restart from a save. This is an Easter Egg***For those with a great computer i suggest grabbing the Morrowind Overhaul 3.0 (Final Version) mod which has many great graphical upgrades as well as bug fixes & tweaking options for better gameplay.http://www.ornitocopter.net/morrowind-overhaul/

												I came from Oblivion to Morrowind and normally I keep an open mind about going to older games and so I did and this game is Incredible, I love the environment of the world and it felt like a very mystical and fun world to explore, the only complaints I have are about the combat system, for the longest time I thought the game was glitched and I could only get hits with a 2% chance while everyone else gets a direct hit, but now I realize how the combat system works, it seems rather odd but after researching it, found it to be bareable to say the least, besides that I found nothing else to dislike about the game, its understandable why theres little voice acting but it doesn't completely take you out of the experience  just makes you appreciate the work put into the dialogue, I fell in love with the crazy amount of weaponry in the game and found myself using spears almost all the time, and however some can argue about not being able to fast travel via a map is a very tedious endeavor however by forcing you to travel from place to place it does make it feel more real the world you are exploring and so I would recommend this to anyone who has played the 4th and 5th elder scrolls game and is looking for something to pass the time while waiting for that 6th elder scrolls announcement.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												The essence of Morrowind is that which cannot be described. It is transcendant, absolute, and eternal. Without a doubt Bethesda's greatest work, this game is what, even now, any serious rpg should aspire to be like.Oblivion and Skyrim, while fine in their own right, fall short of their intended purpose as successors to the Elder Scrolls series. What Morrowind had in spades, such as character building, or spell and equipment variety, Oblivion cut back on. What remained in Oblivion, Skyrim gutted entirely. Luck is dead, and no amount of dual wielding will change that.Depth of lore, fantastic world building, variety in locations, factions, and inhabitants, though sparse by todays standards, each of the locales, their inhabitants, and even the clothes those people wore, were hand crafted with specific purpose in mind. That purpose was to create the most fully realized world possible, with all the factions, motives, loot, and beasts possible, then drop you in the middle of it with the keys to the kingdom in hand.What you did from then on was up to you. Every Elder Scrolls game does this to an extent, but not in the way Morrowind did. As your character grew, so to did his ability to shape the world around him. Guilds would clash against each other depending on who you ally with, self-made gods might very well die by your hand, and if you so chose the very mechanics of the world could allow you to ascend to god-like power. The framework was all there, it was just up to you how you used it. If you don't care about the crunchy bits of roleplaying, in other words half of the fun, pass on it. There are plenty of more casual friendly games out there, like Skyrim or Bejeweled.If you want a game where character stats and gear still matter, where the world is a character itself, and there is always the promise of adventure over the next hill, there are few games more worthy of your time.P.S. - I'm fairly sure there are more mods for this game than there are stars in the sky. Seriously, you'll never run out of things to explore and try out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												This game introduced me to sandbox style games back in 2003 or so. It completely blew my mind, I was hooked. I have no idea how many hundreds of hours I played in on the original XBOX, later on my XBOX 360, and later still on the computer before even learning what Steam was, and now you can see I have over 80 hours clocked. There will always be a place in this gamer's heart for The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.That being said, if I might take off my nostalgia goggles for a moment... visually... it has not aged well. There's a mod for that however, which makes it gorgeous. The only other real drawback of it is the combat system which I really don't mind. Essentially you can level up a skill to 100, and the lowest a skill starts at is 5. That is basically the percentage chance of hitting. You could be fighting a Kwama worm thing that has a disease which renders it  immobile (I assume something that decreases its already pitiful strength), and you will have a VERY hard time hitting it if your skill is only 5-15. *MISS* *MISS* *MISS* *MISS* *HIT* *MISS* *MISS*, etc. Same goes with spells, except it's your chance of casting it. The bright side is however, each race has specific things they're good at, and you can select traits Major skills which are basically what you're really good at, and Minor skills which is what you're somewhat good at. Major skills get a boost of something like 25-30 points as I recall, while Minor ones get around 15 or so I think. There are also teachers all over Morrowind who can teach you various skills, and the lower level you are, the cheaper it is. So if you want to level up something that's only at 5-15, then do some training with a professional first. Get it up to a solid 25 or so at least before training on real enemies.One fascinating thing about this game however is when everything loads, that's how your world is. If you know where to look, you can get some SERIOUSLY good weapons/armour, though if you end up in the wrong place at too low a level, you can get SERIOUSLY messed up by a powerful enemy. Morrowind is quite unforgiving, but if you have the patience to get to know it well, it's very much worth the effort. There are many mods available that can help clean up the visuals, and who knows, there might be some which changes it so that you ALWAYS hit but the damage done is dependant on level, like Oblivion. Though as stated, personally, I don't mind the hit/miss system. The first character you make will just be a test run, I imagine. Getting a feel for the game, trying new things. If you've played Oblivion and/or Skyrim though, and already know all the skills, then that'll give you a great head start.Ultimately, if you don't mind lacking graphics and somewhat clunky combat systems (if you use skills you're not good at though; if you select your race/skills properly, you'll start with level 35-50 with your primary skills, then the combat is more fluid), then I can't recommend this game enough. If you DO mind lacking graphics but don't mind somewhat clunky combat systems, then I still recommend it if you know how to mod. If you mind both, do some research, see if you can mod it so that the combat system is more like Oblivion/Skyrim, and if so, have at it. This game is truly a gem. I believe it has less land than Oblivion or Skyrim, though there are DLC (which I believe is included) which adds an island and an independant city to which you can teleport, and I also recall that Morrowind has more caves/tombs than Oblivion or Skyrim so it likely has more underground terrain than the two of them.I hope I addressed the pros and cons equally here. Oh, one thing that's always bugged me is that magicka doesn't automatically regenerate. You have to drink potions or sleep... but I never bothered looking up a mod to fix this... namely because I found it fun to simply have a drink every time I drink a potion to replenish my magicka :P As for fatigue diminishing as you run, I LOOOOVE realism, so I was saddened when I found it missing in Oblivion, allowing you to jog in full armour anywhere you like, but a mod helped fix that problem so now I lose fatigue by sprinting in Oblivion as well :) Cheers, and hope you enjoy the game! God knows I did and still do!Oh yeah, as for armour customization, there's helmet, cuirass, left pauldron, right pauldron, left gauntlet, right gauntlet, greaves, and boots. You can LITERALLY wear 8 different types of armour if you so choose, which is an impossibility in Oblivion or Morrowind.My most common character choices are probably as follows:Race: Imperial (Sometimes Nord)Gender: Male (always)Hair: Dark Brown (either short or long)Major Skills:Long SwordDestructionSpeechcraftMarksmanMedium Armour (Sometimes I go with Light Armour instead, but NEVER Heavy Armour or Unarmoured. Yes, Unarmoured is an option)Minor SkillsAlchemyMercantileBlacksmithingBlockAlteration (Learn to FLY! Though sometimes I go with Mysticism so I can capture souls in gems more effectively)I can't rightly recall the exact number, but with this combination, my Long Sword starts around 50 give or take 5 levels I think. Speechcraft is way up there as well, and Marksman is not too bad at all. Speaking of which, are there crossbows in Oblivion or Skyrim? I don't recall, but they are most certainly in Morrowind, along with throwing knives, darts, and shurikins or whatever they're called. Ninja stars. Sounds kind of lame, but you find enchanted arrows/shurikins/knives somewhat commonly. Adds some magical damage, which helps.Alright this is basically the second time I'm ending this review, cheers! For those who read the whole damn thing, I hope it didn't bore you too much!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Be warned, this game is different from the next few games in the series. It doesn't hold your hand.Quest Logs? No, look in your notebook, sorted chronologically.Fast Travel? No way, you have to pay for a ride from city to city.Attacking enemies? This is a much more traditional RPG; each swing you take is a roll of a die to determine whether you hit or not. Mods can change this, but it unbalances the game.Bartering? I like this a lot, you can actually barter and raise the price you are selling for or decrease the price you are buying for and see whether merchants will accept your offer.Visuals? Mods work, but still nowhere near on par with Skyrim if that's what you were expecting.With a visual mod I couldn't get above 30fps, which is unusual since I have a GTX 970 and i5. This game feels like a more hardcore Skyrim, that is a bit aged. Still , it is definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Back on xbox it took me a few years to beat the game even with cheats.Buying on PC was probably the most nostaglic thing I did. I started out like I normally did with my old plays and then I came across the console. My trolly side just couldn't help it'self. I created a new play, maxed out my character so all my stats were full. I took an amazing 1 minute journey to Red Mountain from Seyda Neen. Into the depth where the great and powerful Dagoth Ur resided. He greeted me, claiming of course that I had come unprepared. Insulted that he would even suggest that I was lacking the required materials to defeat him I had used my own godly powers to prove him wrong. With Sunder, Wraithguard and Keening suddenly in my posession the Dagoth Ur was curtain that he was ready to take me on. When he thought that I was going to attack him with the one of the weapons I had insulted him by drawing the iron dagger that you get into Census and Excise office at the very beginning of the game. With two swift hits he decided that it be best to move along into the next room. He of course does the normal dialtic claiming that he is a god, but that did not sway me. with a few more hits I had managed to knock the weak god into the pool of lava. I continued to foil his master plan which he was none to happy about. After promptly gloating and leaving the room I was greeted with the final cut scene of the game. That was it I had won. I decided to humour myself some more. I took it upon myself to pay a visit to Caius in Balmora. Turns out I could still take part in all the main story quests that lead up to the magnificent display of my powers. I was quite pleased by this.10/10 would use console commands again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Played this game back when it came out and repeatedly for years.   This game's graphics didn't age well, but fact is this game is freaking amazing and so engrossing words don't do it justice.   It's so deep that you can sink litterally a year or two into it and still not see everything.   I remember playing this so much when it came out that I actually got a verbal warning at work to begin sleeping more and playing this less.   I'm actually amazed my wife stuck with me through how much this game was played.  There was the Morrowind years, the Oblivion years, the Fallout 3 years, Fallout NV years, ...  I do believe I have a problem.   Anyhow, I rate this game 1,000/10 for a few years well spent.   I do have to warn anyone who only likes current generation graphics in their RPG's; you will need to set the resolution a bit lower and "suffer" through the less than stallar graphics on this game.   If you do, I promise you one of the most amazing RPG experiences you can have on a PC.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29
												I played the heck out of Skyrim recently, and this one is so far my favorite in the series.-I personally loved the lack of fast travel, since it extends the gameplay and forces you to pay for traveling services, or go on foot and face the horror that is the disease spreading fauna of Vvardenfell.-I also loved the lack of quest markers. I feel like quest markers in Skyrim diminish the gameplay by straight up telling you were you need to go without forcing you to explore and find your own way, or ask for directions.-The class system and the very minor limitations to skills it imposes really appealed to me. As a Nord Barbarian, I have trouble casting spells; but that makes sense since…Well… I’m not a spell caster. If I wanted to be a spell casting Barbarian, I would have to pay a trainer enough for me to not fail my spell casting as much as I currently do, while in Skyrim, as someone with a thief build, I would have to buy the Flames spell from a shopkeeper and burn some random mudcrabs in order to become a master of destruction.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a classic Open World RPG. It allows you freedom to do what you wish, go where you choose, right after you complete the intro. It won't hold your hand, or coddle you though, so you have to play smartly... wander too far in the wrong direction and you may find yourself getting chomped or blown to bits by something way too powerful for you. The combat is kinda clunky, and in my opinion, one of the game's few weak points... but the depth you'll find in this game is something many games these days sorely lack. You could spend over 100 hours in this game and find half of what lies within it's world.  The characters, plot, and background lore are all carefully crafted, within a vast, rich wold.Play this game if you want a challenge, deep story, and love open world fantasy RPG's. Also, check out the mods and fan restoration projects that update this game's graphics to some surprisingly impressive levels for how old it is.

Skyrim cant compare to morrowind there almost a different genre, Could hardly call skyrim an rpg it's more like a action hack and slash, every character is jack of all trades. Old games like morrowind have complex gameplay mechanics that make you think and work things out for yourself. If you want a complex challenging rpg experience get morrowind.

content:
Posted: January 12
												This game is pretty old with old gameplay features but Morrowind is my favourite elder scrolls game thanks to it's wonderfull map and it's amazing main story. The world of morrowind is very mysterious and harsh, full of weird plants and creatures. Some caves are actually scary thanks to crazy sound effects and dark enviroments. There are strong, weird and sometimes funny special weapons and armor that you can find or earn by quests. You can only be in one guild at a time and this makes it feel more impactfull. You can still do enchantment and blacksmithing. There is also another feature wich I enjoy thats called spellcrafting. You can creat your own spells and make them crazy overpowered. You get levetating spells and jumping spells to get to places you can only get to if you can jump or levetate high enough. The weather is very cool, there are sandstorms, thunderstorms, clearweather and a day and night cycle. You are not allowed to rest in the cities and towns, you can only wait or you can go and sleep on your bed if you own one. If i'm correct you can also own houses in Morrowind. You still get to choos all races and you get to create your own class or choos from the premade classes. There are spears, staffs, longswords, shortswords, axes, hammers, bows, daggers and much more weapons.I feel the most involved in this world out of cyrodiil and skyrim.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												What I love about this game is the way you can make each playthrough unique. What makes this game different from for example Skyrim, is how you have to specialise in skills in order to succeed. In Skyrim you can get good at everything, which isn't exactly something that could realistically happen. What this does also is that unless you in Skyrim keep making new characters before you reach a high level (which is what I did) there's not really as much replayability in that game. More things I love about Morrowind is the lack of skaling (which made Skyrim too easy at high levels and Oblivion too hard) and the quests. The combat is a bit dated though, so it takes some getting used to. The dialogue is also very stupid. Every NPC basically acts like an information dispenser. Also, there's not much voice acting, which is both a pro and a con. You can have more dialogue, you don't have to listen to the same voice actors on different NPCs like later TES games, but because of no voice acting they don't have much personality, a problem which is exaggerated by the fact that 95% of all NPCs have THE SAME ♥♥♥♥ING LINES. Don't be fooled by all those Morrowind fanboys who think every Elder Scrolls game since this one is awful in comparison, and that you're a filthy casual if you disagree with them. All 3 are awesome games IMHO, and I have both good and bad things to say about them.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												There's just something about this game that really hit the sweet spot for Bethesda RPGs.  It's not cut down significantly like recent Fallout/Elder Scrolls games, but at the same time it's not so huge as to be an impossibly glitchy mess like Daggerfall.  This is probably my favorite Elder Scrolls game despite the hiccups.Keep in mind that this being an Elder Scrolls game, many of the cons can be patched away with mods.Pros:- Much greater amounts of unique text than modern Elder Scrolls games.- Spell-crafting system is pretty much unlimited and is really fun to mess around with.- Environment and wildlife is very strange; it's unusual to have a game with the entire ecosystem based on a harsh volcanic island, never mind the magic influence.- Plot is very interesting and can be as deep or shallow as you want to put the effort in to be.- You can choose to kill quest-vital NPCs, and the game will kindly tell you you've done so in case you wish to re-load. (Much nicer option than "NPC just won't die for some reason" in later games)Cons:- 2000s-era graphics and a lot of unvoiced lines, if these things matter to you.- Random townsfolk tend to not have anything interesting to say if they don't have a quest for you.- Dice-based combat is not for everyone, and makes combat really difficult before you get more Agility/Stamina/Magic Skill.- The name of the game is Morrowind, but only part of Morrowind is present. (Of course, the game would've probably taken 5 extra years if it was all there...)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25
												I'm not going to lie I was always put off by this game because of it's dated graphics and tabletop game fighting aspects, but one day I decided to get it. It blew my mind! It was so fun because it was actually brutal on you unlike Skyrim and Oblivion that could make you god sometimes. You want something? Go out and kill ten mudcrabs and collect fifteen mushrooms then you might get 50 gold. Those mudcrabs lower your health? Okay say goodbye to those gold coins so you can get yourself healed. By far the best Elder Scrolls game in my opinion. If you don't have it, get it. If you do have it, play it. If you are playing it right now, you know what you are doing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game is the best TES game ever made. It is beautiful... everything is perfect!I shall make a list of what this game has and the newer ones (Oblivion or Skyrim) does not:- It has the journal system which also works as a quest info provider. One book that you cannot live without. One book that is your life source. It records important events such as critical descisions made by the player and random events that could lead to large quests. Unlike Skyrim and Oblivion, we don't just follow arrows and markers on map or the one that floats on the objective of the quest and instead, it actually tells the player what to do and how to do it. Although puzzles are not a very big thing in TES but in Morrowind, to solve puzzles or riddles, you NEED to read the journal to figure out what to do. You will get lost without reading the Journal for certain quests and/or cannot find the quest's objective which really makes the game challenging and fun unlike in the other TES games, they are too casualized and all players need to do is follow the annoying marker that TELLS them what to do instead of the player FIGURING out what to do.-  It has the class system that does not exist in Skyrim, which is ridiculous for a TES game. Players need to plan what they need to do to instead of leveling up all skills freely and at the same speed even though Skyrim has those stupid Standing Stones which some of them boosts the leveling rate of skills. Players need to get proper gear for their proper class. Although Custom Class is available in Morrowind, players need to do the same. Even Oblivion and the old TES games, Arena and Daggerfall has it. Overally the class system is VERY important for a TES game.That is all I should say for now and I highly recommend any TES gamer to buy this game.[November 2016 edit] This game should win the Test of Time award!

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I've owned this since it released on XBOX.  This is truely a masterpiece which I have logged more than about 1000 hours in outside of steam with no problem.If you're one of the kiddies who think graphics are what define a game, go play Skyrim.  But if you're the one who loves and enjoys this classic of which is best in the series, this is for you.  This game is the most expansive in the series and contains a lot more to discover than in the next two games.  It is titled 'Game of the Year' but in my case I would scratch 'year' out of the logo and replace it with 'century'.This is one of the best RPG piece made ever in history, hands down.If it is your first time playing, you have to be patient as you progress because usually the beginning of the game is very slooooow, but it is worth it as you go.  There is lots of loot to collect and horde and many fun exploits (huehue) that spice the game up a bit.  There are lots of skills you will master in this game, just note that marksmanship is a bit finickey but you will eventually master it.

Once lost three days worth of progress because Skyrim softened me up with not one, but FOUR autosaves.>Leave starting town>Elf falls on head>"Scroll of Icarian Flight">Sure, why not>Nooooooooooooooooooooooope>Two uses later>Cool, SolstheimYou will cark it constantly. It looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥ (hey, it's an old game) It sounds like♥♥♥♥♥♥ In most games, you're the best entity in the world. In Morrowind, you're supposed to be a pretty good entity. You're not. You'll die to an unarmed farmer because you accidently stole a cup. Fight or flight? More like die or cliff racer tornado. This game is harder and more frustrating than dark souls ever was for me. Oh, and Sheogorath's voice acting makes him sound like an accountant.However,10/10, would get paralysed by a scrib againAnd the soundtrack is at a solid 11/5

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Have replayed Morrowind at least three times..absolutely my favourite game. It is an older game and the graphics are not up to par with many modern games (plus you can still get "stuck" in a rock or fall through the floor, necessitating a reload) but the brilliant story line, rich and detailed world of Morrowind itself, huge open world (so much to see and do, you can get lost and die out there, so save often), and masses of quests are the reason I come back to play. Your character can be crafted in any way you want...stealth, melee, ability to mend your own gear, magic (so many spells). The game can still crash but I found the steam version much better than having the game on disc (less crashy)...saving often is a must. There  is also no real hand holding, so paying attention to your world, increasing your skills and reading (the conversations, books, your journal) will point you in the right direction (maybe...I did die a few times before I got the hang of the game). Absolute must play for rpg fans.

content:
Posted: January 8
												To all those who complain about the hit and miss combat, mods exist that remove that system, to all those who whine about the graphics, mods exist that makes everything look much more smooth and less blocky, to all those who simply hate the game because of them reasons, you must either be too stupid to realise mods exist or just hating on it.This game has without a doubt the most immersive world in the elder scrolls with tons of quests littered all over the place so there's not one town wirthout, you can be having a simple stroll along caldera and would run into someone who wants you to locate a bandit for 'love's sake'. You can go literally anywhere at any point, kill any one at any point. Instead of skyrim and oblivion's main antagonist only showing up once or twice before the main fight you can actually to to the villain and see him as it should be in an open world game.The way guilds and factiosn worked were superb no other elder scroll game has done how you rank up and the realsim better, Without a doubt Oblivion has got better storylines, but when you first join a guild they won't send you out to gather these anceint relics kept hidden for centureis but as soon as you come along they get them *skyrim* you start off like in real life, they send you on stupid gathering tasks and petty adventures eventually they give you the good quests.The main quest is the best bethesda game. Sure not everyone like to be the 'God like nerevarine or dragonborn' but unlike skyrim you aren't given the prestigous title after a few quests you must earn it. You need to pursuade all the rival families to come together, rival tribes who've been batlling for years and after that they still won't believe you until you delve into azura's cavern and get an artifact to prove your title. And when everyone knew who you were you were loved by many but outcasted by many as well and that's why it's so good there's not just positives like in later titles there's both good and bad to go with it.Vampires were the ebst ever, istead of becoming more powerful when hungry you are weaker and require more to feed to get your strength up. Depending on who gave you vampirism you can hjoin differnt clans and do quests for them. This si why morrowind's world was truly immersive as everything had a lot of detail and no bethesda title has compared since and with each new title it looks slimmer and slimmer of getting another 'morrowind'.Now you may call em a nostalgia elitist or morrowind fanboy but if you actually get the game to your liking and play the game in depth you will realise how much greatness has been cut out of the newer titles and for what?

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												For those thinking about trying Morrowind because they only started the series with later titles, you may find that Morrowind generally does hold up, though I recommend installing Morrowind Overhaul. Combat is a bit awkward as it relies on dice rolls based on your skills to even land a hit, but there are combat mods out there if you don't like that.If you're okay with reading you will get the most out of it. It's not as heavy as Pillars of Eternity, but there are some parts where you'll need to read a couple paragraphs to understand what's going on. This was the age before the quest compass too, so you'll need to read about and look for clues as to where you're supposed to go. For example, 'look for the fangs of whats-his-face and walk South', and it's referring to a rock formation—or 'he lives at the East end of this road', and you actually have to look for that road and head East. Morrowind does, however, explore the lore and history of the world better than any of the other titles, and it's setting is the most mature and interesting—dealing with drug addiction, slavery, bigotry, religious extremism, and the sex trade in ways that other Elder Scrolls titles never fully got into.Click here for gameplay sample with Overhaul 3.0 installed.

												As someone has already remarked, this game requires patience. I haven't played much of Morrowind, but I have played tons of Oblivion and Skyrim. I love those games unreservedly. If you can pick-up Morrowind for $9.99, go for it. Otherwise, if you are new to these games, go with Oblivion or Skyrim first. I can go to Skyrim & play for an hour doing side quests, and have fun hunting vampires or bandits. 												Morrowind is likely the best game I've ever played; there are no boundries to what you can do, and even after twelve years there's still a huge community for the game. content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This is in my OPINION the best Elder Scrolls game made to date. There is so much to do in this game that it can be scary. There is even a unique item in a chest floating myriad meters above lava! That is a difficult item to get i tell ya. There are numerous factions in the game to join, more unique items then you can count on your hands and feet, a gargantuan number of dungoens to explore, as well as numerous fantastic mods available for this title. The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is and will be for a long time a game in my top 5 best games of all time list. If you are looking for a game to waste hours of your life on Morrowind is the game for you. Mind you it doesn't have the same feel as Skyrim or Oblivion and it is a game that is still selling copies on copies a decade after its release in 2002/2003, it is a fantastic title worth the buy.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Welcome, N'Wah to the wonderful and unique world of Morrowind, they've taken you from the Imperial City to Vvardenfell and now you're epic quest begins. When you first step off the boat onto the island you'll find streaching before you a game unlike Oblivion or Skyrim. This game does not hold your hand, this is not a "follow the quest arrow" simulator. This is not a game that scales everything and anything to your character. Morrowind is a game that will let you fail. You can make NPCs hate you so much they are prevoked into attacking you. This game is crafted for fans of role-playing games, not casual minded gamers.Who should buy this game? Fans intreged by the idea of a game that doesn't hold your hands. Fans of older RPGs. Fans who love depth, lore and replayablility.Who shouldn't buy this game? People who do not like RPGs, who REQUIRE modern "babby" mechanics like quick travel and regenerating health. People who can't find their way around their house let alone Vvardenfell.

												I remember playing this game back in 2004 or 2005. Morrowind was the first game I played on pc. Disregard hours since I just bought it on steam now. I probably have over 1000 hours played on it.Although a very dated game in terms of graphics, I dont recall a single rpg that was better than this game. Unlike oblvion and skyrims main quest line, you're not thrown into whats probably the end of the world. You're given the freedom of time so you can hone your skills until the day you have to fight Dagoth Ur. The mechanics in Morrowind were never that great even back then, but the story and atmosphere do make up for it. The characters in Morrwind make you feel like you're actually there. The antogonist of Morrwind(Dagoth Ur) also has alot more personality then Alduin or Dagon could ever have.Overall a great game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												I was excited when Morrowind finally came out on Steam. I've decided (obviously) to write a review.Let's be clear: This mod is not for you if you require on graphics or audio to enjoy a game. If you don't, read this review (NOTE THAT THERE WILL BE SPOILERS):Morrowind is a creatively-crafted, replayable game with great storylines and gameplay. You start out as a mere, useless outlander and work your way up. This game by no means gives you a title. No matter what quest you do, you must be powerful enough to become the next rank in a guild. The main quest doesn't hold your hand and is relatively harder compared to modern RPS. The combat, the skill system, it's great, yet not perfect. Trust me when I tell you that this game will not be over quick. I became Nerevarine of all tribes and Hortator of all houses... and I was pronounced a heretic and hated by many. If you don't enjoy this game... you're an n'wah!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Here is an honest review on the Elder Scrolls III Morrowind just a quick note that this is not nostalgia as I have played the elder scrolls games backwards.Music: Beautiful I honestly think that this is one of the best game soundtracks ever.Graphics: Not good but atleast its better then I or II.Enviroment: Small but with the constantly changing backgrounds it seems massive.Gameplay: some of the directions the NPCs give you are stupid and hard to follow (this game has no quest markers so if you're a fan of the elder scrolls IV or V that might come as a suprise) but some of the quests have a quirky sense of humour and are fun and rewarding the NPC's aren't static and are somewhat believable but many of the non main-quest related have copy-pasted lines which is kinda stupid but you can't blame the developers as at first the game was going to need as much memeory as next-gen consoles in three years time would struggle to cope with.overall I think thee elder scrolls III morrowind is a flawed masterpiece much like the original legend of zelda which made way many much better sequels.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is a great game, by far the best in the series. Unfortunately many people... dislike this game for its combat system. People say its some simple dice role system but no. They didnt think it through they just layed down a dislike for no reason. The combat system is incredibly complex and has nothing to do with dice rolling at all. (fine it has a little to do with dice rolling but not like a board game) There are so many variables used in one swipe of your sword u cant even count. You have to account for the length of the weapon, how long the weapon, if it hits the enemies hit box, how much strength u have and how long u hold down the mouse button. Is your level with the weapon type in question somewhat high. What is your lvl with the type of weapon. All these things with a press of a button and u dare to call it some simple dice roll. This by far is a great game. Its story is rich and fulfilling unlike oblivions stupid press this enter this clear this find this storyline. There is so many items u can find ull never get bored. For me 10000000000/5

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Welcome, N'Wah to the wonderful and unique world of Morrowind, they've taken you from the Imperial City to Vvardenfell and now you're epic quest begins. When you first step off the boat onto the island you'll find streaching before you a game unlike Oblivion or Skyrim. This game does not hold your hand, this is not a "follow the quest arrow" simulator. This is not a game that scales everything and anything to your character. Morrowind is a game that will let you fail. You can make NPCs hate you so much they are prevoked into attacking you. This game is crafted for fans of role-playing games, not casual minded gamers.Who should buy this game? Fans intreged by the idea of a game that doesn't hold your hands. Fans of older RPGs. Fans who love depth, lore and replayablility.Who shouldn't buy this game? People who do not like RPGs, who REQUIRE modern "babby" mechanics like quick travel and regenerating health. People who can't find their way around their house let alone Vvardenfell.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												I remember playing this game back in 2004 or 2005. Morrowind was the first game I played on pc. Disregard hours since I just bought it on steam now. I probably have over 1000 hours played on it.Although a very dated game in terms of graphics, I dont recall a single rpg that was better than this game. Unlike oblvion and skyrims main quest line, you're not thrown into whats probably the end of the world. You're given the freedom of time so you can hone your skills until the day you have to fight Dagoth Ur. The mechanics in Morrowind were never that great even back then, but the story and atmosphere do make up for it. The characters in Morrwind make you feel like you're actually there. The antogonist of Morrwind(Dagoth Ur) also has alot more personality then Alduin or Dagon could ever have.Overall a great game.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Morrowind is likely the best game I've ever played; there are no boundries to what you can do, and even after twelve years there's still a huge community for the game. Morrowind has a wicked art style that's the most original I've seen in an RPG, rather than Oblivion and Skyrim's cliches. Hell, even the bandits are uniquely, or at least semi-uniquely named. And for those who need a visual boost, there's the Morrowind Overhaul which makes the visuals more up to date and is infinitely customisable. The only real caveat is the bugs, oh the bugs! But those can easlily be fixed with Morrowind Code Patch and Morrowind Patch Project, two very important mods. 9.5/10

												I don't think I can express how much I love Morrowind, a lot of people could be turned off by the graphics, chance-to-hit combat system, or even the fact that dialogue is entirely in text format instead of voice acted. But if you suck it up, and roll with it, it'll be the most incredible RPG experience concievable.Morrowind not only excels in it's story, but in the intricacy of it's magic, the enchanting possibilities, character and enemy design, and the raw sense of living in a hostile province where everyone and everything hates you in both discrimination and prejudice.

content:

												A really good experience. The main story will actually keep you playing and entertained for a decent length of time depending on your skill level, and thats not to mention the numerous side quests. The land is diverse and interesting, with great creatures, peaceful or not, to provide a sense of life to the in-game world. The NPC's can give you bad or outright wrong directions and combat can be tedious at early levels, however the story and the ability to create things on your own such as spells, potions, and even homes more than make up for it. You can even be a werewolf or vampire yourself if you so desire, 8/10 would recommend to most people.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Recently I've come to the conclusion that Morrowind is my favorite Elder Scrolls game.  It was a true old-school RPG, of which only some elements survive in modern games.  There was no fast-travel, quest markers, or the ubiquitous crafting system that seems to be the same in every game nowadays.  There was only adventure! Morrowind is one of the biggest Elder Scrolls games by area and you can get lost for weeks in and out of game exploring all that countryside.  If you haven't played Morrowind, please do so! You'll be much better for the experience!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Where could I possibly begin?The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is perhaps the most notorious title within the Elder Scrolls franchise. While the age of Morrowind is more than evident in it's antiquated graphics it's sheer complexity and depth more than make up for any perceived shortcomings. Players seeking literally hundreds of hours of gameplay, exceptional modding capabilities and immense lands to explore will be more than satisfied by purchasing this game.Downfalls to new players would likely include limited fast travel options, at times overly complex skill selections during character creations and the graphics as mentioned before. Graphics and textures can all be improved with the use of 3rd party mods which have saturated the internet to this very day.Hardcore Elder Scroll and RPG fans will be sure to enjoy Morrowind.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2013
												Most of you have played or heard about Skyrim and Oblivion. What you may not know is that neither of those games could match the mature tone and sense of mystery and wonder that Morrowind mastered. It certainly doesn't looks as good as those games, and the combat isn't as sharp, but it outshines them both in challenge and in freedom. Morrowind does not hold your hand; it does not direct you to points of interest and give you tips on how to improve. It simply offers a massive world to you and lets you do with it as you wish. Of course the main story wil show you a path, but don't expect waypoints or fast travel; You want to progress? It's all on you. And it's all the more rewarding because of it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game is the breaking point when Bethesda escaped the pixels, and was born into 3d amazingness. Though the graphics take some getting used to, once you break the 10 hour point, everything becomes an adventure, and here's why.1. Unlike its previous games (aka Daggerfall, Arena), Morrowind has a clear storyline for you to follow and make branched desisions off of.2. Unlike Skyrim, you can kill whoever you want, without them bowing down and regening their health.3. Unlike Oblivion, you can gain blessings from any shrine, all you have to do is donate some coin. (has a time limit)4. The island of vvardenfell takes an hour or so to cross, but will take 30 hours due to the amount of caves, ancestral tombs, daedric ruins, dunmer fortresses, and much much more. 5. Unlike other games, you can choose from a plethora of guilds and groups to join.(a.k.a. House Hlaalu, House Redoran, House Telvanni, Blades, East Empire Company, Fighters Guild, Imperial Cult, Imperial Legion, Mages Guild, Thieves Guild, Ashlander Tribes, Morag Tong, and the tribunal temple. You can also join one of three vampire clans such as the Aundae Clan, the Berne Clan, and the Quarra Clan.)So with all included, this is a pretty amazing game that deserves the awards it got in its day, and still has talking points that Skyrim, Oblivion, Daggerfall, and Arena cannot compete with.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Absolutley fantastic game. My clocked hours is misleading, as i played most of this game during a car ride across the USA, btw. But to the point, this game is beautiful, in many ways. My favorite part is the environment and the atmosphere. Vvardenfel is such a strange place, you feel like your on another planet sometimes. Wandering through the ashlands, trudging through the swamps, or delving into a daedric ruin, there is tons of stuff to explore.  The dark elf culture is so vibrantly displayed, as is their reactions to other cultures. The customs and armors (especially bonemold, i love that stuff) are so peculiar and awesome, its like nothing you'll find elsewhere.  The sounds are great as well. The soundtrack fits perfectly with the game, however it is only 30min long, and the repitition gets a wee bit annoying sometimes.  The thing that i love the most about it is its complexity. This is not an easy game, and you need some knowledge to get through, unlike Skyrim, which was dumbed down for all the console CoD fans (still a great game tho). The leveling system works very well, the combat system does not. Using melee weapons is okay, but magic is freaking impossible. The graphics on this game are amazing, especially for 2002. They impress me even today. All in all, this is a great game. Highly reccomend it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Before I'd begin, I'd like to say the only Elder Scrolls game I have played prior to this is Skyrim, which I have played since release. I had always been interested in the other games if nothing more then for lore.Morrowind is an interesting game, from my perspective. Coming directly into this after Skyrim, it's a much different experience. I bought the Game of the Year edition to get the full experience, as I had been told this was probably the best Elder Scrolls game. I booted it up, and started playing.The first thing I noticed is... Morrowind is NOT too kind to new players. You're thrown into the world with little to no direction other then go here and deliver a package. Which is not entirely a bad thing. Morrowind gives a sort of feeling of freedom, and pushes you to discover how things work on your own. While in Skyrim, there WAS a sort of feeling of "freedom", but if you did not do the main quest immedietally, or at least go into it, quite a few things were sealed off, like shouts and dragons. And the main quest always sort of felt like it was looming in the background and that I was screwing up by not playing it. Morrowind however, presented more of a... "Take your time to get to know the place" feel. How I can describe it from what I've played thus far? It's a lot like Dungeons and Dragons. You're thrown in, you pick your race, what you're good with, and your special skill/sign. Then you go into a world, get told your main quest... And then you do whatever you feel is right at the time. What REALLY gives it the DnD type feel to me is probably the dialog, which is fairly unique in feel.I'll probably come back to redo this review once I get a few more hours in, or at least enough knowlege of how to play the game correctly. This is my first impression review from someone who never played Morrowind. Thank you for taking the time to read my review.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I've noticed that the reviews for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim tend to be about why that game is the best Elder Scrolls game and the others are terrible in comparison. I really enjoy all three of them (sorry, Arena and Daggerfall, you're just not very enjoyable by today's standards), so I figured I'll give reviews for each that focus on what's unique about each of them, and what kind of players that will appeal to. Morrowind has easily the most vocal proponents of any of the three. They are very passionate about it, and insist that the latter two were disappointments. There's a pretty simple reason for that. It's easily the most chaotic of the three. What I mean by that is that you have far and away the most freedom and choices with Morrowind, but also easily the biggest negatives of the three games. Players who love chaos in their games tend to be the most vocal about what they want, so that's why you see Morrowind fans being the most passionate.For the positives of Morrowind, the aforementioned freedom is the biggest one. It doesn't funnel you into rapidly progressing through the main questline right away, and in fact discourages it through tying a need for certain levels in different skills to the ability to even receive many of the main quests. You are also free to decide which factions appeal to you, based on which skills you emphasize. Unlike Oblivion and Skyrim, you can't decide to progress all the way through the questlines of every faction. Several of them are incompatible with each other, so deciding which factions suit your playstyle is up to you. Morrowind also has the largest selection of spell types, armor types, weapon types, and even skill types (you can cast spells to blind enemies, use spears as your main weapon, and have all sorts of options not available in Oblivion and Skyrim). Another big draw is a beautiful soundtrack that really puts you in the game emotionally. The enchanted items also tend to be much cooler and more abundant than in later games. The recall and mark spells also provide a nice way to teleport out of danger or when you are overburdened. The environment is pretty cool, with swamps, ash storms, green plains, volcanoes and lava, and all sorts of other different types of scenery and climate.For the negatives of Morrowind, you have to be prepared to be much more frustrated with this game than you will with Oblivion or Skyrim. Many areas don't scale to your level, and so sometimes your freedom can be deceptive, as you can't realistically go to many parts of the island for a large chunk of the game without dying almost immediately. There is no fast travel to locations you've already visited, so you waste a lot of time walking the same roads over and over, or constantly paying for transportation between cities. The combat, magicka, and stealth dynamics are also much worse than in later games. Your magicka doesn't replenish on its own, so you have to either sleep, take potions, or wait far away from civilization (you can't use the wait function within a large radius of every town or city). Sneaking is a lot more difficult in this game, but less nuanced. A large portion of it is entirely luck based, regardless of how high your sneak skill is. The barter system is also fairly frustrating, with items costing exorbitant sums while merchants only have a small pool of gold to buy things with from you, so it takes forever to build up the large sums needed for many items.And now, let's talk about the biggest negative of the game, which also happens to be the biggest negative in any of the games: the combat system is terrible. Instead of your weapon skill determining how much damage you do, it determines (although somewhat loosely) whether or not your attacks connect. And even then, they will frequently miss. So you'll stand right in front of an enemy, swinging your weapon over and over, and very few of them will connect. Your fatigue affects it as well. A similar thing goes for spells, where every spell has a rather large chance of failing to cast, while still draining your magicka. It's the single dumbest decision Bethesda made with any of the Elder Scrolls games.This game is definitely worth it, although if you first play it after playing Oblivion or Skyrim, you have to change your expectations, because it is a lot less polished or refined than those two. If you love chaos/anarchy in your games, this will be your favorite. If not, it's still a great game to play, it just takes a lot of getting used to.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Definitely one of, if not the best, Elder Scrolls games. Morrowind's combination of amazing music, immersive story, and fantastic RPG elements definitely make it one of the best games I've ever played. Now since it's the year 2014, the graphics for Morrowind are considerably... laughable, but that's not reason to turn down this amazing game. If you're like me, and you play games mainly for the story, then give Morrowind a shot. It combines the use of directional sense and pen & paper when it comes to quests. You are not given a map, nor quest markers, so you are required to read the quest's objectives and find the goal yourself. I find that writing down locations and drawing a map are extremely useful when venturing out into the land of Morrowind, so you should give that a try too. The game heavily relies on character skills, attributes, and automatic dice rolls when it comes to just about everything. Combat is all about how likely you are to hit your enemies with your current abilities and attributes, rather than you making contact with your weapon. I've been in a number of frustrating situations where I flail my sword against my enemies, only to have me character miss with every swing. However, this is how things worked with table top games such as D&D, and it's nice to see it transitioned to video games, even if it was just the one of the few times. A combination of soothing music to lift the hearts of many adventurers, and intense gameplay, make Morrowind a definite must-play for all RPG fans.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												This game may perhaps be my favorite of all. Morrowind has an endlessly explorable world, is very believable, and very immersive. It's story is captivating, and I would say far more in that regard than its successors, The Elder Scrolls IV and V, Oblivion and Skyrim. Now, it may have some dated combat and some slightly dated graphics, but if you play intelligently the combat shouldn't be a real issue, and the graphics really aren't too terrible, aside from perhaps the low view-distance. I would highly reccomend this game.

												Don't let my "hours played" fool you, I played this game before steam was a thing. My first RPG, and my favorite one to this day. The stealth system wasn't as workable as the newer ones, but you could say it was more realistic. Once enemies are on alert, they will find you, it's only a matter of time. Decided to go wandering the northern parts of vvardenfall before you even found your first enchanted weapon? Probly gonna have a bad time. number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
												Great game, annoying as all hell fanbase. I first came into the Elder Scrolls series with Oblivion and was absolutely absorbed into Skyrim once the game finally released. Now considering myself a die-hard fan of the Elder Scrolls, I took to the internet and found that many considered Oblivion and Skyrim to both be dumbed-down knockoffs of the series' true crowning achievement: Morrowind. I was intrigued by the idea that what had become my favorite game series was spawned from what was apparently a flawless masterpiece that I had yet to experience, so I picked the game up on Steam immediately. I was then treated to appalling graphics with a draw distance shorter than I can throw a football (which isn't far), characters who walked around like they'd just completed a cycling tour of Europe, and fetch quests galore (Gathering mushrooms for the Mages Guild, anyone?). I then forgot about the game for several months until the ESO update announcement put it back into my consciousness. I decided that I owed it to myself to figure out what it was that made people adore this game so much and started a new playthrough. This time, I felt that I was finally seeing the game's charm. Quests without objective markers meant that some modicum of mental effort was actually required to complete them, giving a real sense of weight and accomplishment to even the most simple of tasks. The story and lore were rich and layered, not shying away from unsavory topics like slavery, drug abuse, and religious persecution. The combat, while lacking the fun and dynamic feeling of subsequent entries in the series, gave a real sense of progression as levelling up enabled my character to actually hit enemies and successfully cast what spells that had once felt far out of my depth. I don't have too many hours into the game just yet, but I've explored a great deal of the map and progressed into the main story and can't wait to play for many hours more. I would recommend this game to any Elder Scrolls fan with the caveat that they'll have to look past the game's lackluster, outdated exterior to find the truly excellent experience within. Despite what its most rabid fans will tell you, this game is by no means perfect. However, it is a blast to sink your teeth into and definitely worth your time.

content:
Posted: January 9
												im not good at writing  reveiws but if you need the recipe to a pavlova ingredients: 6 (59g) eggs, separated 1 1/4 cups (270g) caster sugar 2 teaspoons cornflour 1 teaspoon white vinegar 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract 300ml thickened cream 2 tablespoons icing sugar mixture, sifted Finely shredded rind and juice of 2 limes 2 Lady finger bananas, thinly sliced diagonally 3 golden kiwifruit, peeled, thinly sliced 2 starfruit, thinly sliced Pulp of 2-3 passionfruit some of these are optionalmethod: STEP 1: Preheat oven to 120°C. Line an oven tray with foil. Brush with melted butter and dust with cornflour, shaking off excess. Mark a 24cm-diameter circle on foil.STEP 2: Use an electric mixer to whisk egg whites in a clean dry bowl until soft peaks form. Gradually add sugar, 1 tablespoon at a time, beating well after each addition, until meringue is thick and glossy and sugar dissolved. Rub a little meringue between fingers. If still "gritty" with sugar, continue to whisk until sugar dissolves. Add cornflour, vinegar and vanilla and whisk until just combined. Spoon meringue onto the foil, using the marked circle as a guide. Smooth sides and top of pavlova. Use a small spatula to forms little peaks around edge of pavlova. Bake in oven for 11/2 hours or until pavlova is dry to the touch. Turn off oven. Leave pavlova in oven with the door ajar to cool completely. When completely cold, transfer to serving plate or store in an airtight container until required.STEP 3: Use an electric mixer to whisk the cream and icing sugar in a medium bowl until firm peaks form. Spoon cream onto the top of pavlova. Pour lime juice into a ceramic or glass bowl. Add banana slices and toss to coat with juice. Drain. Decorate pavlova with banana, kiwifruit, starfruit, passionfruit and lime rind. now you know how to make a pavlova.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2013
												Featuring graphics that were cutting edge in its day, Morrowind represented a return to the open world style of previous Elder Scrolls games like Daggerfall and Arena after two lackluster attempts by Bethesda to use the world in a thoroughly linear style, Battlespire and Redguard. While the look of the game was fantastic when it was released, Morrowind has the smallest game world of a true Elder Scrolls game and it takes some thorough exploring just to get a handle on the unique nature of this region in Tamriel and the grave threat facing its inhabitants. There's a wide variety of quests you can complete and a solid variety of guilds to consider joining, but Morrowind can be somewhat difficult to find entertaining these days due to the age of its graphics engine and the more than minor detail that almost no characters are voiced. Neither is the fault of Bethesda when you consider the limitations of CD-ROMs and hard drives of its time. I'll definitely say Morrowind was a step in the right direction for the Elder Scrolls series, but sadly no where near the resounding success that Skyrim would be a decade later. 2 1/2 stars out of 4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												A good game, but not without flaws. The music, world, and plot are all top-notch. The only problem is the game itself is well, a bit of a chore. The combat, frankly, is quite awful, as it lacks both the tactical appeal of a top-up party based western RPG like Baldur's Gate or Dragon Age and the fluid action gameplay of a proper action-RPG like Skyrim. You just click repeatedly and hope you hit. Like all Elder Scrolls games, you level up what you use, but the way Morrowind does it can lead to some mildly ridiculous metagaming. (eg: Oh dear, I'd better avoid jumping for the rest of the level or my Acrobatics stat will get ahead of my Short Blades stat.) I would prefer Morrowind's multiple attributes such as strength, speed, intelligence, and willpower to Skyrim's three, health, stanima, and magica, if the sole purpose in every stat in Morrowind was not to raise your health, stanima, or magica, or to raise damage/resistance, which Skyrim did via skills and perks. For example, your character's dialogue isn't any different if he's got an Intelligence of 60 or 30, so why bother keeping count? In Dragon Age, you got unique dialoge options based on your cunning stat, and low intelligence characters in Neverwinter Nights talked reel dum liek thiz. If the only purpose of Intelligence is to get more magica, then honestly, they were streamlining, not dumbing down when they got rid of it in favor of the Magica stat directly. While exploration is much touted, enemies aren't leveled, and as such, may be ridiculously easy or hard depending on the area. This is, of course, more realistic than enemies always being just tough enough for you, and wouldn't be a problem if leveling didn't feel like such a damned grind. To be brutally honest, there are times it feels like a MMO in a vacant world. Other things touted as "perks" by Morrowind afficianados may be tinted a bit by nostalgia as well, I suspect. For example, some people decry that gauntlets come as sets in Oblivion and Skyrim, but to be honest, it feels a bit stupid when a store has three left steel gauntlets and no right ones for sale. Does it cater to one armed men or something? I won't criticize the game based on technological inferiority to more modern games because doing so would be grossly unfair and with all Elder Scrolls games, it's fun enough to♥♥♥♥♥♥around in. However, in all honesty, I reccomend the game more for the fact that it's required to run the upcoming Skywind mod for Skyrim which modernizes the graphics and gameplay while maintaining Morrowind's unique aesthetic and story than the game in its own right. Morrowind is a dated masterpiece, a labor of love to be sure, but if anyone tries to tell you that it is a perfect game, and that more modern games are for stupid illiterate mouth-breathing console peasants, you should gently inform them that it is that sort of attitude that makes Lord Vivec cry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Epic  game with tons of freedom. Probably the truest RPG Bethesda has ever made. If you can get a handle on the somewhat challenging character growth system, enjoy a game with older graphics, and put up with a few odd bugs, it's one of the better entries into the TES series. Main questline good and quite lengthy (30+ hours). With plenty of factions to join and interesting side quests it will keep you busy for weeks or even months. If you can, get the GOTY edition; Tribunal and Bloodmoon are both fantastic and Skyrim's Dragonborn DLC will make a lot more sense. Only minor complaints would have to be 1) shields auto-block which makes combat feel a lot less skillful; 2) it's impossible to retrieve arrows from the environment which makes arrows a scarce commodity. I was afraid to use my good arrows for basically the entire game because of this; 3) fast travel is only from city to city, which means there is a lot of walking involved. Not necessarily a horrible thing, because there are some cool random NPC encounters along roads, but it does slow the game's pace down a bit and it would be nice to be able to fast travel from the map screen like you can in Oblivion and Skyrim. Overall though it's a great game, especially if you're a TES fan. 9.5/10
