number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Disclaimer: I have only played the three most-recent Elder Scrolls games: Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim. I am sadly ignorant on the quality of the earlier installments.---Morrowind is my favorite modern Elder Scrolls game. Period.There are some downsides. Graphically, Morrowind is increasingly dated. It comes from an unfortunately time (early 2000's) in history where full 3D games tried to portray realism without the resources to do so convincingly. Environments are fairly low res. As far as NPCs are concerned, they're not uncanny valley. They're just kind of crappy-looking, and lack the individual daily schedules that NPCs have in later games. Here, they wander within a short range, but people who you encounter outside will forever be standing outside, never to even set foot in their homes. Mechanically, the game can be rough around the edges. In Oblivion and Skyrim, furthering one's combat skill means increased damage. Starting out in Morrowind, low sword skill means you're unlikely to even hit your target when you swing. It's a steep curve, to be sure, and representative of how the game approaches skills and leveling up. Additionally, the quest log -- the game's system for tracking general learned information and info pertaining to specific active or inactive quests -- is unorganized and difficult to work with. It is barely a step above remembering what you're actively doing, and trying not to take up any other tasks until it is completed.So what really separates Morrowind from later Elder Scrolls games?The world is large and real. This isn't scandanavia or medieval England. This is a world unlike any other, with giant mushrooms and huge insects. It is interesting, unique, and worth exploring. And explore you will, because there is no fast-travel. The best form of transportation are via specific routes between certain cities -- boats, Mages Guild teleportation, large land beasts, etc. Anything else, be it going to off-the-beaten-path settlements, or simply getting to one of those hub towns, requires hoofing it. It adds a staggering degree of realism that later games stripped away. The world isn't actually larger, but the game presents itself that way. There are more guilds and organizations. More missions for those guilds. More cities, towns, and people. There's an openness to it because the cities aren't walled in, a separate level from the outside. The player also has a degree of agency that hasn't existed in Elder Scrolls games since. The degree of skill customization is extensive: more kinds of weaponry to specialize in, more kinds of armor, more branches of magic and spells within those branches. The player also has a lot more freedom to affect the world in permanent ways. You actions in one guild will affect other guilds. Everyone can be killed, including quest givers and NPCs integral to the main story. The world is yours to take. Oblivion introduced the concept of player-bought houses. No such game-sanctioned method exists in Morrowind. Instead, acquiring a house involves using your freedom. You could find a house that appears abandoned and move in, or you could find a nice house, murder the occupant, dispose of their body, and make it yours. There aren't items that are free to take and items that constitute stealing. There's just items, and you can steal them.The NPCs that inhabit Morrowind offer vastly more variety. With brief exceptions, the game has no voice acting. All dialogue is simply textual, and different personalities can be revealed through the text of their dialogue. Every NPC doesn't have the same voice, creating the impression of world populated by artificial clones. This fact alone almost certainly influenced the rest of the game, because it meant that something as simple as adding another Thieves Guild quest didn't involve more voice and audio work.This, in a way, describes the game as a whole. It's clear that, when the game was being developed, there was a lot more freedom to add content and run wild when developing the game. It bleeds into almost every aspect of the game. It's not as smooth, nor as pretty, as later installments, but it's a world worth exploring,

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												My first Elder Scrolls game was the fourth of its triology, Elder Scrolls Oblivion. To make long journey/story short, it was mind blowing experience. After reading people's opinions about it's predesor, Morrowind, I have decided on one golden midsummer afternoon to give it a go. And boy was I in for a journey. My first thought going in to the game "looks boring!" and my first thought fighting some monsters "what the ====?". But I did not let those two things stop me from playing. I kept at it and believed that I would have an unbelievable experience. and Boy did I get it. I spent nearly my whole half of the summer playing Morrowind! Each day felt like a dream (in a fantasticaly good way). Walking outside was different after I have played the game because I was so "high" from the game! The details.. my God! The quests were so fun and the traveling was realistic. Items were actually fun to collect rather than just ignoring every thing you came by. I loved that the items that were placed on the environment were actually part of the environment! It was as if you could take out a pot in a painting and put it back without breaking the "morrowind" immersion! (unlike achoo Skyrim). Give this one a go. I loved playing it and I just started playing once more. But just so you know, the game is not so social. If you are naturally a quiet and a smart individual, you will like this game. If you love games you will like this game once you have given it a chance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												For me, Morrowind is one of the most influential RPGs of all time. With hundreds of hours into Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim, Morrowind edges the other two out for the strongest title of the series. The art and world design is, to this day, astounding. From the moment stepping of the boat in Seyda Neen, all the way to the final confrontation on Red Mountain is filled with memorable vistas of the strange, alien land of Vvardenfell. Giant mushroom towers, strange animals and monsters, and mysterious Dwemer ruins show  the creativity that went into this game simply cannot be understated, especially compared with its rather bland successor. A lot of people (players who started with ES IV or V) find that the mechanics and graphics of Morrowind are dated and thus they can't get into the game. I urge anyone to give the game a shot. There is definitely a learning curve, but you'll get past it, I promise. As for the graphics, look up the fan-made Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul, and prepare to be amazed.The game is not without its faults. Combat is somewhat clunky, and many of the sidequests (there are probably hundreds) are uninspired. That said, the main quest is very compelling. This, combined with the incredibly rich world that Bethesda has created, make this a very easy game to recommend.

												Morrowind is the best Elder Scrolls title developed. Coming off of Oblivion and Skyrim, Morrowind is a lot more difficult and the combat system is a little off, but the atmosphere, guilds, story, lore etc. more than make up for that. My favorite aspect of Morrowind is that you start with nothing, and finish with everything; no game reinforces such an accomplished feeling as Morrowind does. Something that deeply improves the experience is the Morrowind Overhaul by Ornitocopter, this mod-pack modernizes the graphics and user interface while fixing bugs and retaining the original Morrowind feel. I greatly recommend this title to anyone who has love for a complicated albeit very rewarding and unexpected RPG experience.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2011
												Outlander. Travel east, to Morrowind. The province of Vvardenfell awaits, full of its enigmatic people, the Dunmer (aka Dark Elves), from the Great Houses and the Temple to the nomadic Ashlander Clans, Vvardenfell has much to offer a traveller to its shores. Solstheim, a harsh unforgiving island to the north and Mournhold, capital of Morrowind. There are many things waiting to be discovered. Find out the truth behind ALMSIVI and the Sixth House.Now dated graphically, but a classic RPG unparalled in scope and size by its more mordern cousins, Oblivion and Skyrim. Not for those who hate reading, however, as there is lots of text dialogue throughout the game. Extremely immersive gameplay, although minor quests can get tedious (as there can be a lot of "courier" work). Many hours of gameplay and excellent replay value.

												Now, even though I am recommending this. I am only recommending it to people who don't mind playing an older, slightly aged and sometimes frustrating game, to get to the really good centre of it. Now, I first played this on the original xbox, and as a younger kid I didn't know what to think. I had never played a game like this before and I was interested to see what this was like. My first quarrel was the game giving directions as I was young and couldn't follow them very well.When I play this game now, I am obviously better with the directions, and I can look past the poor combat sysdtem where you can swing your blade 50 times at a rat and be killed by the bloody thing. Now it might sound like I hate this game, but I do have a level of respect for it. It is not my favourite elder scrolls game, but I do enjoy it and have a respect for how iot shaped the future of elder scrolls games we see today. So if you don't mind a game with slightly aged graphics (Get the MGSO mod, trust me), a wonky combat system, and a few weird directions to the back♥♥♥♥♥end of nowhere then buy this, it's 20 bucks and a good deal at that for 100+ hours of adventure. Plus the soundtrack is figgin awesome :D.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												You're going to feel like a pathetic peasant when you start out: not even capable of handling a single rat or mudcrab, let alone a bandit cave, or worse yet a dungeon full of daedra. The trick is to do small jobs and make enough coin from the Mages' and Fighters' guilds to pay trainers and level up a bit. By endgame, you should feel like the god you're destined to be.Main story is a little over-glorified. Yea, sure, you're supposed to be a potential reincarnation of some really important guy. But your nemesis is the Daedric Prince of Disease? I mean, I guess curing cancer is a pretty big deal, but it hardly makes for a thrilling and exciting plot. Oblivion Gates? Dragons? If only.That's why you're getting the GotY edition, though! This game instantly becomes worth when you have the chance to do battle against one of the three Tribunal gods of Vvardenfell, or travel to a tundra island to stop the Daedric Prince of "The Hunt" himself from unleashing a massive werewolf army!10/10 First real great Elder Scrolls game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												This game is beyond incredible.I originally bought Morrowind because I wanted to see why so many people were saying how much better it was than Skyrim. I thought it would be interesting to play, since it came out such a long time ago, but I never expected to play it for more than a few hours. And I know a lot of people are in the same position as I was back then. 90 hours later, I now truly know why this game is so amazing. Apart from a few things (combat mechanics, skill system and AI), everything has been polished to the highest degree and every little detail feels on point.The first thing you'll notice is that the game is quite intimidating. I remember trying to kill a bandit in a cave not far from Seyda Neen (the starting town), only to find out I couldn't even hit him once. I was forced to walk from town to town, trying to avoid every enemy on the way. And when I finally arrived in Balmora, where my trusty journal was guiding me, I was relieved so much that I spent an hour walking from house to house, talking to anyone I could (even though everyone hated me because I was foreign). For the first 20 hours, I was scared of any mission that involved killing people, simply because I knew I wouldn't be able to kill anyone. Even after 90 hours, I've yet to hit a town guard, because the game taught me not to.To be truly honest, for the first 20 hours or so, I couldn't understand why everyone liked this game so much. I found it quite frustrating and unsatisfying, but something kept me playing it. And after 20 hour mark, it started to shine. I figured out how to attack properly, I figured out how to lose as little health as possible, I started getting people to like me, I finally started to get paid in cash by rich people, I could finally buy the good set of armour I saw at the blacksmith and I could finally venture out into the wilderness, knowing that not many things would stand in my way.And after the 35-40 hour mark, Morrowind turns into the most satisfying game you'll ever play. Nothing feels like a chore anymore, the main quest starts to show all of its greatness and even the most mundane activities become rewarding. Unlike Skyrim, where you feel like an almighty warrior from moment one, Morrowind makes you feel like everything you achieved is a result of your own hard work. And that's why this game is so special. I had no problem playing it for 90 hours, and I've only completed about 50% of the quests I picked up. There's easily more than 100 hours of things I haven't yet done in my first playthrough, and it would take at least two more playthroughs to experience everything this game has to offer.The most crazy thing however, is the fact that all of this was made in 2002, almost 10 years before Skyrim was released. In some areas, Morrowind is miles ahead of Skyrim. And although it lacks polish elsewhere, that can mostly be attributed to technical limitations of the time. Yes, the combat in Skyrim is much more interesting and dynamic, the same goes for the skill system and the AI. But when it comes to meaningful storytelling, actual player progression and everything that matters most in an RPG, Morrowind succeeds like no other game out there.Morrowind's other strong points:- The immersive journal system: your character writes everything down in a little book which you constantly look into for information on your quest objectives. There are no quest markers either, which makes questing much more fun and diverse. You actually ask people for directions etc., unlike Skyrim or Oblivion where your character magically knows exactly which house to go into and which drawer of which cupboard to look into.- No instant fast-travelling everywhere: you can only fast-travel between cities and villages via silt strider or boat, otherwise you will have to walk. Surprisingly, this adds so much depth to every quest, because it actually feels like your character travelled many miles to get to where he is, as opposed to Skyrim and Oblivion where some quests can be completed in a minute and thus feel meaningless. Also surprisingly, this system rarely feels annoying.- Better magic system: there's a much wider variety of spells to make or buy, which allows the player to use the exact spell he wants to. - Better enemy balancing: Alduin is a piece of cake in Skyrim and can be pretty much killed by anyone. I tried killing Vivec at level 20 with daedric armour... I was dead in 3 seconds. This is just one example, but overall the game feels better balanced than Skyrim or Oblivion.- More attention dedicated to decision making: people in Morrowind have extremely different opinions about you, and this shows when it comes to obtaining information or making decisions in quests. You will have to bribe people who don't like you in order to obtain some information, sometimes just saying something offensive will get you killed.- Much, much more...Morrowind's weaknesses:- The combat system: beware of anyone who has a paralyze weapon. There's a high chance you won't get a chance to even hit them, even though you would kill them in one hit. Falling to the ground while in combat is also quite annoying. An unarmed enemy (like a wild Solstheim Nord) can punch you for a minute before you have the chance to hit him back, just because he can punch you to the ground (even though it would take him 50 hits to kill you and you're wearing daedric armour). It takes a while to get used to.- The god awful AI: still haven't gotten used to it (very minor problem).- Choosing skills: in Morrowind, you can only level up by practicing your major skills, which you pick at the very beginning. The game forces you to make this decision, even though you might not know what you're actually picking and regret your decision afterwards (minor problem).- Limitations when progressing through guild ranks: sometimes you won't be able to obtain the next quest in your guild because you haven't levelled up a specific skill, preventing you from progressing through the questline. It's a bit annoying (extremely minor problem).If you're interested in this game, buy it now. Just be patient and it will soon become one of your favourites. It is an absolute masterpiece.

Also, modding is easily accesible to make the aspects of the games that are dated more bareable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												For me, Morrowind is one of the most influential RPGs of all time. With hundreds of hours into Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim, Morrowind edges the other two out for the strongest title of the series. The art and world design is, to this day, astounding. From the moment stepping of the boat in Seyda Neen, all the way to the final confrontation on Red Mountain is filled with memorable vistas of the strange, alien land of Vvardenfell. Giant mushroom towers, strange animals and monsters, and mysterious Dwemer ruins show  the creativity that went into this game simply cannot be understated, especially compared with its rather bland successor. A lot of people (players who started with ES IV or V) find that the mechanics and graphics of Morrowind are dated and thus they can't get into the game. I urge anyone to give the game a shot. There is definitely a learning curve, but you'll get past it, I promise. As for the graphics, look up the fan-made Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul, and prepare to be amazed.The game is not without its faults. Combat is somewhat clunky, and many of the sidequests (there are probably hundreds) are uninspired. That said, the main quest is very compelling. This, combined with the incredibly rich world that Bethesda has created, make this a very easy game to recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game is the♥♥♥♥♥♥man, half of my childhood right here. Yes, this review is based on nostalgia a bit, but that's okay, since I'd enjoy the game without nostalgia a lot as wellMorrowind is an open world fantasy rpg adventure kind of thing, like skyrim. It's a game in which I never had any clue of what to do, but simply enjoyed screwing around. You can choose your own adventure; do you want to do missions? Be a thief and ♥♥♥♥ the system? Be a mage and kill everyone? In Morrowind it's fairly difficult to find out what to do, to be honest. I've found myself wandering around a whole lot, never following the questline due to difficulty (and my lack of english skills back when I was 9, when I mostly played this) so I went the easy way and cheated my way to the top. I became a mage that could kill literally the entire world in 1 spell (quite boring) but then decided to start over and become a skilled marksman and steal whatever I could, trying not to get caught but when I did, I killed the whole town.Morrowind is an extremely unforgiving game; you steal a loaf of bread and everyone in the world tries to kill you. It stimulates good behaviour but doesn't prevent you from breaking the rules. Morrowind is one of the best games I've ever played, still up to today, and it will permanently have a spot in my childhood memories. tl;dr: would recommend, 8/10 due to graphics and engine limitations

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I've heard a lot of people rant and rave about this game. Personally, I started the Elder Scrolls series at Oblivion and then went to Skyrim. I tried Morrowind after that and just couldn't get into it. Then, I got into a situation with work where I had a lot of time where I couldn't be with any of my friends when I got any time off. Fortunately, I had my PC with me. That's when I tried to just grind out Morrowind--mostly for the lore. I'm glad I did. Once I got past the first five levels or so, the game became exponentially more enjoyable. On all of my other start ups (I think there were three.), I just couldn't get too far because I would get so frustrated with how bad the combat was and how long it took to get from place to place. If you can get a few levels in and get lucky on finding some decent gear early on, I guarantee you that you'll start to enjoy this game more. If you are hungry for a little Elder Scrolls lore and haven't ever taken the time to try out Morrowind, that is my advice to you. Grind through the first few levels. It gets better.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Disclaimer: I have only played the three most-recent Elder Scrolls games: Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim. I am sadly ignorant on the quality of the earlier installments.---Morrowind is my favorite modern Elder Scrolls game. Period.There are some downsides. Graphically, Morrowind is increasingly dated. It comes from an unfortunately time (early 2000's) in history where full 3D games tried to portray realism without the resources to do so convincingly. Environments are fairly low res. As far as NPCs are concerned, they're not uncanny valley. They're just kind of crappy-looking, and lack the individual daily schedules that NPCs have in later games. Here, they wander within a short range, but people who you encounter outside will forever be standing outside, never to even set foot in their homes. Mechanically, the game can be rough around the edges. In Oblivion and Skyrim, furthering one's combat skill means increased damage. Starting out in Morrowind, low sword skill means you're unlikely to even hit your target when you swing. It's a steep curve, to be sure, and representative of how the game approaches skills and leveling up. Additionally, the quest log -- the game's system for tracking general learned information and info pertaining to specific active or inactive quests -- is unorganized and difficult to work with. It is barely a step above remembering what you're actively doing, and trying not to take up any other tasks until it is completed.So what really separates Morrowind from later Elder Scrolls games?The world is large and real. This isn't scandanavia or medieval England. This is a world unlike any other, with giant mushrooms and huge insects. It is interesting, unique, and worth exploring. And explore you will, because there is no fast-travel. The best form of transportation are via specific routes between certain cities -- boats, Mages Guild teleportation, large land beasts, etc. Anything else, be it going to off-the-beaten-path settlements, or simply getting to one of those hub towns, requires hoofing it. It adds a staggering degree of realism that later games stripped away. The world isn't actually larger, but the game presents itself that way. There are more guilds and organizations. More missions for those guilds. More cities, towns, and people. There's an openness to it because the cities aren't walled in, a separate level from the outside. The player also has a degree of agency that hasn't existed in Elder Scrolls games since. The degree of skill customization is extensive: more kinds of weaponry to specialize in, more kinds of armor, more branches of magic and spells within those branches. The player also has a lot more freedom to affect the world in permanent ways. You actions in one guild will affect other guilds. Everyone can be killed, including quest givers and NPCs integral to the main story. The world is yours to take. Oblivion introduced the concept of player-bought houses. No such game-sanctioned method exists in Morrowind. Instead, acquiring a house involves using your freedom. You could find a house that appears abandoned and move in, or you could find a nice house, murder the occupant, dispose of their body, and make it yours. There aren't items that are free to take and items that constitute stealing. There's just items, and you can steal them.The NPCs that inhabit Morrowind offer vastly more variety. With brief exceptions, the game has no voice acting. All dialogue is simply textual, and different personalities can be revealed through the text of their dialogue. Every NPC doesn't have the same voice, creating the impression of world populated by artificial clones. This fact alone almost certainly influenced the rest of the game, because it meant that something as simple as adding another Thieves Guild quest didn't involve more voice and audio work.This, in a way, describes the game as a whole. It's clear that, when the game was being developed, there was a lot more freedom to add content and run wild when developing the game. It bleeds into almost every aspect of the game. It's not as smooth, nor as pretty, as later installments, but it's a world worth exploring,

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												The Gold Standard of open world RPG. The mother of all RPG games to come after it. Morrowind revolutionized the idea of an open world game. There is depth to the world that is unparalleled in both games released before this as well as afterwards. The game is dated, so there is something to be said about how smoothly the game runs and looks and feels, but there are many mods that can be used to remedy those issues (http://www.nexusmods.com/morrowind/mods/36945/?). This game begins with you as a prisoner. No history, you can become whatever you want to be. You can create a character who does anything you want. The depth of the character development allows you to become anything you want. You can choose follow a pre-built class chosen from a list of 21 including classes such as: sorceror, thief, and warrior. Or you can be something new and creative by creating your own class. If you want (and I did this), you can be a walking tank with a two handed battleaxe wearing plate armour imbued with the blood of demons. You can choose to be one of one of ten races, each with their own characteristics, each with their stereotypes that generate responses unique to that race from NPCs. You can even choose to become a vampire or (with the bloodmoon expansion included in the Game of the Year edition) werewolf!This means you will have a unique experience in your game that nobody else has quite experienced.While the character creation system is very powerful, it can be confusing for a starting player. The key is you don't have to worry about it. The system has very specific things you can do to optimize your character, but you can enjoy the game just as well without employing those strategies.In playing this game, you find yourself planted in a world, complete with history, religion, science, and anything else you would expect and more. You can find books with conflicting religions. You can worship demons known as daedra. You can read about Vivec ascending to godhood and the religion surrounding them. There are several religious texts in the game that you can read. It is quite a project to learn about the world, sometimes I wonder if I know more about the Elder Scrolls universe or the outside world.The province of Morrowind is in a time of peril. The longstanding religion of worshipping AlmSiVi, the tribunal, is wavering. An old enemy is rising again. You have complete control over what you do with the world. You can completely ignore the world's issues and go to set out to just explore caves, crypts, and other areas on your own. You can go join a guild and rise through those ranks, You can even kill people who are essential to saving the world. You can save the world, or you can just as well doom it. The game is whatever you want it to be.This game is the gold standard of RPG for a reason and all current open world RPGs are based off of this amazing game. If you enjoy any open world RPG,  it is a must to come back to the roots of the genre and play the amazing game that really started it all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Ah, Elder Scrolls; almost never ceases to amaze at launch and onwards. This classic jewel of a game is a must buy for MOST  ES fans out there. I emphasize *MOST* for there are a few things that would keep the veterans begging for more while other newer fans out there might be thrown off.TLDR Version:Discover destiny in all it's glory as you become embroiled in politcs, war, and prophecy.Pros:+Deep, meaningful storyline+Exploration at it's best+Fully customizable character optimization+Very avid modding community+Jump across a continent within 5 minutes of gameplay!!!Cons:-Combat isn't engaging for melee characters-Very weak graphics without mods-Not friendly to the unwary begginer-Some things are never explained and need a wiki9.5/10 BUY IT!! BUY IT!! BUY IT!!!Long VersionQUick Backstory:You are a prisoner on a boat headed for the island of Vvardenfell* for unknown reasons; but they must be important for the Emporer himself ordered your travel there. You are disturbed by foul dreams as a voice speaks to you and says you have been "chosen" and that the voice "will be watchful". You awaken on the boat to be dropped on your sorry♥♥♥♥♥♥in a small village, and are given orders by the local authorities to find a man named "Caius Cassades" and follow his orders to the letter. YOu will follow his orders to the letter and soon find yourself involved in disputes with a theocratic state, battle the forces of a living god, and discover Morrowind in all it's glory, prophecies, and destinies. But in the end, you carve your own destiny...Morrowind is the true ES game which expanded the influence and started ES on it's road to fame and recognition. This is because at the time it's graphics were good, tons to explore, and most importantly, it was the first ES game to port to a console and do it succesfully. It established standards for open-world games and earned itself "Game of the Year", and Bethesda celebrated that by re-releasing it at the time with 2 Expansion packs, eah with their own intrigueing stories and atmospheres. We are going to explore this game and why it is such a huge success and why it is a classic, but also why it might not appeal to newer fans of ES that started with things like ES IV or V*Pros:StorylineThe story is well thought out and is deep and enaging, but also mysterious as well as intrigueing. Without spoling too much, the story consists of you following the story of the ancient dumner hero known as "Nerervar" and why he is so important to the native tribes of Vvardenfell as well as the people of the civilized part of the island. Your exploits soon discover  a secret cult, shrouded in mystery and dread, known as the "Sixth House", ans soon dsicover they have a lot more planned than the world even knows a the time. With these secretive and covert ops, you come to blows with the local religious establishment known as the "Tribunal Temple", which rules most of Morrowind through a merciful, but inquisitive, theocratic state. All of these factions are aware of prophecies of the acient island, and harbor dark secrets that are known to themselves and why they commit to their odd actions. The background lore is solid, with many books and inside lore to fill the mind of the confused player who is embroiled within this conflict. You must persuade and threaten everyone from simple commoners to living gods to determine what the whole scheme of things is and to reveal the whole plot to the player.ExplorationFrom artifacts to mundane bonemeal, you almost never know what you will find in the next cave or tomb you enter a stupid cave with nothing, or you could find a secret daedric ruin within a tomb, and follow it's path to find a long and sought after artifact! Only you can wll yourself to explore, and is there a LOT to explore. There are som many dungeons, so many caves and tombs, that I havn't even foud everything, and i've played this game for YEARS.Fully Customized CharactersYour cosmetics might not be that open to possibilities, but the stats of your character are completley open to experiment with. FInd the best combinations, etermine your playstyle, which can be literally ANYTHING you could imagine. Unlike in ES IV and V, your playstyle is not pushed in a certatin direction. Nope; you can be a jumping, fireball throwing lunatic, a naked sneak-theif, a half- naked mage, you can play however you like.Avid Modding CommuteEven though Ste.Wor.Sho.* doesn't support, their are 10,000's of mods out there for your choosing, from graphics to gameplay to sound and body mods, the mod community continues to thriveto this day. One mod that is essential, however, is the "Morrowind Code Patch" mod, which fixes many bugs and bad scripting that unfortunatly takes place in this game.Jump Across a Continet in under 5 min. of Gameplay!Pretty self explanatory, just go out of town and follow the path till you see a book on the ground and hear screams.ConsMelee CombatMelee combat is sadly a joke in ES III. Everything is based off of chance, and so you can be swinging a battleaxe into someone's face, but if your skill is too low, you still won't hit, which can be rather immersion breaking.Graphics didn't age wellTHis is an old game, and the graphics didn't age well at all. Bad polygon count, poor view range and bad lip synce plague this game. Many graphics mods change many of these features, however, and fix most problems quite nicely. Thank the mod community.Begginers BewareIf you don't know what you're doing, watch out, for yo will find yourself in the wrong cave fighting a level 30 monster who wants to rip your n*ts off. Just think carefully before you go anywhere to dangerous and don;t be afraid to run away if things get too rough.Need a wiki?Yes, even with it's deep, underlying story, some things are never explained in terms of quest objectives, what to do, as well as some lore issues, and some explanations as to where someone is. I presonally reccoment UESPWiki to help with many of your dilemas in this department.Overall, an ageless classic and well worth your time, for it lays down the doundations for many of the ground breaking features in later ES games, and introduces so many lore points tat willl you will be for more.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												This game....First time I heard about Morrowind was from a friend who recently got an Xbox (the original). He was so excited, kept rambling on about how you can fly around the map and stuff, still didn't really interest me much. Finally I got to try it out after him hyping it up...and It just didn't really click for me. Maybe it was because I was so young, or the fact that I just didn't play that many games back then, I just couldn't get into it. Took a couple years till i finally got a PC, and remembering this game I saved up for it, and wow, I don't know what changed, but suddenly this was the best thing I had ever seen. Seriously, ignore my hours on steam, I've put so much time into this game, its pretty much impossible to even estimate how long, and funny enough, I've never beaten it. That's how much stuff there is to do, not only that, but this game is ♥♥♥♥ing hard haha. Not in a bad way, but I remember being stuck on the first quest (that damn dwemer box...) for months, and still had fun just ranking up in the fighters guild until i realized I could just look it up online....Ranting aside, this is an awesome game. If your into RPG's, need something that will (almost) definitely run on your rig, or just wanna see some old school Elder Scrolls history of sorts, I'd say buy it.The main flaws you will probably hear about it is the combat being weird (random dice rolls on every hit, meaning you could be standing there swinging at something and missing over and over when your inches from your opponent...a little weird i have to admit), and maybe the out dated graphics. One word. Mods. Mods for days.

Posted: August 9, 2016
												One of the best games in TES series. Yeah, graphics and gameplay might be a bit outdated, but it doesn't really matter(at least to me). I was pretty sceptical about this game until I actually played it. It has wonderful world filled with a lot of quests and locations. You can be pretty much whoever you want to be. Wanna be a bloody assasin? Sure! Wanna be a sneaky thief? Go ahead! One of the best things about this game is that it doesn't have fast travel function like Skyrim or Oblivion. You actually need to explore the world on your feet, and on your way you may meet some interesting characters or angry monsters or maybe something else. As I said, this is one of the best games in TES series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
The game that pushed the open world western RPGs to the next level.Pros Incredibly detailed and unusual fantasy world Original leveling system Incredible modding potential Best sky representation in it's time, especially the night sky Music, sound effects, voices Completely open world from the get-go Great main story Lots of quests to do Lots of factions and guilds to choose from Weather effects (especially ash storms) adds a lot of uniqueness to the enviroment Almost limitless potential in spellcrafting and enchanting Limitless character developement potential Large amount of weapons and armor to choose from Still runs fine after all these years Low HDD space requirement Tutorial is short but tells you everything you need to know You can become a vampire or a werewolfCons If you are not the patient type, travelling can be a chore No day and night cycle for 99% of the NPCs NPCs are mostly static and do not travel at all Lack of mounts Lack of player housing Fighting mechanics are clunky and barely exist Cannot fight and cast spells at the same time Character creation have very few options Leveling has some issues Character animaton is a mixed bag Useless 3rd person view optionWhat is this game?Morrowind is a first-person view based, open world, non-linear western style RPG released in 2002 for PC and later for the original Xbox. This is the 3rd main title in the Elder Scrolls series, the first fully 3D game and the first with 100% hand crafted enviroment. This version includes both official expansion packs released to the game. While the game is excellent by itself, it is highly modable and let's you upgrade almost all aspect of it. In my opinion it's significance can only be compared to GTA 3 and Final Fantasy VII in their respective genres. A must have experience for RPG fans everywhere around the world, highly recommened. NOTE: There are independent content patches for this game and I'm not sure if they are included in this version. These can be found on the Bethesda website.Long reviewFirst of all sorry about this 'short' review, I had to cut the review in half and redo it completely to fit it in this tiny space. Also this is my first review, so bare with me. Let's get on with it then. Let me start with the beginning, character creation and tutorial. You start as a prisoner released to freedom by the emperor. For what reason? That you'll have to find out in the main quest. Sadly the game don't have too many options coming to character creation, it's very simplistic. Rather focus your attention to your race, class and birthsign: these will determine how powerful your character will be at the beginning. Why just the beginning? Because there is no limitation in skill progression in this game. You can max out everything. To help out newcomers I give a nice melee character combo: Redguard - Knight - The lady. The first building serves as the tutorial area, so examine everything you find, or just skip it entirely. In this game nothing is forced on you. After you got your relaese papers and fee, you are free in every possible respect. While you got pointers to where to go first, you are not forced to, you are set to explore the island of Vvardenfell. At first it seems like just a regular fantasy setting, except for maybe the giant bug you see right next to the village. Yes, that is just the beginning.  As you venture into the island the first thing that stands out are the giant, 10 meters high mushrooms in the grasslands. And further traveling in the island there is nothingness. Vegetation gone and vulcanic ash everywhere. You bump into ancient ruins of Dwemer, Daedric and Dunmer in origin, far from being abandoned. You can find cities made of giant crab shells and magicly altered mushrooms. Your travels will be slowed by ash storms, thunderstorm and bandits. But you'll have to walk, as you have limited ways of transportation in this game. Not all is hostile to you tho. You can find several towns and cities with merchants and inns to sleep in, but most importantly you can find guilds and factions to join. They not just give you additional quests, but they will provide discounted services for you and additional storyline . Speaking of quests, there is of course a main story in the game, which I don't want to spoil too much, is a great epic journey of a prisoner becoming one of the empire's blades agents and at the end ascending to godhood. The main story is about politics, religion, revenge and redemption. You are going to set things right in this land. As your adventure goes forward you will learn a lot about this land and the empire from NPCs and books. Books are also good for leveling your skills, which is mandatory, as this game is all about skills. Skills can go from 0 to 100, representing your chance to succeed in use of given skill. This is important, as the game doesn't make it a secret that everything you do is based on those hidden dice rolls and skill chances. There are no mini games here, even your sword swing is just a start of a dice roll. Skill are also important in leveling up your charater as there is no XP in this game. Instead you have to level 10 major or minor skills to level your character. And when you do, you can increase 3 of your attributes. You can add a multiplier to those attribute levels by leveling skills governed by that attribute. While character creation is simple and hard to do unique characters, the itemisation is very extensive. You can choose from several armor sets and weapon types. If you do not prefer weapons, there is a huge selections of spells to choose from. Even better, you can create your own spell. You can also create magical weapons and potions in the game. Voice acting is good in the game, even if the game is not fully voice acted. Every race has it's unique voice in the game. The music is excellent, composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. While listening to the nice relaxing medieval melodies traveling the wilderness, it can quick turn to a battle chant when you got attacked. Outside of the game world one of the most important aspect is modding. This game can be modded by almost any way you want, or the engine lets you to. Glitches can be patched, graphical fidelity can be upgraded, new stuff can be added to the game. You can make this game feel and handle so much better if your are not satisfied with it's original ways. And there are some things to address here. The leveling system need some tweaking or complete overhaul. Character animation is bad for some races. Characters can use some more polygons just as better textures. A whole graphical overhaul is also can be on the table, especially the viewing distance. Player housing is completely missing from the game just like mounts. NPCs are few and very static with missing day/night cycles, you can change that too.ConclusionEven if the game has several faults, it is nothing short of an ambitious project succeeded. The game has a unique feeling to it, loneliness is weightet heavily on your shoulders as you traverse the vulcanic wasteland of the island or it's catacombs. As you progress through the game and a greater evil force your hand to act, you slowly find a purpose and a goal, even the gods starts to smile on you. It can take 100s of hours of your life easily with one character, not to mention more. I hope I've encouraged you to try this or any of the Elder Scrolls games, they are great experiences. Also, if you are looking for the previous games, you can download the Elder Scrolls 1-2 for FREE from Bethesda.Feel free to comment and send me messages. Good gaming everyone!

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												This is the defining game of the series, Oblivion and Skyrim, (both incredible, fantastic, amazing games), are really just simplified, almost dumbed down versions on THIS game, however, exicuted in a really great way. Morrowind allows freedom that the two games that followed just cant replicate. Spells, and enchanting bassically allow you to create things so powerfull, you would think it shouldnt even be allowed in the game, BUT, you can only achieve such things if you are smart enough to figure out how. Which brings me to my next point, everything in the game is layed out for you, the only things holding you back are skill levels. Once you get high enough levels, you can litterally make a spell to give you the abbility to fly, and shoot nukes at what ever the ♥♥♥♥ you want. You cant buy a house, but that doesnt mean you cant break into some dark elfs manor, kill him, and make his house your's. you can then drop your items where you want them to display them, tons of artifacts to collect. Bottom line, this game is very challenging, it sepparates the real gamers from the posers, the men from the children, It requires you to use youre head once, think about things, it doesnt force you to explore, it doesnt force you to talk to people, but if you dont, and you are lazy about it, this game will eat you alive, and you will be stuck. you literally have to LEARN.. you HAVE to learn, the lore, the skills, the weapons, the artifacts, the land, how to fight and survive. it makes the game very special, to me at the very least. You cant just bull♥♥♥♥♥♥your way through, quests are hard, there are no quest markers, dialouge is all text based. if you kill the wrong person you can doom the world which makes it impposible for you to finish the game or complete certain quests. the sad thing is, that its hard to get into this game these days, the graphics are dated for sure, the combat has some major flaws..  but if you can get past that, this game truely is brilliant, its fantastic, its simply more than words can describe. there is so much content, that im not sure any single person on this planet knows every little thing of information, item, or quest. If you think you can handle all of that.. then buy it, dont think, just do it. Oblivion, and Skyrim wouldnt exsist if this game wasnt so incredible, thats a fact.Edit: i will note that i only have 13 hours in this game on steam, but all of my play time comes from xbox when it was first ported. i was also only in 7th and 8th grade when i spent all my time playing this game.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Still a masterpeice after all these years. Brings a tear to my eye. Seriously though, Morrowind has aged WELL. I got it on sale on Steam recently hit by a nostalgic urge to re-play it. Gave it a graphical mod, an animation mod and (what? I'm impatient) a stamina mod to let you run places and bam. Yes the combat is still clunky, but it's not BAD. At least it's tactical and not just the boring hack and slash Skyrim and Oblivion gave us. The magic in Morrowind is AMAZING - SO MANY EFFECTS! AAAAAAAAA! But yeah, one of my biggest issues with Skyrim was that it simplified magic. Heck, that was an issue I had with Oblivion! But in Morrowind magic really can do anything you could do but better. Except disarm traps. Yup, magical chest traps cannot be disarmed by Magic. Not that I know of. I haven't tried just shooting them yet. You could use Restoration to make yourself a GOD at picking locks for 10 seconds and disarm it with a probe, but that will burn magicka and that doesn't regenerate in Morrowind. Unless you mod it. Like me. Oh, one final point: Morrowind has Tamriel Rebuilt. That's a win in itself.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I know I haven't played this game much, but hear me out. From what I understand, this is a wonderful game. I've not once heard anyone say that Morrowind sucked. However, I caution this:- The graphics have not aged well, which, I know is a deterent for many (myself included)- The combat system is frustrating. Unlike Skyrim and Oblivion, Morrowind runs on a dice roll system, which means that even if your weapon makes contact with the enemy, you might still have an awful roll, and you miss anyways. So if you miss, you miss, and if you hit, you still miss half of the time.I will still rate this game as positive as I have only heard good of this game. So, if you can get past the aforementioned points, I recommend you buy this game. If they sound like an issue, then I recommend saving your money. It may be a great game, but it really doesn't matter if the graphics and mechanics are frustrating.

												Pure awesome! Noticably old graphics and gameplay in general, but the world is magnificent. Lots of text story, and kind of hard to follow at first, but there is a lot of time and story put into this, and it's all available ingame. The Hybrid of choosing FPS and 3rd person at any time will seem clunky at first, but it will not take you away from the game at all, and it is only understandable seeing as how 2002 is probably one of the first times that had been done.All in all: However old the game is, it is still a Magnificent game for you freedom lovers

content:
Posted: December 21, 2011
												Outlander. Travel east, to Morrowind. The province of Vvardenfell awaits, full of its enigmatic people, the Dunmer (aka Dark Elves), from the Great Houses and the Temple to the nomadic Ashlander Clans, Vvardenfell has much to offer a traveller to its shores. Solstheim, a harsh unforgiving island to the north and Mournhold, capital of Morrowind. There are many things waiting to be discovered. Find out the truth behind ALMSIVI and the Sixth House.Now dated graphically, but a classic RPG unparalled in scope and size by its more mordern cousins, Oblivion and Skyrim. Not for those who hate reading, however, as there is lots of text dialogue throughout the game. Extremely immersive gameplay, although minor quests can get tedious (as there can be a lot of "courier" work). Many hours of gameplay and excellent replay value.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												No game is quite as immersive as Morrowind. It has its quirks, and it shows its age, but the game itself is timeless. You can give the base game a facelift with mods and spend hours doing dumb stuff. It's a bit more technical, menu heavy, slower, and less reactive than Skyrim, which leans more towards action-rpg. Morrowind is in a sweet spot, it has true "sandboxy" spells but weapon combat is a bit dull.The game really shines because of the amount of detail, writing, lore, and immersion put into the game. The island isn't as decorated as lets say, Skyrim, which has something to do almost everywhere. Morrowind has plenty to do too but you will spend a lot of time walking and being attacked. Once you get a good hang of the game though, you will be having a blast. The story is actually very engrossing and so is the island of Vvardenfell. You will get lost in the lives of the inhabitants, there are so many faces and stories to be told.Mechanically, Morrowind doesn't really hold up. It's alright, but install some mods before you give the game a good roll for the first time (at least that's what I recommend).

content:
Posted: March 16
												9.5/10Absolutely recommend. Morrowind is a unique, one of a kind game that is unlike any other. Taking a lot of freedom from Arena and Daggerfall before it, Morrowind is an open-world RPG game with no hand-holding and freeform leveling. Unlike Oblivion and titles after it, Morrowind relys a lot of old-school dice rolling and a lot of reading. Be prepared to be lost and fear the world for the first few hours but give it a chance and it quickly becomes an engrossing, engaging land filled with hundreds of quests and things to do. Do not enter Morrowind if you have not read or experienced any idea of how the game works. It is NOT your typical action/adventure RPG. Morrowind is somewhat in it's own gaming genre kinda like a mix between Oblivion/Skyrim but playing with a D&D style mechanic running in the background. There are no quest markers. Everything must be either found with directions, using clues and journals, etc. Enemies do not typically scale. Locations are unique to levels, early end games items can be found with time and skill, etc. You can and more than likely will become a GOD after countless hours of playtime although this requires actually playing and working for it. Morrowind is my personal favorite Elder Scrolls title. No nostalgia here either as Oblivion was my first followed by Skyrim. A better magic system featuring spells and schools of magick either nerfed or completely removed from later games. More types of weapons like spears, short katanas, crossbows, throwing stars/knives, etc. Each dungeon being handcrafted (although typically they looks similar, they each tend to play their own story in the background), more fleshed out guilds, the ability to wear clothing under armor and seperate left/right pieces. Just too much to list. I paid $14.99 USD for the Game of The Year Edition. Considering the amount of content and the current going price for a physical copy, a well spent purchase. The Steam Edition runs beautifuly and is also capable of modding. The same Morrowind as before, nothing new, nothing different. *TIP!* To play Morrowind in 1080p HD or higher (it looks so much better and keeps the vanilla textures), download 'Morrowind FPS Optimizer' and place it inside the Morrowind folder. Run it and click 'change Morrowind registry settings' then set to your liking. Enjoy!

9/10 - This game never gets old.I'll do a total run through of the game every year or two years and even as the intro scene starts up for the tenth time, and Azura talks of the prophesy (with me reciting it along with her) I feel like I'm coming home to Morrowind after a year away, anticipating meeting familiar faces and returning to Balmora. I've played Oblivion and Skyrim and in terms of story, Morrowind has the best story centering around you (and not being a sidekick of Sean Bean, or whoever was the main character was in Skyrim (oh, was that me? With a plethora of mods available, you can get textures, models, whole landscapes, lighting, water, and even sounds up to the standard of recently released games. This game really seems timeless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The best 'modern' Elder Scrolls game by a long shot, and a rude awakening for anyone whose introduction to ES was Oblivion or Skyrim. You begin as literally a nobody, born under a certain sign to uncertain parents, released from the Imperial City's prison under questionable circumstances and thrust into a world where nobody likes you and everything will probably try to kill you. There is no magical arrow in the sky showing you where to go, and even the smallest of encounters can be deadly. Fast travel exists only in the form of paid transports, running everywhere will render you too exhausted to fight effectively, untrained spells will fail and unpracticed attacks will miss. But this is what makes Morrowind special; a truly fantastic, alien, landscape, real challenges, complex plotlines requiring real choices and tests of loyalty and skill instead of 'follow the magic arrow to the next cutscene'.11/10.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I have actually started binging this game lately, so I guess I will make a review for it that is completely un-nostalgia biased.I purchased this game in late 2013 and I decided its finally time to play this gem. I installed the MGSO mod and a few more graphical and bug fixing improvements and I was set. I set foot out of the starting ship, and man, this game can be absolutely gorgeous! I went through the tutorial and went into the first dungeon, and to keep it simple, there is a steep learning curve to this game. This game is by no means an easy game. Enemies and missions don't scale to your level, and the game barely holds your hand. The only ways you're going to fast travel are spells and Silt Striders, and you miss 90% of your strikes when you begin. But once you spend some time leveling, doing quests, and play for a good amount of time, this game really begins to shine. There is so much depth to this game it's astonishing. I can definitely tell why people adore this game after all this time and have spent thousands of hours playing it. Just remember to jump around a million times to up your acrobatics.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2011
												Morrowind is possibly one of the last RPG games before the (needed?) simplification of the genre: forget about map markings or arrows pointing to quest objectives; traveling is pretty much done "by foot", as the means for auto-travel are scarce - and the world is HUGE. Killed that random guy for no reason (he was part of the main quest)? Well, too bad, find something else to do. Morrowind will let you goof and you won’t know until it’s too late. Yet, this is an awesome game, in every aspect: you’ll walk a lot but, as a reward, you’ll find something new everytime; small things that make you want to explore just for the sake of it. Morrowind is rich in every aspect: lore, characters, environment, quests, soundtrack… if you can cope with outdated graphics and likes really challenging RPGs (Ultima series style), give it a try. It is definitely the best one of the Elder Scrolls games.Bethesda, remaster this game!!!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												The best world out of all the Elder Scrolls games imho; a truly alien fantasy world with its own alien culture, coinhabited by your more common fantasy tropes. Most factions of all the 3D Elder Scrolls games too, and each feels real with their relationships with each other and between people in the factions themselves being varied and diverse. You do need to love world exploration and quests more than action to get the most out of this game, but the overhaul mod does update the graphics into the "old school but beautiful" territory and modernize some dated choices in game design.If the world intrigues you at all, go for it and explore at your own pace!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Morrowind is an amazing open-world RPG that is definately worth playing. It is, in my opinion, the greatest of the Elder Scrolls games. You start out as a nobody; a prisoner boarding a ship to the island of Vvardenfell. You don't know why, but you have been sent to Morrowind. You must carefully choose a race, class, and skills to advance through the game as you see fit.      At this point, you can do whatever you want from this point on. You could join one of the Great Houses of Morrowind, join a guild, progress through the main quest, or just wander. You see a ancient burial site, explore it. You see an Ancient Dwemer ruin, go check it out. You see a daedric shine, go loot it. This is where Morrowind shines. There are so many dungeons that have no correlation with questlines. Exploration in this game is amazing.    The game also must be the most realistic of the franchise. It is hard calling a game with magic and giant floating jellyfish realistic, but the skill system is very good. You will hear many gripes about the combat in Morrowind, on how it takes dozens of hits to kill a mudcrab. You must work and hone your skills to become good at them. If you are highly skilled with a long blade, you will kill that mudcrab with ease. However, if you are a skilled mage, and you go stab that mudcrab with a spear, you will never hit it and your spear may break before you even kill the darn thing.    Morrowind's story tells a great tale, and is aided by a true sense of accomplishment that I have never felt in a game before. To avoid spoilers, you start out as a prisoner, like pretty much ever other Elder Scrolls game, and grow into something much, much greater. And the immersive atmosphere helps the story along just fine. It is true that Morrowind isn't the prettiest game out there, but the sound, lighting, and weather effects polish up your sorroundings.    When you progress, you will have to increase skills to level up. Upon leveling up you can approve your attributes (this is similiar to S.P.E.C.I.A.L in the Fallout series) and get a little motivational message. Accomplishment is well rewarded with a powerful weapon or item, and when you receive that weapon, you feel slightly more powerful. For the most part, enemies are not scaled. So when you do get that extremely powerful weapon, you feel extremely powerful. Soon you'll realize that there are stronger weapons to be found and stronger enemies to overcome. This process can repeat many times over.     There you have it, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. It is definately one of my favorite games of all time and worth the purchase.PS- Beware of Cliff Racers

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												To this date, I believe this to be the best open-world RPG of all time, and the other elder scrolls simply cannot compare, in my opinion. First and foremost, if you are thinking of trying this game, remember that it is not very user-friendly for most people that haven't played a hardcore RPG like this before. You need to put in time and effort to figure things out, because it's not the instant gratification kind of deal you see in nearly all modern RPGs nowadays. You will also need to read. A LOT.In addition, you must also remember that this game is quite old, so if you're not comfortable with old 3D graphics, then you will need to mod it.If you are not willing to do these things, then turn back now.That aside, Morrowind is an incredible experience. It has one of the most developed and well thought-out worlds ever made in the history of fiction. The lore of this game is a deep, entagling web of stories that draws you in and never lets go.The gameplay--once you grasp it--is very intricate and fun, specially if you are a mage. To this date, I don't think there's ever been a game that lets the player truly feel like an all-mighty sorcerer better than morrowind, so if you like in-depth magic in games, then you will adore it.The soundtrack, composed by the legendary Jeremy Soule, is simply beautiful. It fits perfectly with the mood this game creates. Also, it might interest you to know that the "elder scrolls theme" that we all know and love made its debut here.Finally, the looks.While the graphics may not be top of the line anymore by any stretch of the imagination, it still looks fantastic simply because of the outstanding art direction this game has, proving once again that artstyle is much more important than graphic fidelity in videogames.From the ashen wastelands filled with blighted beasts, to the titanic, sprawling cities bustling with people, to the expansive valleys filled with towering mushrooms, this game truly leaves an impression for the eyes with its strangely plausible, alien-fantasy aesthetic. No one forgets the first time they visit the city of Vivec, I assure you.With all that said, I wholeheartedly recomend this game to anyone who is willing to put the time and effort for a truly fascinating and rewarding experience. If you are a fan of RPGs, specially open-world ones, then you should absolutely play this. And after you are done, you can explore the seemingly never-ending list of mods lovingly made by a community that still supports the game to this day, so you can experience something fresh every time you replay it.BLESSED BE ALMSIVI.

												Before Skyrim there was OblivionBefore Oblivion there was MorrowindAnd Morrowind was a game to start with if you want a huge rpg experience with deep lore. I always felt this title was the most knee-deep in lore that took itself more seriously than its successors. And with less voice acting, you were actually forced to read the dialogue. Which in this case is GOOD! Why? It makes you learn the in world lore more so than the other games, hence, you actually get something back for reading rather than "skip this, blah blah blah, ok wheres the next dungeon?" You also feel like you had to try harder to acheive something in this game. Its not like Skyrim where you almost instantly praised for being Dragonborn. A reputation was more woven into the system mechanics in Morrowind. And thus a more real RPG experience!Did i mention the spell crafting system is the best?

												One of my favorite games of all time. Open world free-roaming type fantasy RPG, this title grants you near 100% freedom to do what you will. Create any character you can imagine, and embark upon an epic journey that is hard to beat. The game spans a giant landmass so there is plenty to explore as well as a plethora of quests. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Fantastical adventure with an enormous amount of detail and attention. I've been playing it throughout the years, since it first released on Xbox back in Spring of 2002.You have a huge, carefully-constructed open world to discover with dozens upon dozens of unmarked caves and dungeons and ruins to explore. Hidden easter eggs and references scattered throughout :0Extensive and thought out skill system. Customize your character into whatever you want. A rouge that favors spears and uses paralysis spells and wears medium armor. A mage that focuses on alteration to bend the environment to their will, while also specializing in sneak to steal anything not bolted to the floor. Splendid combinations!Levitation as well. Don't feel like climbing or walking around a giant mountain? Drink or use a levitation spell and you'll soon be soaring through the skies... with cliff racers D:Two other expansion packs, Bloodmoon and Tribunal, further expand upon the story and offer new locations, powerful items and other goodies. Definitely well worth the time to play through those. I quite like Tribunal as my favorite =]And, of course, there are the hundreds of mods available, if you don't quite like the vanilla game in all it's low-resolution meshed-together glory. Make it look like an upgraded Oblivion if you so choose <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Morrowind is really a masterpiece RPG, one I've played since I got a copy in 2003. It can be difficult at early levels, but honestly, there's nothing too hard about it. A lot of problems that new players find have simple solutions.Think movement is too slow? Go with Sign of the Steed.Can't hit anything? Stop running around near monsters. Slow down. Or pick Sign of the Lady for the +25 Agility, or Warrior for the all-around attack boost. Or make sure your racial weapon bonuses and class bonuses line up with your weapon.Still having trouble with Stamina? Amulets of Stamina are pretty easy to find once you get to Balmora. Just visit the enchanter in the Mage's Guild, or spend some pocket change hopping between the guilds until you find one.Is money getting you down? Sell everything you find, do some quests. You'll have more than you know what to do with soon enough.Game crashes a lot? Save often, or get patches. Actually, do both. The Morrowind Code Patch is amazing, and saving often, in different slots, never hurt anyone.Can't fight off chains of Dark Brotherhood Assassins who keep interrupting your rest? You got me there. Those guys are pretty tough. Don't wander so far from civilization that you can't take some trips to Ebonheart after your first attack, I guess.Enemies to watch out for early on include ghosts (you will want silver or magic weapons for them), that mage in the newbie cave (he might kill you in 1 hit, often takes 2), and pretty much any enemies in dungeons that aren't in the starter area. Not all dungeons are like this, but save before you check out each one.Once you get the hang of the game, you'll find that everything you do can be OP if you play your cards right. I've walked into Daedric ruins at level 2/3 and killed some of the high-level NPCs in there for really nice loot, like Ebony and Orcish armor. It took a lot of potions, but it was worth it. (Hint: save your game before you try some as inherently suicidal as this).Final advice: save often. Especially if you like jumping.

												Played this game back before Steam existed on my friends PC back when I was 13. Simply, THE best RPG game of all time (In my opinion). number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												Morrowind is the best Elder Scrolls title developed. Coming off of Oblivion and Skyrim, Morrowind is a lot more difficult and the combat system is a little off, but the atmosphere, guilds, story, lore etc. more than make up for that. My favorite aspect of Morrowind is that you start with nothing, and finish with everything; no game reinforces such an accomplished feeling as Morrowind does. Something that deeply improves the experience is the Morrowind Overhaul by Ornitocopter, this mod-pack modernizes the graphics and user interface while fixing bugs and retaining the original Morrowind feel. I greatly recommend this title to anyone who has love for a complicated albeit very rewarding and unexpected RPG experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I've found Morrowind to be the most enjoyable, immersive, and rewarding game in the Elder Scrolls franchise, and this is coming from someone who played both Oblivion and Skyrim before Morrowind. Unlike newer games in the series, this game is an old-school CRPG that pulls no punches; map markers are nonexistent, fast travel is only possible through in-game transportations systems (silt strider ports, mages guilds, boats, etc), almost every game mechanic is based on a 'dice roll' of sorts (this is why you'll miss nearly every sword swing in the beginning), and enemies/gear in no way scale to the player's level. Make no mistake, this is a game that will absolutely kick your♥♥♥♥♥for the first 10-15 hours on a first-time playthrough, but if you have the patience and are willing to invest a decent amount of time into your character build, I think you'll find an extremely rewarding experience at the heart of Morrowind.Note: I higly recommend using Morrowind Overhaul if you want to get the most out of your experience. It increases the visual fidelity of the game drastically and allows you to tweak certain game mechanics to your liking.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Ah, Elder Scrolls; almost never ceases to amaze at launch and onwards. This classic jewel of a game is a must buy for MOST  ES fans out there. I emphasize *MOST* for there are a few things that would keep the veterans begging for more while other newer fans out there might be thrown off.TLDR Version:Discover destiny in all it's glory as you become embroiled in politcs, war, and prophecy.Pros:+Deep, meaningful storyline+Exploration at it's best+Fully customizable character optimization+Very avid modding community+Jump across a continent within 5 minutes of gameplay!!!Cons:-Combat isn't engaging for melee characters-Very weak graphics without mods-Not friendly to the unwary begginer-Some things are never explained and need a wiki9.5/10 BUY IT!! BUY IT!! BUY IT!!!Long VersionQUick Backstory:You are a prisoner on a boat headed for the island of Vvardenfell* for unknown reasons; but they must be important for the Emporer himself ordered your travel there. You are disturbed by foul dreams as a voice speaks to you and says you have been "chosen" and that the voice "will be watchful". You awaken on the boat to be dropped on your sorry♥♥♥♥♥♥in a small village, and are given orders by the local authorities to find a man named "Caius Cassades" and follow his orders to the letter. YOu will follow his orders to the letter and soon find yourself involved in disputes with a theocratic state, battle the forces of a living god, and discover Morrowind in all it's glory, prophecies, and destinies. But in the end, you carve your own destiny...Morrowind is the true ES game which expanded the influence and started ES on it's road to fame and recognition. This is because at the time it's graphics were good, tons to explore, and most importantly, it was the first ES game to port to a console and do it succesfully. It established standards for open-world games and earned itself "Game of the Year", and Bethesda celebrated that by re-releasing it at the time with 2 Expansion packs, eah with their own intrigueing stories and atmospheres. We are going to explore this game and why it is such a huge success and why it is a classic, but also why it might not appeal to newer fans of ES that started with things like ES IV or V*Pros:StorylineThe story is well thought out and is deep and enaging, but also mysterious as well as intrigueing. Without spoling too much, the story consists of you following the story of the ancient dumner hero known as "Nerervar" and why he is so important to the native tribes of Vvardenfell as well as the people of the civilized part of the island. Your exploits soon discover  a secret cult, shrouded in mystery and dread, known as the "Sixth House", ans soon dsicover they have a lot more planned than the world even knows a the time. With these secretive and covert ops, you come to blows with the local religious establishment known as the "Tribunal Temple", which rules most of Morrowind through a merciful, but inquisitive, theocratic state. All of these factions are aware of prophecies of the acient island, and harbor dark secrets that are known to themselves and why they commit to their odd actions. The background lore is solid, with many books and inside lore to fill the mind of the confused player who is embroiled within this conflict. You must persuade and threaten everyone from simple commoners to living gods to determine what the whole scheme of things is and to reveal the whole plot to the player.ExplorationFrom artifacts to mundane bonemeal, you almost never know what you will find in the next cave or tomb you enter a stupid cave with nothing, or you could find a secret daedric ruin within a tomb, and follow it's path to find a long and sought after artifact! Only you can wll yourself to explore, and is there a LOT to explore. There are som many dungeons, so many caves and tombs, that I havn't even foud everything, and i've played this game for YEARS.Fully Customized CharactersYour cosmetics might not be that open to possibilities, but the stats of your character are completley open to experiment with. FInd the best combinations, etermine your playstyle, which can be literally ANYTHING you could imagine. Unlike in ES IV and V, your playstyle is not pushed in a certatin direction. Nope; you can be a jumping, fireball throwing lunatic, a naked sneak-theif, a half- naked mage, you can play however you like.Avid Modding CommuteEven though Ste.Wor.Sho.* doesn't support, their are 10,000's of mods out there for your choosing, from graphics to gameplay to sound and body mods, the mod community continues to thriveto this day. One mod that is essential, however, is the "Morrowind Code Patch" mod, which fixes many bugs and bad scripting that unfortunatly takes place in this game.Jump Across a Continet in under 5 min. of Gameplay!Pretty self explanatory, just go out of town and follow the path till you see a book on the ground and hear screams.ConsMelee CombatMelee combat is sadly a joke in ES III. Everything is based off of chance, and so you can be swinging a battleaxe into someone's face, but if your skill is too low, you still won't hit, which can be rather immersion breaking.Graphics didn't age wellTHis is an old game, and the graphics didn't age well at all. Bad polygon count, poor view range and bad lip synce plague this game. Many graphics mods change many of these features, however, and fix most problems quite nicely. Thank the mod community.Begginers BewareIf you don't know what you're doing, watch out, for yo will find yourself in the wrong cave fighting a level 30 monster who wants to rip your n*ts off. Just think carefully before you go anywhere to dangerous and don;t be afraid to run away if things get too rough.Need a wiki?Yes, even with it's deep, underlying story, some things are never explained in terms of quest objectives, what to do, as well as some lore issues, and some explanations as to where someone is. I presonally reccoment UESPWiki to help with many of your dilemas in this department.Overall, an ageless classic and well worth your time, for it lays down the doundations for many of the ground breaking features in later ES games, and introduces so many lore points tat willl you will be for more.
