number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I started with Skyrim and wanted to see where this crazy Elder Scrolls open world stuff really got started. I was not disappointed when I started playing Morrowind. The game is a bit dated, graphically and gameplay-wise, but I think it offers a lot of fun times and interesting ways to play. Pros: -text based dialogue gives more information and options that aren't limited by voiceovers-intricate magic and leveling systems allow for truly amazing customization -main quest is really interesting so far (I'm about 30 hours in)-the lore is vast, making it seem like a living, breathing world despite the aged mechanics-the creature designs are simply amazing... creepy and intimidating...-varied map makes the world seem even bigger than it is (in-game fast travel options add to immersion too)-in game strip club with some swag moves-score by the same guy who did Skyrim's soundtrack (and SW KOTOR and Bounty Hunter)Cons:-lack of tutorials means you have to either experiment for endless hours or get help online with gameplay mechanics-some stock dialogue gets repetitive-soundtrack is limited... you will hear the same explore tracks over and over again-graphics are dated (though I really enjoy the oldschool feel)-difficult to tell what you can and can't do in-game... some enemies look tough but get killed easily and vice-versa-those who know what they're doing can totally break the game and become godlike (Is that a con? Still not sure...)Basically, this game is really cool. Even if it were worse than Skyrim or Oblivion in every aspect, it's still really unique and offers a lot of cool exploration. I suggest looking up videos about why Morrowind is the best TES game. They'll do it more justice. I definitely reccommend this game to anybody who wants to see a little more of Tamriel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2013
												If you came into the TES series after Oblivion or Skyrim it may be very difficult to go back to this game, with its dice-roll combat and much, much slower-placed magic (and decade-old graphics). If you do not go back to this game, you are a philistine anti-hipster who hates everything that is awesome. Morrowind has the best setting in any TES game and possibly any RPG, with storylines you can explore and lore you can lose yourself in. It may not play half as well as the games that followed, but I still yearn for a TES game with half its imagination.But the cliff racers just suck.

I give Morrowind an 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Just Epic!I spent with this title many hours of my life and it still delights me. The world presented in Morrowind is really unique. You could say that the combat system and the graphics are old. But there are so many modifications to the graphics and the game itself (MGSO, MR, TR ...). You should also pay attention to the project OpenMW, which admittedly is still unfinished but thanks to it you can for example play Morrowind on multiple platforms (Mac , Win, Lin). The game can drag on for hours... and even if You put away this title for some amount of time... it contains this kind of magic, which makes You return to it... If You play, You'll understand charm of this game...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Insanely in depth, allowance to make nearly any character build you wish.   Become a Nord thief, an Elf barbarian, Breton smuggler, lizard who uses magic. God knows one of those combinations in game is going to kick your♥♥♥♥♥hard if you stick it out far enough.Intricate social interactions across multiple people and guilds.   People from other guilds will not like you, maybe. Maybe you'll be forced to kill a bunch of people who you could have joined. Join religions. Be a pilgrim, be a crusader. Join the local occupying imperial army. Join a mercenary guild with connections to the native crime syndicate, join the upstart crime syndicate in a turf war with that native crime syndicate. Get your♥♥♥♥♥rocked by the native ashlander tribes when you come bothering them because you're a dirty, filthy foreigner/outlander.Morag Tong > Dark Brotherhood.   Leave your edginess at the door. The Night Mother can step the ♥♥♥♥ off when it comes to the Assassins Guild of Vvardenfel. Honorable, working in the day, having actual writs of assassination that clear you of charges for killings. You just gotta find their base first.Vampires.   Three clans, three separate questlines. I always kill them because they're dirty abominations, but you can join them if you think your fedora is black enough and you have enough Xx_xX's in your name.Werewolves.   Yeah they're in here too.Dungeons.   Clear out a cave of dirty smugglers in the name of justice, leveling up, or some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ skooma. Raid an egg mine and ruin the livelihood of hundreds and the GDP of a nation. Clear out someone's family tomb or get split open by the daedric monsters guarding them. Bring a torch, Stranger.Storyline.   Wow...you can't do the storyline in one go immediately??? You need to actually get competent???? Skyrim is soooooo muchg beretter ♥♥♥♥ thsif game lolll.   Get competent and become a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hero. Running at 2mph at first level will be totally worth it when you're 25th level and creating magic boots that make you fly, getting swords that are literally on fire, and having the charisma to lead the local guild halls. None of that♥♥♥♥♥♥where you have 5 in almost every magic school and can become the archmage, LAME. You gotta work, and know people, and get in good with this nation that thinks you're a worthless outlander piece of trash. You're the ♥♥♥♥in' man, you just have to work for it. It's so worth it.This game is my mid-childhood. It's the basis of a very important aspect of my conscious. That's really deep, it's also really sad, but undeniably really true. Play the ♥♥♥♥ing game if you think you like Elder Scrolls, then play Daggerfall. Become elitist, you'll see you're right.

												Disclaimer: I have only played the three most-recent Elder Scrolls games: Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim. I am sadly ignorant on the quality of the earlier installments.---Morrowind is my favorite modern Elder Scrolls game. Period.There are some downsides. Graphically, Morrowind is increasingly dated. It comes from an unfortunately time (early 2000's) in history where full 3D games tried to portray realism without the resources to do so convincingly. Environments are fairly low res. As far as NPCs are concerned, they're not uncanny valley. They're just kind of crappy-looking, and lack the individual daily schedules that NPCs have in later games. Here, they wander within a short range, but people who you encounter outside will forever be standing outside, never to even set foot in their homes. Mechanically, the game can be rough around the edges. In Oblivion and Skyrim, furthering one's combat skill means increased damage. Starting out in Morrowind, low sword skill means you're unlikely to even hit your target when you swing. It's a steep curve, to be sure, and representative of how the game approaches skills and leveling up. Additionally, the quest log -- the game's system for tracking general learned information and info pertaining to specific active or inactive quests -- is unorganized and difficult to work with. It is barely a step above remembering what you're actively doing, and trying not to take up any other tasks until it is completed.So what really separates Morrowind from later Elder Scrolls games?The world is large and real. This isn't scandanavia or medieval England. This is a world unlike any other, with giant mushrooms and huge insects. It is interesting, unique, and worth exploring. And explore you will, because there is no fast-travel. The best form of transportation are via specific routes between certain cities -- boats, Mages Guild teleportation, large land beasts, etc. Anything else, be it going to off-the-beaten-path settlements, or simply getting to one of those hub towns, requires hoofing it. It adds a staggering degree of realism that later games stripped away. The world isn't actually larger, but the game presents itself that way. There are more guilds and organizations. More missions for those guilds. More cities, towns, and people. There's an openness to it because the cities aren't walled in, a separate level from the outside. The player also has a degree of agency that hasn't existed in Elder Scrolls games since. The degree of skill customization is extensive: more kinds of weaponry to specialize in, more kinds of armor, more branches of magic and spells within those branches. The player also has a lot more freedom to affect the world in permanent ways. You actions in one guild will affect other guilds. Everyone can be killed, including quest givers and NPCs integral to the main story. The world is yours to take. Oblivion introduced the concept of player-bought houses. No such game-sanctioned method exists in Morrowind. Instead, acquiring a house involves using your freedom. You could find a house that appears abandoned and move in, or you could find a nice house, murder the occupant, dispose of their body, and make it yours. There aren't items that are free to take and items that constitute stealing. There's just items, and you can steal them.The NPCs that inhabit Morrowind offer vastly more variety. With brief exceptions, the game has no voice acting. All dialogue is simply textual, and different personalities can be revealed through the text of their dialogue. Every NPC doesn't have the same voice, creating the impression of world populated by artificial clones. This fact alone almost certainly influenced the rest of the game, because it meant that something as simple as adding another Thieves Guild quest didn't involve more voice and audio work.This, in a way, describes the game as a whole. It's clear that, when the game was being developed, there was a lot more freedom to add content and run wild when developing the game. It bleeds into almost every aspect of the game. It's not as smooth, nor as pretty, as later installments, but it's a world worth exploring,

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a game that was constructed with one of the most developed atmospheres I've seen to this day. It is a unique experience that, although dated by today's standards, presents a beautiful sprawling world that the player can experience in almost any way they see fit. It consistently rewards curiosity and exploration with loot and lore crammed into corners where most people would never look. It doesn't showcase the "balanced" difficulty of the later elder scrolls games but in my mind that is a great advantage... it forces the player to really plan and manipulate all their available tools to survive an area that should really be too difficult for them. Similarly, as the player grows in strength, there is a point at which many of the enemies are fodder rather than a challenge, this takes a while to achieve and is actually feels really rewarding. While it hasn't necessarily aged well, there are plenty of mods that can bring things up-to-date without to much hassle. I wouldn't say Morrowind is perfect, especially nowadays, but it still holds a lot of its original charm. If you can get over the first couple humps of difficulty, there's a lot of worthwhile content, characters and environments to explore.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Still a masterpeice after all these years. Brings a tear to my eye. Seriously though, Morrowind has aged WELL. I got it on sale on Steam recently hit by a nostalgic urge to re-play it. Gave it a graphical mod, an animation mod and (what? I'm impatient) a stamina mod to let you run places and bam. Yes the combat is still clunky, but it's not BAD. At least it's tactical and not just the boring hack and slash Skyrim and Oblivion gave us. The magic in Morrowind is AMAZING - SO MANY EFFECTS! AAAAAAAAA! But yeah, one of my biggest issues with Skyrim was that it simplified magic. Heck, that was an issue I had with Oblivion! But in Morrowind magic really can do anything you could do but better. Except disarm traps. Yup, magical chest traps cannot be disarmed by Magic. Not that I know of. I haven't tried just shooting them yet. You could use Restoration to make yourself a GOD at picking locks for 10 seconds and disarm it with a probe, but that will burn magicka and that doesn't regenerate in Morrowind. Unless you mod it. Like me. Oh, one final point: Morrowind has Tamriel Rebuilt. That's a win in itself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												I played Morrowind for 2 years straight before I got into any MMOs and it felt as big as any MMO out there today. Thanks to today's addons for this game it helps replayablility. I do not use any mods that alter gameplay too much mind you, because the game itself is fantastic, I basically use addons to update the graphics.Morrowind has it's pro's and con's just like any other game. For me the pro's far outweigh the con's though.My Pro's:- Massive gameplay area, although not as big as Skyrim.- Tons of factions. 10+ all with their own quest chain.- Great houses. Choose between three great houses and complete quests. Ultimately you end up with a home, the location depending on the house you chose to join.- Lengendary items. Sure Oblivion and Skyrim have them also, but it seem that you get those from quest rewards. Morrowind rewards you with many of these by surprise.- Soundtrack is fantastic.Con's:- Slow start. Literally you start off so slow. You walk and run sooo slooow.- Attacking is difficult. With your low stats, you can be standing directly in front of a bad guy swinging like crazy but missing him. Of course all this goes away once you level up your skills.- Switching from magic to weapon is cumberson. There is no doubt Skyrim's dual hand abilities is leaps and bounds over Morrowinds combat system.- Quests are hard to follow. With so much exploration you come across a lot of quests, all kept in a journal. As well as any notable conversation. After hours of game play, quests are hard to follow and the journal interface is somewhat confusing to find things that may be important.Of course there are more minor ones, but these are the ones that stand out the most in my mind. Even though there are issues that impact the game, I can easily say that Morrowind is in the top 5 of my favorite games. A game that is truely epic. If you go off doing as many faction quests lines as you can, exploring as much as you can before completing the main story line, once you finish the game you will feel like you have been on an amazing journey.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24
												For me, this is the definitive open-world RPG. I don't foresee anyone ever making one I like more than Morrowind. Quest markers have since taken away the sense of immersion and adventure that you were given in Morrowind. You're expected to interact with NPC's, get information and vague locations through conversations, and find things by surveying the enviroment around you. It creates a genuine sense of intimacy with the world when you're familiarizing yourself with the geology and lore for the sake of navigation that you absolutely cannot get from following a compass at the top of your HUD. Character building is everything in Morrowind. You have to be very careful when you're spec'ing your character if you want to kill so much as a kwama forager once you leave Seyda Neen. If you're looking for an RPG with open-ended stat building where you can feel free to experiment, or switch to a different class type after several hours, Morrowind is not the game for you. How you choose your major and minor skills, your favored attributes, and your race determines how you'll play the rest of the game as that character. This may mean some trial and error to new players, I would definitely advise not to get too attached to your first character. What makes this game so addicting is the empowerment it gives you, and how rewarding it feels to get that power. There is little to no level-scaling in this game. You start out struggling to fight even the rats and mudcrabs, and very slowly become an unstoppable, even literal, god. While it may be too slow for some to retain interest, the slow gradual pacing is more fulfilling than anything Bethesda has released since. There are no hard caps to your power, either, as you can creatively enchant or brew your way to immortality if you've put enough hours in. This sounds overpowered and unbalanced, but the amount of work you have to put in to to reach this status never leaves you feeling cheated of an experience. You earn every increase in strength you get, but no matter how powerful you feel there is always something out there that can kill you if you're not careful. This is because you're not the only god on the island, and no NPC's are so important that they will go unconscious instead of dying.Dungeons are can be massive and rarely linear. Caverns have intersecting, winding tunnels, some of them underwater, some of them requiring levitation to reach. Each one is handmade, unlike Oblivion, and unlike Skyrim you feel like you're discovering them yourself, instead of tripping over new delves that you could already see on your compass anyway. Many open world RPG's fall into the trap of the world existing soley for the player, like no one actually lived there before you got there. If you don't want to feel like you're the first person to enter any of these 400 crypts in thousands of years, Morrowind will give you a breath of fresh air since everything feels very natural and lived in. Ancestral tombs are littered with offerings from visiting family members who paid their respects before you stepped in, caves are turned into furnished homes by smugglers and thieves, and ancient towers becomes fortresses to powerful archmages. Even when you do feel like you're the first person there in years, it's usually for good reason, with high leveled monsters and the bodies of lesser adventurers on the ground. Gold is a precious commodity, a design choice that has apparently become out of style in modern open world games. No matter how rich you get in this game, there is always something to spend your money on. Enchantments and skill training can quickly climb to astronomical numbers if you seek true power, but it's there to take if you're determined, unlike later installments in the series where gold essentially becomes useless after just a few hours. The legendary and mythical artifacts and weapons are not likely to bring you tangible wealth either, since no common shopkeeper is going to be able to afford these holy relics. This makes them feel more special, since you can't just sell your Daedric artifacts to some random bumkin in the imperial city for 2,000 gold. Some say the game has aged too poorly which might be true. The gameplay itself was divisive when it was released so I don't think it's fair to chalk that up to "aging" but the engine is obviously very dated, it can take some tweaking and modding to run on modern hardware and vanilla Morrowind only supports up to 1024x768 resolution. You'll immediately notice how short the render distance is. There are definitely a lot of things that Oblivion and Skyrim did a lot better than Morrowind could. The UI is very clunky. It's almost always obvious that you're playing a very old game.The most common complaint against the game though isn't the legacy software. It always seems to be about the dice-roll combat and the walking speed, which I think is what ultimately makes or breaks the experience so here's my thoughts on it. For the dice-rolling, people are turned off by statistic-based combat in a first-person view. If, for instance, you're shooting a bow while steathed, the arrow may go through the enemy but it will still roll a dice behind the scenes, in DnD fashion, to see if you miss, hit, how much damage. And there are many modifiers, such as your fatigue, skill level, governing attribute, specialization, etc. You roll misses pretty often and some people don't like this, which is totally valid. I've never seen why the two elements can't coexist or why people think it's inherently a bad design choice, but I do understand why some people would hate it. I've always been under the impression that the fights aren't visually supposed to be literal interpretations of the encounter: I think Morrowind works so well because the game is simple enough to let your imagination fill in the blanks, from the immense text, to the static NPC's, and the rng combat. If you were playing DnD with your friends, you would imagine the fight happening as it corresponds to every miss and hit and critical that you roll. Morrowind evokes the same type of lucid roleplaying where what you're seeing is more of a representation than an interpretation. As for the walking speed, it IS quite slow. Running uses your stamina which is essential for all combat classes, meaning there are times where you may need to walk if you're expecting combat in the near future. You can make yourself much faster through enchantments, spells, potions, etc. but for much of the early game you will be very slow. There is no fast travel, but there are boats and silt striders and teleportation spells that can take you to virtually every populated area in the game, but you can't open the map and choose a location. This means the game overall is a much slower paced, patient game than other open world games and it drives some people crazy.Obviously, both the walking speed and DnD combat can be changed to your liking with some very popular, very easily installed mods. With one of the most active modding communities on the internet even after 15 years, there's very little about the game you can't change to your liking at this point, yes even taking away random weapon misses. The buggy mess that Bethesda released in 2002 can now be comepletely polished and tailored to your specific preferences. I personally still play a mostly Vanilla build with only a couple hundred Audio/Visual enhancements with bugs and balance fixes for polish. Why change my favorite game anyway?

Posted: August 5, 2016
												The best world out of all the Elder Scrolls games imho; a truly alien fantasy world with its own alien culture, coinhabited by your more common fantasy tropes. Most factions of all the 3D Elder Scrolls games too, and each feels real with their relationships with each other and between people in the factions themselves being varied and diverse. You do need to love world exploration and quests more than action to get the most out of this game, but the overhaul mod does update the graphics into the "old school but beautiful" territory and modernize some dated choices in game design.If the world intrigues you at all, go for it and explore at your own pace!

content:

												This is hands down one of the greatest video games of all time! This is Skyrim's grand-daddy. When this game came out it was ground-breaking on just about every level. As I said, this is one of the best games in TES series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
The game that pushed the open world western RPGs to the next level.Pros Incredibly detailed and unusual fantasy world Original leveling system Incredible modding potential Best sky representation in it's time, especially the night sky Music, sound effects, voices Completely open world from the get-go Great main story Lots of quests to do Lots of factions and guilds to choose from Weather effects (especially ash storms) adds a lot of uniqueness to the enviroment Almost limitless potential in spellcrafting and enchanting Limitless character developement potential Large amount of weapons and armor to choose from Still runs fine after all these years Low HDD space requirement Tutorial is short but tells you everything you need to know You can become a vampire or a werewolfCons If you are not the patient type, travelling can be a chore No day and night cycle for 99% of the NPCs NPCs are mostly static and do not travel at all Lack of mounts Lack of player housing Fighting mechanics are clunky and barely exist Cannot fight and cast spells at the same time Character creation have very few options Leveling has some issues Character animaton is a mixed bag Useless 3rd person view optionWhat is this game?Morrowind is a first-person view based, open world, non-linear western style RPG released in 2002 for PC and later for the original Xbox. This is the 3rd main title in the Elder Scrolls series, the first fully 3D game and the first with 100% hand crafted enviroment. This version includes both official expansion packs released to the game. While the game is excellent by itself, it is highly modable and let's you upgrade almost all aspect of it. In my opinion it's significance can only be compared to GTA 3 and Final Fantasy VII in their respective genres. A must have experience for RPG fans everywhere around the world, highly recommened. NOTE: There are independent content patches for this game and I'm not sure if they are included in this version. These can be found on the Bethesda website.Long reviewFirst of all sorry about this 'short' review, I had to cut the review in half and redo it completely to fit it in this tiny space. Also this is my first review, so bare with me. Let's get on with it then. Let me start with the beginning, character creation and tutorial. You start as a prisoner released to freedom by the emperor. For what reason? That you'll have to find out in the main quest. Sadly the game don't have too many options coming to character creation, it's very simplistic. Rather focus your attention to your race, class and birthsign: these will determine how powerful your character will be at the beginning. Why just the beginning? Because there is no limitation in skill progression in this game. You can max out everything. To help out newcomers I give a nice melee character combo: Redguard - Knight - The lady. The first building serves as the tutorial area, so examine everything you find, or just skip it entirely. In this game nothing is forced on you. After you got your relaese papers and fee, you are free in every possible respect. While you got pointers to where to go first, you are not forced to, you are set to explore the island of Vvardenfell. At first it seems like just a regular fantasy setting, except for maybe the giant bug you see right next to the village. Yes, that is just the beginning.  As you venture into the island the first thing that stands out are the giant, 10 meters high mushrooms in the grasslands. And further traveling in the island there is nothingness. Vegetation gone and vulcanic ash everywhere. You bump into ancient ruins of Dwemer, Daedric and Dunmer in origin, far from being abandoned. You can find cities made of giant crab shells and magicly altered mushrooms. Your travels will be slowed by ash storms, thunderstorm and bandits. But you'll have to walk, as you have limited ways of transportation in this game. Not all is hostile to you tho. You can find several towns and cities with merchants and inns to sleep in, but most importantly you can find guilds and factions to join. They not just give you additional quests, but they will provide discounted services for you and additional storyline . Speaking of quests, there is of course a main story in the game, which I don't want to spoil too much, is a great epic journey of a prisoner becoming one of the empire's blades agents and at the end ascending to godhood. The main story is about politics, religion, revenge and redemption. You are going to set things right in this land. As your adventure goes forward you will learn a lot about this land and the empire from NPCs and books. Books are also good for leveling your skills, which is mandatory, as this game is all about skills. Skills can go from 0 to 100, representing your chance to succeed in use of given skill. This is important, as the game doesn't make it a secret that everything you do is based on those hidden dice rolls and skill chances. There are no mini games here, even your sword swing is just a start of a dice roll. Skill are also important in leveling up your charater as there is no XP in this game. Instead you have to level 10 major or minor skills to level your character. And when you do, you can increase 3 of your attributes. You can add a multiplier to those attribute levels by leveling skills governed by that attribute. While character creation is simple and hard to do unique characters, the itemisation is very extensive. You can choose from several armor sets and weapon types. If you do not prefer weapons, there is a huge selections of spells to choose from. Even better, you can create your own spell. You can also create magical weapons and potions in the game. Voice acting is good in the game, even if the game is not fully voice acted. Every race has it's unique voice in the game. The music is excellent, composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. While listening to the nice relaxing medieval melodies traveling the wilderness, it can quick turn to a battle chant when you got attacked. Outside of the game world one of the most important aspect is modding. This game can be modded by almost any way you want, or the engine lets you to. Glitches can be patched, graphical fidelity can be upgraded, new stuff can be added to the game. You can make this game feel and handle so much better if your are not satisfied with it's original ways. And there are some things to address here. The leveling system need some tweaking or complete overhaul. Character animation is bad for some races. Characters can use some more polygons just as better textures. A whole graphical overhaul is also can be on the table, especially the viewing distance. Player housing is completely missing from the game just like mounts. NPCs are few and very static with missing day/night cycles, you can change that too.ConclusionEven if the game has several faults, it is nothing short of an ambitious project succeeded. The game has a unique feeling to it, loneliness is weightet heavily on your shoulders as you traverse the vulcanic wasteland of the island or it's catacombs. As you progress through the game and a greater evil force your hand to act, you slowly find a purpose and a goal, even the gods starts to smile on you. It can take 100s of hours of your life easily with one character, not to mention more. I hope I've encouraged you to try this or any of the Elder Scrolls games, they are great experiences. Also, if you are looking for the previous games, you can download the Elder Scrolls 1-2 for FREE from Bethesda.Feel free to comment and send me messages. Good gaming everyone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												This is the defining game of the series, Oblivion and Skyrim, (both incredible, fantastic, amazing games), are really just simplified, almost dumbed down versions on THIS game, however, exicuted in a really great way. Morrowind allows freedom that the two games that followed just cant replicate. Spells, and enchanting bassically allow you to create things so powerfull, you would think it shouldnt even be allowed in the game, BUT, you can only achieve such things if you are smart enough to figure out how. Which brings me to my next point, everything in the game is layed out for you, the only things holding you back are skill levels. Once you get high enough levels, you can litterally make a spell to give you the abbility to fly, and shoot nukes at what ever the ♥♥♥♥ you want. You cant buy a house, but that doesnt mean you cant break into some dark elfs manor, kill him, and make his house your's. you can then drop your items where you want them to display them, tons of artifacts to collect. Bottom line, this game is very challenging, it sepparates the real gamers from the posers, the men from the children, It requires you to use youre head once, think about things, it doesnt force you to explore, it doesnt force you to talk to people, but if you dont, and you are lazy about it, this game will eat you alive, and you will be stuck. you literally have to LEARN.. you HAVE to learn, the lore, the skills, the weapons, the artifacts, the land, how to fight and survive. it makes the game very special, to me at the very least. You cant just bull♥♥♥♥♥♥your way through, quests are hard, there are no quest markers, dialouge is all text based. if you kill the wrong person you can doom the world which makes it impposible for you to finish the game or complete certain quests. the sad thing is, that its hard to get into this game these days, the graphics are dated for sure, the combat has some major flaws..  but if you can get past that, this game truely is brilliant, its fantastic, its simply more than words can describe. there is so much content, that im not sure any single person on this planet knows every little thing of information, item, or quest. If you think you can handle all of that.. then buy it, dont think, just do it. Oblivion, and Skyrim wouldnt exsist if this game wasnt so incredible, thats a fact.Edit: i will note that i only have 13 hours in this game on steam, but all of my play time comes from xbox when it was first ported. i was also only in 7th and 8th grade when i spent all my time playing this game.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I know I haven't played this game much, but hear me out. From what I understand, this is a wonderful game. I've not once heard anyone say that Morrowind sucked. However, I caution this:- The graphics have not aged well, which, I know is a deterent for many (myself included)- The combat system is frustrating. Unlike Skyrim and Oblivion, Morrowind runs on a dice roll system, which means that even if your weapon makes contact with the enemy, you might still have an awful roll, and you miss anyways. So if you miss, you miss, and if you hit, you still miss half of the time.I will still rate this game as positive as I have only heard good of this game. So, if you can get past the aforementioned points, I recommend you buy this game. If they sound like an issue, then I recommend saving your money. It may be a great game, but it really doesn't matter if the graphics and mechanics are frustrating.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												For someone who is used to modern RPGs, Morrowind will be incredibly difficult to get into and I imagine most people who pick this up expecting it to be like Skyrim or perhaps more Oblivion will be disappointed, frustrated and never play it again. I say this because that's exactly what I did around 2006 after playing Oblivion all those years ago. No voice acting, fast travel or map markers? Not worth my time, or so I thought.In 2012 one night, out of boredom, I saw my ancient Morrowind case and decided to give the game a shot again, with many years passed and more patience at my disposal, my view of the game transformed since I first shot it down. Morrowind is, without a doubt, the most complex open world RPG ever created- if not the last Bethesda game designed mainly with the PC in mind too.At the start, you are extremely weak, barely hitting anything despite your constant attempts, however, if you learn to accept this and venture forward boldly, you will be rewarded richly and your character has the potentional to feel stronger than any other game provides. Whereas in Oblivion the world scales for your character, in Morrowind your character scales for the world and you can definietly feel the progression.The dialogue is brilliant and even humorous on some occasions. Morrowind is a hostile place to foreigners and you definietly do feel unwelcome as opposed to being constantly showered in praise in Cyrodil, however, as time progresses, people start to respect you more on your feats and you feel accepted and even somewhat flattered. In regards to the actual place, Morrowind is extremely diverse due to it not fully accepting Legion culture. Dark elf civilizations differ vastly from other places and nowhere truly feels the same. Cyrodil and Skyrim are all quite similar architecturally no matter where you are, which makes sense as the races are all human in nature, but the same cannot be said for Morrowind and your eyes should never get bored, that is, if you can see past the view distance. Speaking of graphics, they are of course, terrible but you'll probably go and get some mods to fix that anyway. One thing you shouldn't change however is the music, which is of absolute quality and a pleasure to listen too.It's cheap, it's old, but seriously, if you're a fan of RPGs give it a chance. It'll make you realize just how dumbed down modern RPGs are.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												I have played hundreds of hours in Morrowind for PC since its release as well as the xbox version.Strenghts of the game compared to Skyrim The world and settings are interesting and have that mystic foreign feelings. Has a lot of factions and unique political struggle The sandstorm weather effect was one of the most interesting effects I seen in video games back in the days (though now MGSV does that better) There are more skills categories than both Oblivion and Skyrim. Plot is interestingWeakness and Outdated features Fighting is awkward and it is all based on how high your skill level is. There are bugs and techincal issues. Probably some game breaking bugs are still there so you might need to have lots of save games. Dialoug with NPCs is not as fun. It is all text and they talk in paragraphs.The game is recommended for those who are interested in Elder Scrolls lore. If you are new to the series, just pick Skyrim or Oblivion.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Skyrim 3: Morrow, I I MEAN ELDER SCROLLS...This game is pretty good for what it costs, but to be fair this game is kinda puny in Skyrim's huge shadow, but I won't be comaring this to Skyrim because this came out in 2003.  Gameplay wise it's not bad.  I feels like the weapons and armor you use give some personality to your play style, and there is a large array of weapons anddd armor.  I do especially like that there is no beginning mission that wastes 20-30 minutes every time you start a new game.  The world is most certainly a large and open land just waiting to be discovered.  But I can't praise this game with the problems that you do face, and all the things I mentioned already do have some problems within the good.The world, while expansive, feels confined to the path that is presented to you.  It never feels like you can go off the path, which makes all the area in between towns feel very dull and hollow.  Everytime that I came across a dungeon or a cave I would feel this overwelming joy of discovery, that would soon be lost seeing as all the dungeons are small, especially for the small amount of them there even are.  The combat is not very good because you hardly ever hit the target unless you are in their face and then you might just land a hit, and I am pretty sure that each hit only deals damage if you have some stamina which takes for ever to recharge.  The controls are the worst seeing as each button has a seperate funtion, which means you'll have about thirty keys in use for every thing and often get lost in your keyboard.  This also most definitly ties into the iffy combat.The functions and game modes that are in Morrowind are as expected, the open world and beautiful (I'll be it polygonal) that are home to your custom avatar, but the game does also have a very nice soundtrack.  Every track is full of magic and wonder that gets you in the mood for an adventure, and they melt from note to note perfectly, ESPECIALLY the opening theme.I usually would make a section for the basic layout of the story here, but the beauty of this game is that it gives you no story, which leaves you to do everything that YOU want to do.This game would be perfect in my opinion if all the problems with the controls where fixed and there were maybe a few more dungeons, but everytime that I load up this game, I hear that theme and I makes me calm and ready for any challenges that face my way.So in conclusion, my final rating for this game is a 6/10, probably 10/10 if not for so many problems.

												What can I really say about morrowind. It served me very well in my younger years providing me with a personal experience still unmatched by Most sandbox RPGS today. Anyone that has played Morrowind enough to overlook it's flaws will tell you that Oblivion and Skyrim feel like they take you by the hand and therefore feel less rewarding than Morrowind. Those people wouldn't be incorrect. This game really put the elder scrolls on the map and to this day gets me all nostolgic. If I were to explain this game it would take me all day. Thats how much content was crammed into this little masterpiece. It's easily moded using nexus and you can even play this game on Oblivion and Skyrim with the correct mods. Though I prefer to update the graphics and keep the same engine. This is a must buy for any Elder scrolls, modern Fallout or western RPG fan.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I have played hundreds of hours in Morrowind for PC since its release as well as the xbox version.Strenghts of the game compared to Skyrim The world and settings are interesting and have that mystic foreign feelings. Has a lot of factions and unique political struggle The sandstorm weather effect was one of the most interesting effects I seen in video games back in the days (though now MGSV does that better) There are more skills categories than both Oblivion and Skyrim. Plot is interestingWeakness and Outdated features Fighting is awkward and it is all based on how high your skill level is. There are bugs and techincal issues. Probably some game breaking bugs are still there so you might need to have lots of save games. Dialoug with NPCs is not as fun. It is all text and they talk in paragraphs.The game is recommended for those who are interested in Elder Scrolls lore. If you are new to the series, just pick Skyrim or Oblivion.

												I have to admit, this game is a little hard to get into due to ye olde graphicks. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												This is one of my favourite RPG games of all time. I perfer this more than the later games for a couple reasons. I think the biggests is because there is much less voice acting in this, most of the dialog is text based and as result you can ask NPC many more questions and they give long responses to your questions. Well that may not appeal to people with short attension spans, and I must admit I often skim the longer dialog, it makes the world feel so much more developed and you can learn so much about the back story of the world and the characters.  Secondly I really liked that this game didn't hold your hand when you were doing quests. Later games would literally show you exactly where to go, but morrowind would often just give a vague hint or tell you the descriptions of where you should go or who you should talk to. And there was no fast traveling, you can hop between nearby cities using two different modes of transportation, boats and these giant bug guys. Skyrim brought that back a bit with carts but morrowind did it better.Lastly, I love the art style and the world of this game. It is so unique and mysterious, you never know what to expect. Oblivion just didn't hit this button for me because it was more of a generic medeval fantasy world but morrowind felt like you were exploring a completely different world where people live the shells of giant creatures or in giant mushrooms or in magical cities run by gods that walk among mortals.However I will say that the game is starting to feel quite dated, I definately recommend modding this game like crazy to bring the graphics up to date. Luckily there are a ton of mods for this game and testing out different mods sometimes feels like half the game in itself.Anyway if you haven't tried it I recommend it because it was everything I liked in the elder srcolls before oblivion started watering things down to move more into the mainstream. Don't get me wrong I loved Oblivion and Skyrim too, but even after I got tired of those two I always like going back and playing morrowind.

But biggest thing new comers will notice you will have to always deal with the luck factor alway and a bit of skill and randomness.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Morrowind is an amazing open-world RPG that is definately worth playing. It is, in my opinion, the greatest of the Elder Scrolls games. You start out as a nobody; a prisoner boarding a ship to the island of Vvardenfell. You don't know why, but you have been sent to Morrowind. You must carefully choose a race, class, and skills to advance through the game as you see fit.      At this point, you can do whatever you want from this point on. You could join one of the Great Houses of Morrowind, join a guild, progress through the main quest, or just wander. You see a ancient burial site, explore it. You see an Ancient Dwemer ruin, go check it out. You see a daedric shine, go loot it. This is where Morrowind shines. There are so many dungeons that have no correlation with questlines. Exploration in this game is amazing.    The game also must be the most realistic of the franchise. It is hard calling a game with magic and giant floating jellyfish realistic, but the skill system is very good. You will hear many gripes about the combat in Morrowind, on how it takes dozens of hits to kill a mudcrab. You must work and hone your skills to become good at them. If you are highly skilled with a long blade, you will kill that mudcrab with ease. However, if you are a skilled mage, and you go stab that mudcrab with a spear, you will never hit it and your spear may break before you even kill the darn thing.    Morrowind's story tells a great tale, and is aided by a true sense of accomplishment that I have never felt in a game before. To avoid spoilers, you start out as a prisoner, like pretty much ever other Elder Scrolls game, and grow into something much, much greater. And the immersive atmosphere helps the story along just fine. It is true that Morrowind isn't the prettiest game out there, but the sound, lighting, and weather effects polish up your sorroundings.    When you progress, you will have to increase skills to level up. Upon leveling up you can approve your attributes (this is similiar to S.P.E.C.I.A.L in the Fallout series) and get a little motivational message. Accomplishment is well rewarded with a powerful weapon or item, and when you receive that weapon, you feel slightly more powerful. For the most part, enemies are not scaled. So when you do get that extremely powerful weapon, you feel extremely powerful. Soon you'll realize that there are stronger weapons to be found and stronger enemies to overcome. This process can repeat many times over.     There you have it, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. It is definately one of my favorite games of all time and worth the purchase.PS- Beware of Cliff Racers

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2011
												Morrowind is possibly one of the last RPG games before the (needed?) simplification of the genre: forget about map markings or arrows pointing to quest objectives; traveling is pretty much done "by foot", as the means for auto-travel are scarce - and the world is HUGE. Killed that random guy for no reason (he was part of the main quest)? Well, too bad, find something else to do. Morrowind will let you goof and you won’t know until it’s too late. Yet, this is an awesome game, in every aspect: you’ll walk a lot but, as a reward, you’ll find something new everytime; small things that make you want to explore just for the sake of it. Morrowind is rich in every aspect: lore, characters, environment, quests, soundtrack… if you can cope with outdated graphics and likes really challenging RPGs (Ultima series style), give it a try. It is definitely the best one of the Elder Scrolls games.Bethesda, remaster this game!!!

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Morrowind where a mudcrab can kill you without any effort if you anr't careful (has happened to me more time than I would like to admit). Where cliff racers *cringe* are the bane of your exsistance (may we all praise saint jiub for their eradication). How ever the story telling in this game is beyond amazing. the amout of time that must have gone into it just blows my mind. when i first played this game I was probably 8 or 9 years old and I couldm't even figure out how to sell thing (don't ask why, you won't get an answer because I'm still wondering that myself.). To now being 19 and managing to get nearly 2000g and nearly full armor before leaving the first town without commiting any crimes. There is so much to learn an do and explore without it all being shoved down your throat the entire game. With later entries in the seris (skyrim mainly) uping graphical quality, they also took away a lot of the aspects of morrowind that i found the most enjoyable. Many of wich are reducing the weapon varitiy found within the game. Skyrim has about 12 weapon types ranging from small daggers to bows. while morrowind has nearly that many types of swords alone. As well as diffrent skills for diffrent weapon types so axes and swords dont fall into the skill. And the last thing I'm going to mention here is somthing that i fell compares morrowind to skyrim fairly well (sorry for only really comparing these two games, I haven't played enough of Oblivion to make viable comparisons) "Morrowinds way of telling a story is very novalistic in its exicution, it may not be the fastest paced but It's nearly impossible to put down. While Skyrim is very much cinimatic it the wayit was made. Very flashy and nice to look at, but really lacking the depth and emotion of the original source material. Sofor those who prefer the noval over the movie I belive morrowind may be the game for you. 10/10 would recomend

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Morrowind is really a masterpiece RPG, one I've played since I got a copy in 2003. It can be difficult at early levels, but honestly, there's nothing too hard about it. A lot of problems that new players find have simple solutions.Think movement is too slow? Go with Sign of the Steed.Can't hit anything? Stop running around near monsters. Slow down. Or pick Sign of the Lady for the +25 Agility, or Warrior for the all-around attack boost. Or make sure your racial weapon bonuses and class bonuses line up with your weapon.Still having trouble with Stamina? Amulets of Stamina are pretty easy to find once you get to Balmora. Just visit the enchanter in the Mage's Guild, or spend some pocket change hopping between the guilds until you find one.Is money getting you down? Sell everything you find, do some quests. You'll have more than you know what to do with soon enough.Game crashes a lot? Save often, or get patches. Actually, do both. The Morrowind Code Patch is amazing, and saving often, in different slots, never hurt anyone.Can't fight off chains of Dark Brotherhood Assassins who keep interrupting your rest? You got me there. Those guys are pretty tough. Don't wander so far from civilization that you can't take some trips to Ebonheart after your first attack, I guess.Enemies to watch out for early on include ghosts (you will want silver or magic weapons for them), that mage in the newbie cave (he might kill you in 1 hit, often takes 2), and pretty much any enemies in dungeons that aren't in the starter area. Not all dungeons are like this, but save before you check out each one.Once you get the hang of the game, you'll find that everything you do can be OP if you play your cards right. I've walked into Daedric ruins at level 2/3 and killed some of the high-level NPCs in there for really nice loot, like Ebony and Orcish armor. It took a lot of potions, but it was worth it. (Hint: save your game before you try some as inherently suicidal as this).Final advice: save often. Especially if you like jumping.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												This might be my favorite game ever.  The atmosphere draws you in with good music and a totaly alien looking landscape. flora, and fauna, which makes you more interested in the lore.  Learning the lore pretty tedious since its all done through reading in game conversations and books, but the effort increaces the immersion.Combat is pretty terrrible though.  It consists almost exclusively of you clicking over and over again to land a hit about 1 out of 10 times while some old lady calls you an N'wah or S'wit continuously until she finally dies so you can steal every last shoe, plate. and pice of saltrice in her house to sell to the local pawn shop.The choices you make have little affect on the world, exept that killing the wrong guy can ♥♥♥♥ vaardenfell's fate up so bad that Dagoth Ur's victory becomes a forgone conclusion, but all that really means to the player is that you cannot complete the main quest line.  And it will tell you if you do this so you can reload.At the time this game was released it was groundbreaking.  It probably dosn't seem like a good game by todays standards, but people interested in the elder scrolls series that got into it a bit late could find morrowind to be an interesting iteration of the series.Also try Daggerfall or as I call it "get stuck for 9 hours in a maze so complicated that the 3d map cant even help you find the exit, then delete the game and look up the story online to see what you missed."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Morrowind is by far the best Elder Scrolls in the series. It is a game with depth but simplicity and the mix works perfectly. In Morrowind the world is expansive and there are plenty of things to do, as it is in all Elder Scrolls games but Morrowind expands that freedom more than any other game. For example, in Skyrim when you defeat the Stormcloaks and take victory for the Imperials, guardsmen and foot soldiers treat you as if you are just a regular person getting in the way of "their" business, but in Morrowind when you reach high ranks as an Imperial Legionnaire you are addressed by your rank and respected by lower ranks. The game also brings in a small piece of politics when you choose one of three houses working towards ruling Vvardenfell. The game also adds in simplicity. If you’ve ever played Arena or Daggerfall then you understand how complicated things were, doing quests and keeping up with them was a chore, finding locations and fighting were also very clunky points in those games, but in Morrowind you are given a journal that organizes everything much easier, and the fighting (all though it’s not perfect) has been greatly improved. Traveling is more fun and entertaining then is hard and painful. But the game does have its problems for instance, the fighting, while it has been improved, is very clunky, it’s hard to hit enemies when you're right in front of them, the Brightside to this is after progressing and playing for some time you seem to get used to it. Another small issue is that some of the enemies are too difficult to fight; it’s a problem when you can beat the final boss with no problem but a Cliff Racer can destroy you because it can fly.Overall the game only has a few problems that are easy to get passed. If you're looking into this game because you've played  another Elder Scrolls game or are just interested in it, the game it amazing. Morrowind has a vast amount of side-quests and storylines, great structure, a huge amount of enemies, weapons, armor, spells, and items. The game's world is vast and beautiful, and the expansion packs are perfect with this game. After years of playing this game off Steam, I'm glad to have gotten it on Steam to replay it again and again.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The game that made me love RPG's, the game that made me into a gamer (even if I don't find ones comparable to this first love)! I still remember seeing it on a shelve 12 years ago, and wanting to play it just by reading the description..It is one of the most complete and heroic games of all times. It's better than Oblivion and Skyrim put together. You can do everything, you can customize your spells, your house, choose which guild you want to support, participate in political plots with the Noble Houses, loot dungeons, talk with the Gods, take part in initiatic rituals, invoke deadly creatures. You can be whoever you want to be, a proud Dark Elf to a rejected Argonian.Nothing feels invented in the game, the immersion is total. Even when you enter more desolate parts of Vvardenfell, you feel like you are there. Years after, the graphics still matter, the music feels the same, the architecture is stunning. With or without mods, this is one of the most amazing things ever created, it just has this magic, this special feeling that others don't have.I must warn you, Nostalgia will hunt you for years after playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This is one of the first games that made my jaw drop (minor spoilers may follow). Yeah, its pretty dated in terms of graphics and mechanics now, but in my opinion it still holds up as the best TES game yet. Does the game have issues? Hell yes it does - from kind of static, stat based combat, through a cluttered inventory system, quest breaking bugs, terrible character animations, and sometimes unintuitive navigation and progression. The thing is, that even those things, in my opinion, don't detract from the overall game. It still has probably the most interesting setting out of all TES games, with deep lore and inter-faction intrigue. All this set against a main plot about, in now typical TES fashion, being the messiah. The difference, compared to Skyrim, for example, is that Morrowind makes you work for it. You don't get to be the savior after a couple of hours of gameplay - you'll have to prove yourself in front of several faction leaders, and deal with religious persecution along the way.You can join and rank up in any faction, some of which prevent you from joining other competing ones, and take part in quests which range from common item fetching, assassinations and monster hunts, to some actual problem solving and investigation - something that later games in the series rarely provide. What, again, differentiates Morrowind from the 4th and 5th installments is the lack of handholding. The quest arrow you probably got used to is nowhere to be found and the game will actually require you to find places, items and people on your own, providing, sometimes vague, directions from NPCs. You may find this annoying and tedious, but, in my opinion, the final result is that the game doesn't treat you like an idiot who can't find his or her way around and actually believes, that you can make it on your own. The world has enough distinct landmarks and locations to make the directions given by NPCs sufficient to get you where you need to go. Mechanically, apart from the stat based fighting, it's the most complex TES game next to Daggerfall, but it gets rid of a lot of pointless passive skills while still providing a lot of variety in terms of possible builds. Typical of the series, you level up by actually using the skills and with enough effort you can max out everything. Can't be bothered to develop a particular attribute or skill? You can probably either make a potion for it or charm an item. And because the game distinguishes between between left and right for things like gloves and shoulder pads and includes belts, armored pants, regular pants and shirts as separate wearable items - the possibilities of customisation are probably larger than in most other games. The magic system is really flexible, allowing you to choose between ready-made spells, making your own crazy spell effect combinations (provided you have the gold, skill and mana pool to pull it off), or simply charming a piece of your armor to let you cast any spell available ingame with the item's separate, rechargeable charge. Additionally, the game doesn't restrict particular spells to specific items - if an item can handle the power of the spell, you can charm it. Want to cast fireballs with the rate of a machine gun? You can. Want to make a ring that lets you perform quarter mile long jumps while slowing your fall? You can. If you get your head around the mechanics of the game, you can do anything.So, how does the game hold up after over 11 years? Surprisingly good. Sure, textures can get pretty blurry up close, and animations aren't anything to brag about, but at the same time the whole explorable area has a very unique and varied style and atmosphere to it. You get your typical medieval towns, castles, forts, tribal camps, cities within large pyramid-like structures (including the capital, Vivec, made out of several such sections), run down swamp and coast towns, and - probably my favorite - cities with buildings made out of giant crab shells. And if you're still put off by the visuals, the game can be modded to a state that gives Skyrim a run for its money. By now you can get mods for anything, from textures, models, lighting and sound effects, to animations, as well as additional factions, quests, locations, items, and - under continued development - a recreation of the rest of the province of Morrowind based on lore and developer notes with its own towns, quests, and new, harder monsters. Additionally, the community managed to fix most of the bugs that Bethesda managed to miss over the years. Morrowind, unlike the most recent installment in the TES series, is not a game for everyone - especially, if you're a fan of the recently omnipresent streamlining of everything. You'll probably have to get over several hurdles along the way, and the game has its problems, sometimes major ones, but for someone who wants to go really deep into mechanics, exploration and customization, this one is highly recommended. Get it, if you havent done so yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												If you're looking for Skyrim but the older graphics, this isn't the game for you. If you're wanting to see how Skyrim and The Elder Scrolls Online came to be, then it might be worth it for you. If you love the worldbuilding that's been done in Skyrim and other Elder Scrolls games and you're not adverse to some older game design and graphics, then definitely consider this.For a game that I have much love for, the above might seem to be a lot of qualifications. It's important to understand that Morrowind was the last "PC design" of the ES (Elder Scrolls) games. While the ES games have continued, their design philosophy and approaches to game systems jumped to a whole different track. Oblivion was the introduction of the gameplay systems you see in the current ES games and was an extremely limited feeling game in comparison. It also helped push the ES games from being niche rpgs into a larger recognition.Who's going to like this game? Folks that have a nostalgia for older game design, and people that love the worldbuilding of ES games and want to get more into the created world. The game has some seriously twitchy technical issues, mainly brought about by how much the hardware and operating systems have changed since it was released and now. You can certainly run it on modern systems, get mods that modify the textures and help fix other things, but there's still an element of software glitchiness you're going to have to deal with.Do I recommend the game? Most definitely. It's a game that's more...relaxed...in having the player get into stuff and explore the world. It's also a game that has 4 or 5 other games before it, of varying degrees of quality, which helped to inform and shape the design of Morrowind. And the worldbuilding that went in with all of the other games blossoms into life in Morrowind.

One of the most addictive, time consuming games I've ever played.Granted, the game has aged a little and its graphics might be off-putting to younger players but it is an absolute essential.When I first played it, it took me about three weeks of roaming around and side-questing before even getting to the main quest. And don't forget that the modding community, as for all TES games, is simply awesome and offers an amazing amount of content.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Ah, Morrowind.  I can't think of any other game I get quite as nostalgic about.  It's one of the few that I don't feel a certain sense of disappointment when I go back to play it after a while without it.  Containing one of the most unique and intriguing fantasy settings I've ever encountered, Morrowind is an open-world CRPG par excellence.  Its world feels alive and expansive in a way future entries in the series did not, though its quest tracking does leave a bit to be desired.  I've never played another game that I can recommend quite as highly as this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												The game that made me love RPG's, the game that made me into a gamer (even if I don't find ones comparable to this first love)! I still remember seeing it on a shelve 12 years ago, and wanting to play it just by reading the description..It is one of the most complete and heroic games of all times. It's better than Oblivion and Skyrim put together. You can do everything, you can customize your spells, your house, choose which guild you want to support, participate in political plots with the Noble Houses, loot dungeons, talk with the Gods, take part in initiatic rituals, invoke deadly creatures. You can be whoever you want to be, a proud Dark Elf to a rejected Argonian.Nothing feels invented in the game, the immersion is total. Even when you enter more desolate parts of Vvardenfell, you feel like you are there. Years after, the graphics still matter, the music feels the same, the architecture is stunning. With or without mods, this is one of the most amazing things ever created, it just has this magic, this special feeling that others don't have.I must warn you, Nostalgia will hunt you for years after playing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Morrowind is by far the best Elder Scrolls in the series. It is a game with depth but simplicity and the mix works perfectly. In Morrowind the world is expansive and there are plenty of things to do, as it is in all Elder Scrolls games but Morrowind expands that freedom more than any other game. For example, in Skyrim when you defeat the Stormcloaks and take victory for the Imperials, guardsmen and foot soldiers treat you as if you are just a regular person getting in the way of "their" business, but in Morrowind when you reach high ranks as an Imperial Legionnaire you are addressed by your rank and respected by lower ranks. The game also brings in a small piece of politics when you choose one of three houses working towards ruling Vvardenfell. The game also adds in simplicity. If you’ve ever played Arena or Daggerfall then you understand how complicated things were, doing quests and keeping up with them was a chore, finding locations and fighting were also very clunky points in those games, but in Morrowind you are given a journal that organizes everything much easier, and the fighting (all though it’s not perfect) has been greatly improved. Traveling is more fun and entertaining then is hard and painful. But the game does have its problems for instance, the fighting, while it has been improved, is very clunky, it’s hard to hit enemies when you're right in front of them, the Brightside to this is after progressing and playing for some time you seem to get used to it. Another small issue is that some of the enemies are too difficult to fight; it’s a problem when you can beat the final boss with no problem but a Cliff Racer can destroy you because it can fly.Overall the game only has a few problems that are easy to get passed. If you're looking into this game because you've played  another Elder Scrolls game or are just interested in it, the game it amazing. Morrowind has a vast amount of side-quests and storylines, great structure, a huge amount of enemies, weapons, armor, spells, and items. The game's world is vast and beautiful, and the expansion packs are perfect with this game. After years of playing this game off Steam, I'm glad to have gotten it on Steam to replay it again and again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												Many people who try Morrowind don't give it much of a chance; they play for maybe half an hour and either say "This is too boring!" or "This is too hard". But with a game this vast, not even an hour or two, let alone half an hour, is nearly enough time to take it all in. The level of detail is astounding, especially when compared to it's sequels. Oblivion was a reletively large area with only a few different landscapes, and each location seemed reminiscent of the last, and while Skyrim is a huge game, full of detail, it still lacks the complexity of Morrowind. For anyone tolerant enough to get over the sub-par graphics (they were fantastic for their time however), and anyone patient enough to get over the initially frustrating combat system, they will love this game for it's diversity, complexity, and character. If you're a fan of Elder Scrolls games, but have only tried the latest ones, or a fan of RPGs in general, get this game. At $20, you get what you pay for and then some.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Ah ElderScrolls III Morrowind.For this review I need to point out that I did not play this game when it first came outso I'm not running on nostalgia goggles here.At first it didn't seem that I would like this game initally. Compared to The Elder Scrolls IV Oblivion (the first game of the series I played) it seened so damn Archaic. I didn't think I would be able to enjoy it. This game seemed so much more difficult to start off and the mechanics are much older. However once I really sat down and played for real I was hooked. The game even after all this time is still an outstanding game with a refreshing fantasy setting and great story with an even greater lore. If you want a real challenge and a good RPG story this is an excellent game. However a word of a warning. Although I admit I'm still fairly new to The Elder Scrolls Series (as a someone who had only played on Nintendo platforms for most of their life until recently)  I own Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim on PC via steam.I have seen the trend many refer to as "dumbing down" and I'm afraid I am in agreement with this term. This game is much more difficult than skyrim and has almost a completely different method of mechanics in terms of gameplay (Leveling and combat) and functions with quest work (I.E being promoted in factions/directions/Quest orgainzation) I can only recommend this game to Gamers who have the patience to work with a more complex gameplay and input anymore effort into a character. If you can, outstanding! Play this game and have fun. And you don't then please continue to play other games that you enjoy. Its your loss.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Morrowind is one the best open world roleplaying games ever made, with astounding game play variety, with a beautiful yet unfamiliar world that feels more original and fresh than the more conventional European fantasy formula settings of its sequels Oblivion and Skyrim. I played it on disc extensively when it originally came out and I still discover new things about the game and its world. The huge modding community for this game makes it ever better, updating graphics and sounds, and fixing bugs with unoffcial patches, Mods also add substantial new content and gameplay. Morrowind, however, is a harder game than Oblivion or Skyrim, and it has dice-rolling mechanics in the background that may at first seem less than intuitive. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Morrowind, "one of the best in the Elder Scrolls series" is what most of the people were saying before I played it. First time I played this as a kid but I didn't know how to play it and I thought I should give it another try after playing Oblivion and Skyrim.I would have to agree one some part - story is really the best thing in the Morrowind, how it expands and how it ends. I was amazed all the time and I wasn't dissapointed at the end.POSITIVE:- Story- Quests (there is a lot of variety and it doesn't feel like they are generic. Compared to Skyrim and Oblivion, much better!)- Exploration- You can really put a lot of creativity in spells and enchantments - No quick way to travel is what makes the adventure great. This adds a lot to the feeling of adventure.NEGATIVE:- It can be hardcore for most of the players (decisions that may have a big impact, fighting...)- there is no quick way of traveling except striders & boats & some teleports. Yes, you will have to walk.- some unecessary encounters ( yes Cliff Racers, I'm talking to you!)Overall, I think a lot of people will find Morrowind hard to get into but if you prepare and put some hours into the start I'm sure it will pull you in.Please note that I've played a lot more than 10 hours but it was not on Steam. Even though I've spent quite some time in the game I only scrached the surface since I was following mainly a main quest line.CONCLUSION: Yes, if you are a huge fan of RPG games, this is something you should play becuase it is one of those game that will stay with you forever.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Morrowind is the best game in the Elder Scrolls franchise hands down. The gameplay is second to none, as for the graphics, you could download a mod to upgrade them, or you could play the game how it's supposed to be played. I chose the latter. The game itself can be a bit aggrivating at times, missing most of your swings in the beggining (upgrade your agility and that won't happen, random mobs hindering your ability to heal, and it took me awhile to get used to not being able to fast travel. But, the selling point in this game is it's compelling storyline (not found in skyrim or oblivion); from starting out a prisoner, to defeating Dagoth Ur and fufilling your prophecy this game is a rollercoaster. It's worth the ride, but it's not for everyone. Once you get used to the graphics, you'll be in for the story of a lifetime.

content:
Posted: January 5
												You know, Im in an Odd position reviewing Morrowind, I started playing the Elder Scrolls Games with Skyrim, and I will honestly say, I enjoyed Morrowind so much more than I ever enjoyed Skyrim.The game hasen't aged well, thats for sure, but that isn't somthing which really drags down an expierence with the game, Just because its an old game doesn't mean It can't be a fun experince, this is the mentality I had going into Morrowind, and maybe because of that, I came out loving the game.It told a story I felt I was so much more intertwined with than later games in the series, I was never treated as the chosen person to be this and that and pretty much the leader of everything, The game made you earn things, and I loved that, I loved how I was just some outlander who had to make his way into some form of respect, and even more work to climb higher than that, Even in the main story where your destined to become a great hero, you still have to earn it far more than later games ever made you.As for mechanics, I can understand how it can be frustrating to some missing 9/10 of there swings or spells, but of course, with time you as a player can understand how the system works (Heres a hint for you new players, pace out your swings, don't spam it), and as a character to miss more like 1/10 of those swings or spells, and you can see that as your character improving as time goes on, lets be honest, your character is thrown off a boat knowing nothing, and of course your going to have to learn via trial and error, and I love how the game puts you through that, Rather than just being able to do all that right off the bat as later games allow you to. I also throughly enjoyed the ammount of customisation you had, how many skills there were to level up, though it may be more tedious, the reward is far more worth it because of it.All in all, I loved Morrowind, I can confidently say its a great game that I would reccomend people try and give a chance to with an open mind, you'll certainly come out with a great experience if you do.(Also, Hey look, a Positive Morrowind review from someone that doesn't have Nostalgia for it)

content:
Posted: February 24
												The best Elder Scrolls game by a long way. The atmosphere is cruel and alien, the game is unafraid to tackle issues like slavery and the story is nuanced and interesting.The gameplay mechanics are that of a true RPG. You start as an everyman, with little to no skill in anything. For those complaining that the game is bad because they can't hit anything, go out and pick a fight with a trained swordsman in real life and you'll soon see that Morrowind's system is pretty realistic.A true RPG and not nearly as arcadey and casual as the mechanics of Skyrim or Fallout 4.Mods available to make it run at modern resolutions.
