content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
One of the best things that have ever happend to RPG genre.This part of Elder Scrolls saga is one, that gives you TRUE freedom, unlike it's younger and more casual-firendly cousins, Oblivion and Skyrim.Cities are openYou can levitate (and game really makes use of it, it's not just a useles gimmickYou can create our OWN spells (if you cheat enough money, you can create a spell that kills whole population of Balmora- one of the cities in game)And many more.This is a game, for people who want to immerse in a game, and feel like really being the protagonist they're playing asThere is no quest markersThere is no real quest log - only journal. If you want to finish that quest you started back in the beggining of the game, you've got to go through a couple of dozens pages that you filled up during your journeyAnd again, many many more.Finally. Skyrim is a game, in which you fight dragons. Morrowind is a game, in which you fight ♥♥♥♥ING GODS. Isn't it enough badass? Go play this game if you haven't already. Espiecially if you started your adventure with Elder Scrolls with Skyrim. But don't expect it to be "nice". This game is brutal for newcommers.You will start with basicly no decent tutorial.You will have no idea how to navigate through this massive and (unlike Skyrim) alien and full of surprises land of Vvanderfell.You're gonna die. A lot.You're gonna have hard time trying to find a 10cm^3 dwemmer cube in bigass ruins without any clue where to start, or any quest marker.You're gonna get a disease and spend hours trying to cure it.You're gonna help a nice lady, who's ring fell into that small pond.You're gonna regret it.And lastly, if you're anything like me You're gonna love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Without a hero, the prophecy can never be rendered so, but Morrowind is its own hero. It is not a game of beauty nor is it a game of finesse - though it might've been both in its day - instead, it is a game with character. Morrowind truly established the reputation of the epic RPG series The Elder Scrolls in the modern day, so it's no surprise that with a mind opened outwards to gaming's past, one can find a game that they love just as much as, or better, than Oblivion or Skyrim. The story is fantastic; without issue you can feel the weight and gravity of it all, and it lives up to that feeling from when you're walking to Balmora dressed in a mess of Iron and cloth and when you're ascending Red Mountain in a shell of Glass. The atmosphere is too--the only issue left behind is the combat. Unlike Skyrim and Oblivion, the combat here is decided by complex "dice rolls" and not by contact alone. If you can get past the admittedly sometimes frustrating combat and enjoy the game in everything else it has to offer, you'll be finding an experience without rival. It deserves a chance from you, and it deserves the "Test of Time" Award just as well.

												Ein Spiel ungeahnter Größe! Auch wenn die weite, unglaublich facettenreiche Welt in Morrowind grafisch ein wenig an Glanz verloren hat, zeigt Bethesda in diesem Klassiker wie viel Atmosphäre ein RPG haben kann. Eine Geschichte voll Helden, Krieg, Religion, Macht und Lokalpolitik in der Dunkelelfenregion rund um den Roten Berg.Der angegrauten Grafik sollte man mit der Mod "Morrowind Overhaul - Sound and Graphics" auf die Sprünge helfen (bitte beachten, dass dafür die englische VErsion installiert ist). Ebenfalls empfehlen sich "Morrowind Better Gameplay" und der "Morrowind FPS Optimizer" für frustfreieres bzw. hochauflösenderes Spielvergnügen.

												-I took all Endurance, Willpower and Personality skills for my major and minor skills.-got to about level 8, purposefully steal something to put a bounty of 15 gold on myself. None of the Ordinators care. So I go talk to one and resist arrest. Then I levitate above him, kill him and then sell the armor to Wayn in the Balmora Fighter's guild.-get something like 12k gold per Ordinator killed. Spend it all on training in Balmora. Only have 15 bounty...-I repeated this from level 8 to level 32. I maxed all my attributes (besides luck) by level 35.-Power through all the Quests in the: Mage's guild, Fighter's guild, Morag Tong, Thieves guild, Imperial Legion, and House Telvanni.-Start the main quest at level 41 and with 46 reputation.-Decide to turn the difficulty up to 100 before doing any main quest objectives.-Power through the main quest, get to Red Mountain. Spend two hours destroying all signs of the Sixth House and explore all regions within the ghost gate.-Saved Dagoth Ur for last, destroyed that guy.-Spend hours hunting for Golden saints and start tribunal in order to get a set of full deadric armor.-Collect all Exquisite clothing.-Enchant all armor and clothing to have a grand total of: +106 strength(206 total), +48 speed(148 total), Heal 7 hit points per second(constant effect), heal 14 fatigue per second(constant effect) and have 20 night eye(it's just convenient).i'm level 51 and have over 70 reputation.I've loved this game since bfore i knew how to read. This was the second time i've beaten the game, and I was only capable of beating the game AFTER I learned how to read. It's great. Take time to read Dialogues/books, the story is amazing!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Morrowind was the first Elder Scrolls game I ever played.  I thought the game was fantastic at the time, and I still do.  There is some warning which should be given to people who have played the newer games first, and want to go back in time to try this one.  There are differences which you may find annoying.  This review is targeted towards people who have played the newer games but not the older ones.  If you are completely new to the series, and are thinking about starting with Morrowind, then there are older reviews which can summarize the experience without comparing it to anything else.I will refer to many things as a "change" even though this game did them first.  This is because I am making the comparison as if the newer games were played before this older one.Lets start with the Pros.  I will be vague about this since there are so many things that make the Elder Scrolls amazing, and the majority of the pros are shared across all games in the series.- Amazing Story:  This has the same immersive story and quality that you have come to love in the other games.- Amazing Environment:  Morrowind has the most varied and exciting environment of any Elder Scrolls game to date.  From burnt, ashy volcanic regions, to  snowy northern islands, to the swamps in the south, and everything imagineable in between.  Vvardenfell is superior in every way to any other location ever used.  It's something which you need to experience to appreciate.  Once you explore Vvardenfell, you will realize just how boring and repetitive the locations in Oblivion and (especially) Skyrim are.- Weapon Variety: Morrowind has more weapon categories than newer titles like Skyrim and Oblivion.  Favorites of mine are spears and crossbows, but there are a few more.  To be fair, Skyrim has crossbows, but as a part of a DLC.  You get them as part of the game right off the bat in the case of Morrowind.  There are also throwing knives, darts, and stars, throwing weapons which don't make an appearance in Skyrim and Oblivion (to my knowledge).- Levitation: You can fly!Now we can explore some differences which are quite broad and affect many parts of gameplay, meaning they can have both good and bad effects.- Weapon Behavior: This is a big one.    1) In combat, there are many, many instances where you will swing at an enemy and miss, regardless of how well you are aiming.  Morrowind uses your character statistics (and the stats of whatever you are attacking) to determine what percent of your attacks will hit.  This can leave combat feeling VERY disappointing during early game while your stats are low.  As you progress and these stats get better, there is a great feeling of power as your hours of practice pay off and you find yourself landing nearly every hit and inflicting massive damage on your foes.  There are rarely miracles in Morrowind.  If an enemy is just too powerful for you, you need to come back to them later when you are stronger.  You wont be able to use trickery or exploits as much as you might think, because the stats don't lie.  If your character is too weak, you will lose.      2) Weapons in Morrowind truly feel special.  There are noticeable differences in the way each one behaves.  Short blades are fast, extremely close range weapons.  If you are good, they are great for landing many fast hits and dealing small amounts of damage repeatedly until your foes are defeated.  Long blades are slow and powerful, spears even more so.  These will require knowledge of how quickly your enemy swings, so you can time your attacks between theirs, and retreat when necessary.  These are slower, more methodical weapons, and they have incredible range.  Bows and crossbows behave as you would expect, but remember to keep in mind that you need to be good with these for your attacks to actually connect.  Bows allow for more input, allowing you to use the appropriate balance of power and speed for the situation.  Crossbows are simple, one power setting, a slow reload, and a lightning fast projectile.  Fantastic.- Character creation:  Character creation gives you more freedom as to the backstory of your character.  You can change Race (as usual), select a premade class (absent in Skyrim) or create a custom one yourself, and choose a star sign (also absent in Skyrim).  The combination of these three things can lead to some extremely unique and customized characters.  You can fine tune them a lot more, which is a welcome change to personalize who you play as (and I missed the freedom in Skyrim and Oblivion).  Star signs are very cool because they do so many things, from passive, always active abilities, to temporary abilities and spells you can use once a day.  And you get all this, ready to go, the second your character creation is finished.  So what's the catch?  Well, there are no sliders to fine tune your characters body and face.  As someone who plays with first person camera on, I don't see my character all that much anyways.  This is not a game which uses cutscenes, so I find myself more appreciative of the ability to fine tune performance over appearance.- Dialogue:  Morrowind has a lot more dialogue than you are probably used to in the other games.  This means that a compromise had to be made somewhere along the lines.  Probably the most jarring switch from a newer game like Oblivion and Skyrim to an older one like Morrowind, is the lack of voice acting.  There ARE some lines which are audible, but be prepared to do a lot of reading.  If you find yourself pressing the skip button during conversations with NPCs in Oblivion, Skyrim, and Fallout, this is a welcome change, as you can read the dialogue at your own pace, and you can even save it for later if you wish to read your journal.  If you hate reading on the other hand, and want information spoon fed to you, you wont like this.  Personally, I zone out when I listen to characters drone on and on about where I need to go and what I need to do.  Reading keeps me alert.  And the best part is, you can absorb the info you want.  If you want to be immersed, you can enjoy the lore.  If you only care about the objective, you can just read that bit as well.  Take in the info you want, and leave the rest.  Another benefit of no voice acting is that the dialogue feels more real.  There are fewer shared lines as a result of no voice acting.  Speech is more believable.- Exploration:  Morrowind does not have a compass.  Navigation must be done by using a map, and listening to the directions of others.  If an NPC is giving you directions to a house on the other side of town, you better listen to every turn they tell you to make, because you cannot just point your character in the right direction and run.  This is an inconvenience at first, but if you want to be fully immersed in the world, its a welcome change.  You need to actually explore the land, and look at where you are going.  Your eyes aren't glued to an arrow on a compass bar.  This is a change I love.- Seamless Cities:  In Morrowind, there are no loading screens to enter and exit a city.  This is fantastic because your immersion is never broken as you seamlessly explore Vvardenfell.  This also saves the pain of some instances where you accidentally enter a large complicated area by accident, only to turn back and deal with the loading screen twice.  Something to keep in mind is that because of this, a few of the cities and towns seem abnormally small, likely due to performance.  You wont find the same scale that is present in Skyrim because there is no loading screen to hide a massive world behind.  Cities are by no means tiny, just slightly smaller than you may expect.  It is something which is easy to get used to.And now, the only con I can think of:- Homes:  You cannot own a house in Morrowind.  You CAN take one from someone else though.
